fulltext.ft_body: Cheating Attacks and Resistance Techniques in GeoGame Design Robert J. Hall AT&T Labs Research Florham Park, NJ, 07932, USA hall@research.att.com ABSTRACT The GeoGames Architecture (GGA) supports the imple­mentation of electronic games that are to be played out­doors and that inherently incorporate vigorous physical ac­tivity. The basis of the GGA is to use geocast messaging within an ad hoc network of handheld devices, with game control implemented in a distributed fashion, without a cen­tral server and without requiring connection to the Internet cloud. This approach leads to several cheating attacks in­herent to ad hoc networking, distributed control, and the open and uncontrolled nature of the play areas. This paper analyzes the threats, describes speci.c attacks, and gives several techniques that increase a GeoGame s resistance to these attacks. The threats, attacks, and resistance tech­niques are illustrated in the context of a case study focusing on two signi.cantly di.erent GeoGames, iTESS and iTron. Categories and Subject Descriptors J.7 [Computers in Other Systems]: Consumer products; D.1 [Programming Techniques]: Concurrent Program­ming; C.2 [Computer-Communication Networks]: Dis­tributed Systems General Terms Design, Security Keywords ad hoc networking, geocast, game, GeoGame, cheating 1. INTRODUCTION Electronic games provide elements unobtainable or im­practical in real-world-only games, such as simulated weaponry, virtual structures, arti.cial creatures, and complex scoring systems. The attractions of such are well known, and yet electronic games have disadvantages as well. Players tend to exercise too little and spend too much leisure time indoors, Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 10 Vancouver, BC, Canada Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05...$10.00. missing out on the health, cognitive, and developmental ben­e.ts of vigorous outdoor play. The goal of the GeoGames research program (cf. [1]) is to provide multi-player elec­tronic games purposely designed for outdoor play, incorpo­rating vigorous physical activity, while still providing virtual elements that make games so attractive. By contrast, for ex­ample, the Wii game system s [11] innovative controllers and games provide vigorous play, but one must still remain in the immediate area in front of the television and game console, which keeps players from ranging over large outdoor areas or truly running, chasing, or climbing. GeoGame design presents several fundamental challenges. First, outdoor vigorous play obviously implies the need for wireless connections among players. Second, outdoor sce­narios typically involve a group of players in a park, camp, or other outdoor setting where it is inconvenient, insecure, or impossible to power and operate a central game server (such as a laptop) that is distinct from devices carried by players. This implies a need for distributing game control among peer handheld (or worn) devices. Third, these out­door venues often lack wireless network coverage, meaning that games cannot depend on constant connectivity of each player to a game server in the Internet cloud. Fourth, vig­orous play involves running, hiding, jumping, and climbing; all of these make it likely that pairs of players will frequently be subject to obstructed sight lines or too far apart for di­rect wireless communications, such as by bluetooth or wi. broadcasts. This implies a need for a more sophisticated style of ad hoc networking [8] than simple broadcasts. The GeoGames Architecture (GGA) is designed to sup­port this style of gaming under these conditions. It is based on the idea of distributing game control among carried or worn location-aware devices, with inter-device communica­tions implemented using a scalable ad hoc geocast proto­col. However, GeoGaming and the GGA also come with new ways to cheat. This paper s novel contributions include analyzing threat modes relevant to GeoGames, describing speci.c attacks within each of these, and de.ning eight de­sign techniques that can increase a GeoGame s resistance to cheating. All these are illustrated in the context of a case study focusing on two signi.cantly di.erent GeoGames, iTESS and iTron. 2. THE GEOGAMES ARCHITECTURE The GeoGames Architecture (GGA) is designed to sup­port vigorous game play under outdoor conditions in poten­tially large geographic areas having diverse terrain features. It is designed also for practicality, avoiding the need for extensive setup, installation, or operation of extra devices. Basically, players bring their devices with the software and maps loaded and can begin play immediately. The GGA is based on three key ideas. Game control is distributed among location aware hand­held devices (such as smart phones) carried or worn by players; Inter-device communication is based primarily on a scalable ad hoc wireless geocast protocol;and when long distance network support is available, an optional Long Range Extension (LRE) to GGA em­ploys a tiered geocast protocol that allows play over long distances. Each of these elements is brie.y overviewed here. Distributed Game Control. GeoGames should be playable by children as well as adults, using only devices they other­wise carry with them, such as smart phones. Requiring extra devices, like a laptop, brings several unacceptable burdens that would likely make GeoGames signi.cantly less success­ful. An extra device would have to be carried to and from the game area. It would have to be placed in the area in a way allowing communications from it to all players. It would likely have to be guarded by a person who therefore could not participate in the game, as no one would like to leave an expensive device unattended in uncontrolled out­door situations. And it needs to be protected from outdoor conditions like rain, snow, mud, wind, and .ying debris. On the other hand, smart phones themselves are either carried in the hand, or can even be worn in fully enclosed armband mounts that keep them secure from moisture and dirt, and from being dropped. Beyond physical considerations, however, GeoGames must avoid even logical centralized control. The di.culty is that as players move around rapidly over the play area, there is often no central point or device that maintains network contact with all devices at all times. People go around build­ings, into low spots, or behind hills; at any time they could be cut o. from contact with a device acting at that time as the server. Under a centralized control architecture, that would mean such devices are dropped or suspended from further game activities until contact is reestablished. Thus, the GGA requires fully distributed peer-to-peer control. As one example, in a game involving simulated weapons, a centralized architecture would require devices to report trigger pulls and device locations to a central server, which would assess damage and then distribute health updates to a.ected devices. However, such a design would fail when two players shoot it out o. by themselves behind a hill: even though the two devices can communicate with each other, they would be cut o. from network contact with other devices, including a central server. In the GGA, one would implement this type of interaction by having one device send a shot via a geocast message (see next section) directly to the area possibly a.ected by the shot. Because of the ad hoc and peer-to-peer design of this protocol, the message could travel directly from shooter to target (if a target is present who should be hit), without having to pass through distant devices. Thus, the isolated shoot out scenario would succeed in the GGA design. Scalable Ad Hoc Geocast. Geocast is a protocol imple­menting geographic addressing of network messages. The Figure 1: Geocast ad hoc propagation idea is that a packet is addressed by describing a region of space, known as the geocast region, to which the packet is to be delivered. The network then transfers this packet to all devices (if any) currently within the region. There are many ways to implement geographic addressing [4, 6, 7]; however, we focus in the GGA on the scalable, ad hoc, wireless geocast de.ned in [4]. Scalability is important in GeoGame design both because we envision the possibility of large scale games, such as large battle or sports simula­tion games, but also because GeoGames may be played in crowded park or beach settings where there can be hundreds of other devices around. Not all may be playing the game, but all are taking up resources doing other activities, as well as potentially propagating geocast messaging. An ad hoc protocol is one where messages are propagated peer to peer, without using routers or access points. Some ad hoc network protocols, and even some geocast protocols, use clusters and incorporate cluster formation as a necessary step. A cluster is a group of devices that all communicate via a single elected leader device, known as a cluster head. Inter-cluster messages travel .rst to the local cluster head and then to the head of the destination cluster before being delivered to the target devices. However, this violates our requirement for full distribution in the GGA: just as frequent disconnections can cause failures at the application level, such would also cause messaging to fail. The protocol de.ned in [4] is fully distributed and each node relies only on locally collected packet statistics to de­cide whether to transmit each packet. In brief, a node hear­ing a geocast transmission decides whether to retransmit it based on heuristic rules: for example, if only one copy has been heard, the node will retransmit; or, if all copies heard have been sent from at least a distance T away, the device will retransmit. The complete set of rules, parameters, and packet statistics used in the protocol are de.ned in [4]. The process is illustrated in Figure 1. In that scenario, de­vice B geocasts a message to devices D and E in the geocast region circle. First, B transmits. A hears the transmis­sion but because it is outside of the forwarding zone de.ned for the packet, it does not retransmit. Device C, however, is within the forwarding zone and retransmits the packet. This is heard by device D, who also retransmits. Between C s and D s transmissions, device E receives the geocast as Figure 2: Tiered geocast propagation well. Note that the message traversed the radio obstacle that prohibited B sending directly to D and E. Note that since this geocast protocol is implemented us­ing only basic broadcast transmissions, it can take place even without full network support. For example, there need be no IP routing system or domain name system present; devices need have no IP addresses (or can have only self-assigned, dummy IP addresses). On the other hand, if network sup­port is present, it can fully interoperate with normal IP networking, with each geocast transmission simply a UDP broadcast. Thus, this protocol can work either with or with­out network infrastructure support. This design achieves .ooding of the geocast region with­out the usual high cost of traditional .ooding algorithms. In studies of the selected protocol [4, 5], we see approximately constant scaling of transmissions per geocast as node den­sity increases. That is, adding more nodes to a local area (roughly) does not increase the number of retransmissions. Long Range Extension. If network infrastructure support is present in the GeoGame area, so that at least some of the devices can reach the Internet, the GGA supports an optional Long Range Extension (LRE) that enables geocast messages to propagate long distances. This would allow Ge­oGames played between players in di.erent cities or coun­tries around the world. For example, one half of a virtual volleyball court could be mapped out on the ground in Cal­ifornia, while the other half is in New York. A virtual ball can be hit back and forth via the LRE. The LRE is implemented via Tiered Geocast [5]. The idea is that one implements geocasting independently in separate network tiers; some nodes have interfaces to multiple tiers, and if a packet is received on one tier, the node will re­transmit it on the other tiers to which it is connected, with retransmission rules and other implementation algorithms operating independently. This process is illustrated in Figure 2. In this scenario, some of the mobile devices (2 and 3) have connections via a 3G network to geographic routers in the Internet. The sender is device 1, who wishes to geocast to the distant circle on the right side. The tiered geocast protocol proceeds .rst by device 1 transmitting in the ad hoc wireless network. This is received by device 2, who retransmits both in the ad hoc network and (via 3G) over the Internet. The latter step is computed by looking up which other geographic routers are close to the de.ned geocast region and sending to their IP addresses via normal Internet UDP. Device 3 receives the Figure 3: iTESS game situation display packet (via 3G) from the receiving router and retransmits on the ad hoc network, which is then received and retransmitted by device 4 in the geocast region, resulting in all devices in the geocast region receiving it. Note that using the LRE requires that some devices have interfaces to a long range tier, but it does not require that all do so. For example, it is enough for one member of each volleyball team to have a 3G-capable device while others play on WiFi-only devices, as long as the 3G-capable device also has a WiFi interface. 3. CASE STUDY: TWO GEOGAMES To illustrate the use of GGA, and to use in studying cheat­ing attacks and resistance techniques, I describe here two GeoGames, iTESS and iTron. These have been implemented as prototypes running on Apple iPhones. iTESS. iTESS can be thought of as hide-and-seek with (simulated) artillery and surveillance devices. (TESS stands for tactical engagement simulation system, a term borrowed from military training.) In principle, the play area is the entire world, but in practice, iTESS is played in an area cov­ered by one or more maps loaded on the devices. Typically, a mapped area covers a few square kilometers and includes terrain features like hills, buildings, and landscaped areas. The goal of the game is to survive the longest. Players target each other with artillery by tapping a map display on the handheld and pressing the Fire button. Op­ponents positions are not displayed on the handheld by default. If one sees the other person directly (i.e. in the real world), one can try to point on the map and target by relative position to landmarks; however, that is di.cult to do accurately. iTESS also provides each player an Un­manned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) simulation for surveillance. iTESS UAVs are simulated radio-controlled airplanes hav­ing simulated look-down video cameras. They move slowly, and their look-down area is relatively limited (50 meter ra­dius). The user commands their course using taps on the map display to set waypoints. Once the UAV locates an opponent, the location is painted as a red dot on the user s map display, allowing accurate targeting. Figure 3 shows a screen shot from the iTESS implemen­tation illustrating these elements. The map represents an area approximately 500 x 750 meters. Here, the blue dot is the position of the player holding the device. His UAV is indicated in light green: the line shows its recent course, the circle shows its current look-down area. It has .own over one opponent (upper red dot) and then over another on its way to the commanded waypoint in the lower right. The blue shaded circle over the upper red dot shows that this player has targeted that opponent and a shell is in .ight. The targeting reticle (black circle with crosshair) containing the other opponent shows that this player is about to .re at the other opponent. Once an artillery shot is .red, there is a delay simulating the fact that artillery shells take many seconds to reach their target. During this time, players near the target area have red circles painted on their displays warning of the incom­ing round, simulating having radar to detect in-.ight shells. Two such are shown in Figure 3 indicating two in-.ight shots that will narrowly miss the player. If a targeted player can run out of the e.ect circle in time, the round will miss. iTESS requires physical activity both when covering ground in the stealth and planning mode of play as well as when sprinting away from incoming rounds. iTESS implementation. iTESS shots are implemented by the shooter s device sending a geocast message to an area containing the e.ect circle of the simulated shell. Devices in that area then wait until the end of the .ight time, determine whether the unit s position at that time is within the e.ect circle, and if so adjudicate game over. Also during that time, the red shaded circle is displayed on the unit s display. iTESS UAVs are implemented as follows. The device keeps track of the UAV s position at all times via a sim­ple real-time .ight path simulation. Once per 2 seconds, the device geocasts a UAV-query message to a circle of ra­dius 50 meters around the UAV s current position. Any iTESS devices receiving the geocast then respond immedi­ately with a UAV-query-response geocast back to a circle around the sender s position, from which the sender can ex­tract their positions. These are then painted on the display as red dots. iTron. iTron is based on one of the video games depicted in the 1980s movie Tron, as well as a family of related games (such as Snake). Players positions are depicted on a map display on the device. A virtual game stadium is declared and players within it can join by tapping in . Once the game starts, as players move, they leave a tail of virtual wall behind them. The object is to survive the longest with­out crashing into a wall. Players are compelled to move at a minimum speed or else their tail catches up and hits them. In a team variant, players on the same team can move through their type of wall but not the opponents (still maintaining a minimum speed). iTron is played with the human players supplying the movement by running or walking. The location-aware hand­held measures position in real time. Its display shows the map, one s own and opponents positions, and walls as they are built. Obviously, this requires vigorous physical activity. Figure 4: Seven player iTron. In fact, the more vigorous, the better are one s chances of winning; a common strategy is to surround one s opponents in as small an area as possible. To do this, one needs to outrun them. Figure 4 shows a screen shot from the implementation depicting a seven player instance of iTron. It can be played on any size map, though at larger scales it becomes di.cult to see what is going on when players are close together. The map shown represents an area 600 x 900 meters. Of course, iTron need not necessarily be played on foot: players could skate, ride bikes or, as in the movie, ride motorcycles (lightcycles, actually). Faster movement will make larger maps easier to use. Any player may declare a stadium and game start time by tapping and dragging between opposite corners of the rectangle on the map and then tapping Join. The devices periodically (e.g. once per second) take po­sition .xes using the built-in location framework of the lo­cation aware smartphone. After each new .x, the device computes whether the latest tail segment crosses any other segment (either its own tail, an opponent s tail, or a stadium wall). If it computes that an intersection has occurred, it moves to the game-over state. iTron implementation. The game is mediated by fre­quent inter-player messages. Each unit periodically geocasts a player state message to the stadium in which it is play­ing. Other devices in the same game receive and record the information on all other players. This information in­cludes game de.nition, game state (i.e. whether the player has crashed), current position of the player, and his (up to 100) most recent tail segments. Each device uses this to construct the game display and to determine when he has crashed. Each device adjudicates its own crashes. Once the device determines that the player has crashed, all sub­sequent player state messages have unchanging information, i.e. that device s wall becomes .xed for the rest of the game. Note in Figure 4 that the iTron stadium is drawn to sur­round four buildings and a pond. This points out the need for network messaging to incorporate peer-to-peer relaying so that geocasts can reach all players in the game area. A simple broadcast-based scheme would lead to severe discon­nectivity problems. The elapsed time at which the crash occurred is displayed on the device display. To determine the winner, the players gather after they have all crashed out and simply compare screens to see who had the longest elapsed time. Each device also geocasts crash-noti.cation text messages to the game area for the information of other players, but the o.cial results are contained on the device screens themselves. 4. THREAT MODES We analyze cheat vulnerabilities into threat modes, spe­ci.c attacks within a threat mode, and possible techniques for resisting or mitigating attacks. A threat mode is a cat­egory of attacks de.ned by a particular set of assumptions about what is trusted and what is not trusted. This section describes the three main threat modes. The next three sec­tions elaborate on each one with speci.c attacks, responses, and examples from the case study. Player-only: In player-only, we assume that all de­vices are trusted and they are running the intended software with no malicious add-ons. During the game, the devices (and software load) remain uncompromised. Furthermore, there are no external devices present un­der untrusted control whose behavior a.ects game play. The only untrusted elements are the players. This mode is expected to be most commonly encoun­tered, as others require signi.cant preparation or re­source acquisition. This one is constrained only by the creativity and ethical character of the players. External-device: In external-device, we assume at­tackers may additionally use external devices and may have the help of (non-player) confederates. For exam­ple, since GeoGames are played in uncontrolled out­door settings, it is easy for a player to stash a wireless­capable laptop in the bushes near the play area run­ning malicious scripts. This sort of attack is much more di.cult in traditional console gaming with wired controllers; even with wireless controllers (connected by bluetooth or infrared), since the game play occurs typically in a home or other controlled environment, it is more di.cult to carry out this type of attack. It is unlikely this type of threat is worth the e.ort in casual play among friends. However, with su.cient motivation, such as in tournaments played for money, this type of threat is potentially serious. Compromised-device: Here, we assume it is possi­ble for players to alter either the hardware or software (or both) running on their device and possibly even those of the other players. With or without the aid of external devices, compromised-device attacks are hard­est to defeat. However, this threat mode is shared by all game architectures, not just GeoGames. If an at­tacker can load arbitrary code on the device, virtually any game can be cheated. Compounding this problem, software-only cheats, once created, can be easily dis­tributed via the Internet, so this type of attack is often easy to copy once done the .rst time. The next sections discuss speci.c attacks and defenses. 5. PLAYER-ONLY THREAT MODE If the player is using trusted device and software, he is limited to external manipulations consistent with normal use of the device. The design principles of the GeoGames Architecture leave it vulnerable to cheat attacks based on its properties. Three such attack classes discussed here are network interdiction, GPS interdiction, and game interrup­tion. I will illustrate each attack using iTESS and iTron. I will then describe resistance techniques for each attack and discuss how they can be applied in the case study. 5.1 Network Interdiction Attacks A network interdiction attack is one in which the cheater purposely interferes with the operation of the wireless net­work at a chosen time in order to avoid receiving one or more messages that would cause an unfavorable change of device state. One way to do this is to insert the device in a metal enclosure, like a foil pouch, which cuts o. all radio reception; another is to move the device so as to increase Fresnel Zone interference, say, by moving into a depression so that the line of sight to the transmitter skims or inter­sects the Earth s surface. The iTESS and iTron prototypes use 802.11 based networking operating at 2.4 GHz and so are quite susceptible to Fresnel Zone interference. Case Study Examples. In iTESS, such cheating can help by allowing one s device to miss receiving the geocast shot message from an opponent. If the device does not receive it, the player will not be hit. Also, if one can keep one s device from receiving UAV query messages, it will not send back responses that would allow opponents to locate it. In iTron, interdicting game state messages from an op­ponent means that the opponent s tail will not change on the cheater s device, so the cheater could move across the opponent s actual path without crashing. Resistance Techniques. Method RT-1 for increasing re­sistance to network interdiction attacks is to disincent being out of contact by detecting and penalizing the network dis­connectivity condition. Not all game designs make it possible to distinguish network disconnectivity from simple device si­lence due to player inaction. To implement RT-1, one typi­cally introduces periodic or other guaranteed transmissions. iTESS can incorporate RT-1 as follows. Each device keeps track of how long it has been since the last time it received any network packet, including those below the application level, such as received geocast transmissions not destined for the unit itself. Call this received silence time s.If s reaches a threshold, such as 4 seconds, the unit enters penalty mode. It displays an out-of-contact indicator on the display and reduces the time in game (i.e. the score in iTESS) by k seconds per second (beyond s) of real time out of contact. Larger k (such as k = 10 or 20) results in sti.er penalties for being out of contact. In iTESS it is natural for devices to be silent for extended periods if they are not using the UAV and not shooting or messaging. Thus, RT-1 requires that all devices send a periodic dummy transmission if the unit goes more than a speci.ed keep-alive period, such as 2 seconds without trans­mitting. This dummy transmission is only sent if the unit itself hasn t generated a transmission normally. It causes no application level state changes, but is provided merely to support connectivity detection. Note that these dummy transmissions should not be retransmitted at all, since all devices do them independently anyway. Being infrequent and unretransmitted, it does not impose an undue burden on wireless network resources. RT-1 does not guarantee constant total connectivity of all devices to each other, merely that each device can reach at least one other. This defends against placing the device in a foil pouch, but has limitations; it is possible for a player to arrange to be in contact with one other device, while positioning himself to maximize Fresnel Zone obstructions between him and a shooter. Thus, RT-1 is a resistance tech­nique rather than a guaranteed cheat prevention. Note that RT-1 causes the player to have to think about network connectivity. One may view this as undesirable, as it may detract from the dramatic illusion being portrayed in the game (e.g. of weaponry and surveillance drones). How­ever, while a perfect illusion is desirable, the physical reality of today s radio technology intrudes. Instead, I believe sim­ple radio connectivity reasoning (lines of sight, proximity to obstacles) can be a fun added game element, as one comes to plan one s connectivity along with one s shots. This hy­pothesis is yet to be veri.ed with user testing. Method RT-2 compensates for lost messages with redun­dancy. For example, iTESS can implement this for lost shot messages by having units repeat the shot messages many times, once per second. The e.ect of this is that the cheater s unit must remain out of contact through all the repetitions as well and, hence, be penalized heavily via RT-1. If it re­ceives one of the later repetitions without receiving the .rst message, it su.ers two problems: (a) it will still receive the shot and be hit at the same time it would have been had it received the .rst message, and (b) it will have the added dis­advantage of having less time to run out of the way. iTESS UAV queries are naturally repeated anyway, so RT-2 is im­plemented there as well. RT-2 is useful also in iTron, if we include in the transmit­ted state messages the time of each position .x in the tail. Then, if a unit is out of contact with a particular opponent for a period, once they come back in contact the intersection algorithm can examine its own history and that of its op­ponent to determine if and when it crossed the opponent s tail, based on the positions and times of the .xes. Thus, the attack outlined above, where one purposely interdicts a few messages in order to cross a wall will be defeated when the unit later discovers the intersection. The .x time infor­mation is technically redundant, since less resilient update algorithms can be implemented which do not use times in the packets. However, .x times allow accurate determina­tion of who crossed a tail .rst. 5.2 GPS Interdiction Attacks Today s devices typically sense their location either ex­clusively or with the assistance of the Global Positioning System (GPS). This involves receiving radio signals from sets of GPS satellites. If one s device does not receive these signals correctly, the device can infer a highly inaccurate lo­cation. This can be useful to a cheater, for example, if one needs to quickly move one s location to avoid a game haz­ard. Satellite signals can be interdicted in similar ways to 802.11 signals; however, di.erent speci.c techniques may be useful due to GPS operating on di.erent wavelengths. This means di.erent types of things are obstacles for GPS than for 802.11. Because of the unpredictability of inaccurate location .xes, this attack is risky for the cheater. For example, a long jump might transport the cheater past the iTron stadium wall, which would be an immediate crash. Still, such tricks may be worth the risk in some situations. One might, in fact, in some GeoGame designs, even choose to allow it as a legal game element. We assume here that the designer wishes to disallow it, so using it is cheating. Case Study Examples. In iTESS, for example, if one is about to be hit by a shot, jumping far away instanta­neously via GPS interdiction can save one from being hit. In iTron, this sort of jumping can move one much faster than an opponent can physically run, possibly enabling one to surround more area. Resistance Techniques. Method RT-3 compensates for GPS interdiction attacks by detecting and penalizing impos­sible movements. For example, if we assume that humans on foot can move at a maximum of 6 meters per second, a jump of 100 meters in a second is clearly physically invalid. Dis­tinguishing jumps due to sensor inaccuracy from high speed movements becomes more di.cult if one is allowed to use vehicles during GeoGame play, of course, so RT-3 becomes less useful in such situations. In iTESS and iTron played on foot, one can easily detect almost all GPS interdiction attacks. In iTESS, detecting such a major jump could cause a time penalty to be applied, subtracting some large number of seconds from the current elapsed time. Alternatively, it could cause an immediate game over, meaning the player gets whatever elapsed time had been accrued prior to the jump and must then start over from zero elapsed. In iTron, this could also result in a game over as well, meaning the jump is equivalent to crashing. A limitation of the use of RT-3 is that sometimes the de­vices lose satellite lock naturally due to motion, proximity of obstacles and terrain features, etc. Consequently there is some jumpiness of location reports even under normal op­erations. Some level of noise tolerance must be built in to RT-3 so that natural GPS jumpiness, which is quite preva­lent on today s devices, is tolerated. A simple threshold scheme separating jumps of up to 20 meters from huge ones of 100 meters or more is a good start at this. 5.3 Game Interruption Attacks Since, according to the GGA, the game is controlled in a distributed fashion by all units working together, it is poten­tially vulnerable to a cheater turning o. his unit, relaunching the game application, or otherwise interrupting its operation to gain advantage. Case Study Examples. In iTESS, because there is concep­tually one in.nite game incorporating the whole Earth and all time, exiting and rejoining the game must be incorpo­rated as a natural part. One cannot be shot when out of the game, and one cannot be detected by UAVs. Also, restart­ing the game replenishes one s supply of weapons. Restart­ing iTron would erase one s tail and all stored information about one s opponents. Thus, these games must be designed to resist cheating-by-restarting. Resistance Techniques. Method RT-4 avoids game inter­ruption attacks by penalizing game restarts. In iTESS, the object is to obtain the highest elapsed time in-game; score is not related to number of kills . A game restart sets one s elapsed time back to zero, so one cannot improve one s score by restarting. Method RT-5 avoids game interruption attacks by dis­playing a unique game identi.er which includes start time on each display and disallowing game reentry after game start. This is not applicable to iTESS by its design. However, if one could re-enter an iTron game after it started, one could gain signi.cant advantage. Thus, each declared iTron game is identi.ed uniquely by the device ID of the game declarer plus the declared start time. These two numbers are dis­played as the game serial number on the game display. One may only tap in to an iTron game during the 30 second countdown period between .rst declaration and start; after the start time is reached, one may no longer join. Thus, we are guaranteed that when the players compare displays at the end of the game, only those players displaying the correct game identi.er information should be counted as .nishing. 6. EXTERNAL-DEVICE THREAT MODE A player (or non-playing confederate) can attack Ge­oGames communications by operating an external wireless­capable device. The open and uncontrolled character of Ge­oGame play areas allows hiding and operating such devices more easily than would be the case in other gaming venues. Here we again assume that the players handheld devices are trusted. External device attacks include network interdiction and packet insertion. This section again illustrates these attacks using the case study and describes resistance techniques. 6.1 Network Interdiction A wireless device, such as a laptop hidden in the bushes somewhere, could e.ectively jam communications for the GeoGame. This can be exploited by a cheating player to prevent his own device from receiving unfavorable packets. Beyond simple jamming, a more clever device could jam only packets originated from selected players while allowing pack­ets from others. For example, by altering .rmware or drivers for the wireless card, one could program it to recognize the MAC addresses of selected players and, if detected, imme­diately transmit noise to corrupt the ends of those packets. Even more sophisticated attacks could jam certain packet types or even selected packet types from selected players. Case Study Examples. We have already seen in Section 5 how network interdiction can be used by a cheater to gain advantage. We can adapt these to external device attacks. For example, simple blanket jamming by the external device could result in dead areas on the playing .eld; a cheater could retreat to these areas to interdict his communications. Alternatively, the external device could be programmed to selectively jam only shot packets originated by non-cheating players. This would leave the cheater as the only one capable of launching a shot successfully. Section 5 described how network interdiction can bene.t a cheater in iTron. Again, the simplest approach is to use blanket jamming of a known area so that the cheater can, for example, choose to loiter in the dead area while opponents spend time in other areas actually competing. A selective packet jamming attack would jam only game state messages of the non-cheating players, so that the cheater not only could loiter in the jammed area, but could build walls around it to keep the others out. Resistance Techniques. RT-1 and RT-2 are e.ective against the cheater in a blanket-jamming network interdiction at­tack, but they also penalize non-cheaters. When non-cheaters try and fail to get back into contact, it alerts them to the possibility of jamming. Selective jamming attacks, however, are not addressed by them, since some packets are allowed through. To address the more general case of selective jam­ming, method RT-6 exploits properties of geocast opera­tion: each device listens for retransmissions of geocasts it originates; if it hears no retransmissions, it indicates jam­ming to the user via the display. If over the course of a game players notice the jamming display present, then it should cause a further investigation. In iTESS, this would help detect the selective shot jamming problem, as the shooter would see the indicator each time he shot. In iTron, the jamming indicator would be on constantly on the displays of selectively jammed players. Note that there can be occasions, such as when the player is completely isolated from all other devices, that RT-1 will detect out-of-contact and RT-6 will erroneously indicate jam­ming, because there are no other devices nearby to retrans­mit the device s geocasts. Ultimately, it is up to the players to decide, based on when and how often they have received jamming indications, whether they need to investigate fur­ther for external devices. 6.2 Packet Insertion An external device can easily send packets that are con­structed to appear as if they came from a legitimate player s device. In an insecure wireless ad hoc network, this class of attacks can target the application level, such as by send­ing false shot, UAV query response, or scoring messages. However, it can also target the protocol level, for example by aggressively retransmitting geocasts as early as possible (before other devices can retransmit normally), yet alter­ing or corrupting the packets. Attacks spoo.ng or jamming GPS signals are also known [2]. Case Study Examples. In iTESS, an external device un­der control of a cheater (or non-playing confederate) could launch unlimited shot messages against opponents, giving the cheater an overwhelming ammo load advantage. It could also send spoofed UAV query responses which would provide an incorrect position of the cheater to other players. In iTron, an external device could send to the cheater s device inaccurate game state messages for opponents, such as with o.set or missing tail segments, thereby allowing the cheater to move where otherwise a crash would result. Spoofed GPS signals applied at selected times could help an iTESS cheater quickly move out of a shot e.ect area or to sprint ahead of iTron opponents to help surround them. Resistance Techniques. The straight forward solution to packet insertion by external devices is RT-7: use digital sig­natures [9] to provide network packet authentication. That is, a signing and veri.cation key, such as an AES key, is issued in common to all valid installations of the GeoGame app. Each packet is digitally signed using this key, and a device receiving a packet .rst veri.es the signature on the packet, discarding any packet for which veri.cation fails. Assuming this key is known only on the trusted devices, the external device cannot create a valid packet, so its packets will be ignored by trusted devices. One might think replay attacks are possible by having the external device retransmit packets it hears on the medium. However, it is a nice property of geocast communications that geocasts are invulnerable to packet-replay attacks: the protocol is built to use retransmissions of packets, so each node is designed to handle hearing multiple copies of each packet, processing at most one such copy. Replayed packets from an external device will not cause invalid repetitions or other unwanted state changes. One weakness of RT-7 is that if the shared signing key is distributed with the application download, it is always pos­sible that a cheater could reverse engineer the key out of the download and then transfer this to the external device. This would then allow the device to insert packets. A solution to this problem, RT-8,is to design the devices to accept one or more passphrase strings at the outset of play via the de­vice s user interface; use the passphrase strings to generate the secret shared key. Thus, in one usage scenario, a single trusted player enters this passphrase into the device of each player without disclosing it to other players. Assuming the trusted player is not the cheater, the external device has no way of getting the key. An even stronger method is for each of two players to enter a passphrase into each device; the key is then constructed from both passphrases (e.g. by XORing them), with no single player knowing enough to reconstruct the key. This scheme can, of course, be extended to the case of all players entering a passphrase into each device playing. In that case, no proper subset of the players can collude to infer the key for use by the external device. The variants with two or more players entering passphrases are variations of the secret splitting scheme in [9] (p.70). Note that GPS spoo.ng [2] cannot be prevented in this way, since public GPS signals are not encrypted. This is a serious open problem for many systems, including navigation and other systems outside the gaming world. 7. COMPROMISED-DEVICE ATTACKS Attacks where a cheater gains access to and can alter the software load running on the device and/or alter the hard­ware itself, are extremely di.cult to defend against. These attacks are not new, as all electronic game architectures are susceptible to them. The GeoGames architecture is really neither more nor less susceptible, though the fact that game control is implemented in a distributed fashion across all players devices means there are that many more devices that could be subject to compromise, as compared with a single central console or game server, for example. Such attacks are of concern in GeoGames, but at this point remain an open area for future work. There has been initial encouraging work on this sort of problem, however. In [3], the authors describe a study using the Trusted Platform Module [10] to verify that the software load running on a public kiosk machine is the one believed/intended. Such an approach is not yet practical on smart phones and other low capability computing devices, however, as the necessary hardware is not present. 8. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK GeoGames are designed to incorporate vigorous physical activity outdoors. They can be implemented using the Ge­oGames Architecture, which is based upon fully distributed control mediated by a scalable wireless geocast protocol. However, the GGA brings with it new ways to cheat. This paper has reported on an initial analysis of this problem. Its novel contributions include detailed description of the GGA, de.nition of threat modes, attack categories within each, eight resistance techniques, and applications of these within the context of a case study of two signi.cantly di.er­ent GeoGames, iTESS and iTron. The three threat modes, player-only, external-device, and compromised-device each bring di.erent attacks and responses. Among these, net­work and GPS interdiction, packet insertion, and game in­terruption are the main attack categories. I have outlined eight resistance techniques, RT-1 through RT-8, which can help increase the resistance of GeoGames to these cheating attacks. I have also shown how two case study GeoGames, iTESS and iTron, can be hardened using these techniques. This work has demonstrated encouraging initial progress on attacks within two of the three threat modes, player­only and external-device. Speci.c limitations of the RT-i have been discussed above; beyond those, the compromised­device threat mode is still as di.cult as ever and, perhaps, exacerbated slightly by the fact that, in the GGA, game con­trol is implemented across devices owned by all the players. Future work will proceed from this basis to explore more threat modes and attacks, such as device-speci.c attacks like clock-compromise and cell-call-processing attacks. We will also create and explore new GeoGames for novel attacks and resistance techniques, and continue pursuing ways to apply trusted computing techniques in small mobile devices. 9. article_rec.title: Game design for ad-hoc multi-touch gameplay on large tabletop displays

abstract.par: This paper examines game design for multi-touch enabled systems, focusing on tabletop computers that are exposed to the public. We first elaborate on the requirements for ad-hoc collaborative multi-touch gameplay. As our main contribution, we identified particular gameplay aspects and formalized them in reference to formal elements of gameplay: The game mechanics should support different scopes of involvement and make use of spatial conflicts that relate to the player resources. The game should further offer outcomes that can be achieved in continuous ad-hoc group gameplay. Based on these criteria, we developed the multi-touch game Magic Garden. The case shows, how the defined elements support game creation for ad-hoc collaborative multi-touch play. As a final result, we propose to combine multiple separate mini-games in a mixed scenario as a general approach for the creation of multi-touch games for large public displays.

fulltext.ft_body: Game Design for Ad-Hoc Multi-Touch Gameplay on Large Tabletop Displays Jonas Schild Entertainment Computing Group University of Duisburg-Essen 47057 Duisburg, Germany jonas.schild@uni-due.de ABSTRACT This paper examines game design for multi-touch enabled systems, focusing on tabletop computers that are exposed to the public. We .rst elaborate on the requirements for ad-hoc collaborative multi-touch gameplay. As our main contribution, we identi.ed particular gameplay aspects and formalized them in reference to formal elements of gameplay: The game mechanics should support di.erent scopes of in­volvement and make use of spatial con.icts that relate to the player resources. The game should further o.er outcomes that can be achieved in continuous ad-hoc group gameplay. Based on these criteria, we developed the multi-touch game Magic Garden. The case shows, how the de.ned elements support game creation for ad-hoc collaborative multi-touch play. As a .nal result, we propose to combine multiple sep­arate mini-games in a mixed scenario as a general approach for the creation of multi-touch games for large public dis­plays. Categories and Subject Descriptors H.5.3 [Information Interfaces and Presentation]: Group and Organization Interfaces Collaborative Comput­ing, Synchronous Interaction; K.8.0 [Personal Comput­ing]: General Games General Terms Design Keywords games, multi-touch, game design, ad-hoc gameplay, collab­oration, game interaction patterns 1. INTRODUCTION With commercial success of multi-touch powered electro­nic devices such as the Apple iPhone, games using multi­touch input are commonly used by the public. These pri­marily involve one player per screen at a time, due to the Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2010, May 6-7 2010 Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 ...$5.00. Maic Masuch Entertainment Computing Group University of Duisburg-Essen 47507 Duisburg, Germany maic.masuch@uni-due.de small screen size. On the contrary, usage of large multi-touch displays or surface computers [17] is often restricted to se­lected public places such as hotel lobbies [18], bars [19] or museums [11]. Other o.-line examples include chess boards in public parks, public art exhibitions and installations, or board game-equipped tables in caf´es [6]. In this ad-hoc con­text, people typically enter a game without prior intention of play or previous experience in the game. Still, there are no public multi-touch games that achieve appeal by a broader audience, it is di.cult to design such games, and there is no general approach for doing so. In the following, we analyze the requirements of ad-hoc play based on previous work. As a .rst contribution, we propose a generalization of game design elements for such systems based on our analyses and o.er implications for the game creation process. We then show in a case study, how we applied these aspects to the multi-touch game Magic Gar­den. We give .rst reactions of actual players to the proto­type and assess the previously provided formalizations, lead­ing to a set of recommendations that concludes this paper. 2. RELATED WORK The described context has been further observed by Cao et al., who identi.ed goals for such public ad-hoc games using a large display [4]. These goals include simplicity, a broad appeal to di.erent audiences, support for ad-hoc joining and leaving, and for cooperative play and communication. Recent work on multi-touch collaborative play has been summarized by Khaled et al. [12] who further analyzed the topic by creating and testing two multi-touch tabletop games. They observed hesitation to enter the game and ad­hoc collaboration to occur out of a social context primar­ily caused by spatial proximity rather than by self-induced group organization. Thus, players in such games prefer to play sole with optional collaboration in the case of a emerg­ing social context with another player within the real envi­ronment. In this regard, the authors emphasize the social impact of sound, as it is the only feedback that is shared among all players. Another important aspect is interaction, that is both promising through its fascinating novelty, and di.cult because of the implication of unknown or untrained a.ordances. This highly depends on the technical quality, namely on input latency. Echtler et al. describe a possible way to overcome hesita­tion in ad-hoc play (or casual interaction as they call it) by mixing collaborative tabletop gaming and nearby solo play. The players can choose to either join playing at the table or to transfer the current game state to their mobile phones in order to play the game in a further remote social context. To distinguish touches between players and to track their lo­cations at the table, their Sudoku-based prototype connects to the players mobile phones. To enable play from all four sides of the table, the Sudoku numbers are displayed from all four directions [6]. Esenther and Wittenburg explore some possible designs most of which include direct re-alignment of objects on a surface, or are a direct transfer of existing board games [7], which can be enhanced with augmented reality [16] and thus be treated as pervasive games [15]. Such games are also described as surface games that enhance classic design of tabletop games through tangible interaction [3] on a surface computer [13]. Other approaches focus on creating inno­vative usage of additional sensor information [2, 9] or on e.cient (i.e. easy to learn and innovative) touch interaction [24, 5]. The previous reports show di.culties related to their tech­nical implementations, such as user identi.cation, latency, precision, resolution, maximum number of parallel touches, or occlusion problems caused by both front-or backprojec­tion. These problems often have a strong impact on game design decisions but are speci.c to the current state of tech­nology or even to respective single solutions only. Thus, taking the resulting constraints into account should be one part of a good game design. All these results and insights are helpful for designing multi-touch games, but what are the actual implications for a general approach of a game design process? 3. ELEMENTS OF GAME DESIGN To generalize game design for multi-touch enabled systems featuring large displays that allow for collaborative ad-hoc gameplay, we propose to formalize the characteristics in ref­erence to the formal elements introduced by Fullerton et al. [8], i.e. Players, Objectives, Procedures, Rules, Resources, Con.ict, Boundaries, and Outcome. 3.1 Players and Touches Players can play alone, focused on a single part of the display, or they can collaborate with one or many others. They can also multi-task, doing multiple things at a time. Multiple players can organize collaboration, thus enabling to act as one player with massive multi-input capabilities. As a result, we propose to not di.erentiate between play­ers and touch events unless each touch has a user identi.ca­tion. Even common multi-touch interaction techniques such as pinch or zoom can be invoked by multiple .ngers of one or multiple players working together. Another good reason for this decision is related to the player interaction patterns. All patterns listed by Fullerton can be easily transfered to touches instead of players, resulting in a list of touch inter­action patterns: Single touch vs. game: Touching and moving an object around to control the game. Multiple individual touches vs. game: Using multiple .ngers or hands to manipulate one or multiple objects in a game, also pinch and zoom gestures. Touch vs. touch: The impact of one touch can be coun­ tered by another touch. One touch vs. many other touches: (unilateral compe­ tition) One touch has an impact that can only be coun­tered through multiple touches, e.g. one touch controls a gun trigger while the other touches control targets that have to avoid the gun. Many touches vs. many other touches: (multilateral competition) Many touch-triggered guns to shoot at multiple touch objects. Cooperative touches: Multiple touches are needed to be invoked together for a common manipulation or objec­ tive. Team competition: Multiple sets of cooperative touches compete with each other. To di.erentiate these patterns and map them to single game mechanics might provide a good approach to create a set of game interaction techniques. 3.2 Contextual Objectives, Rules and Proce­dures As in other games, objectives can be structured into over­all game objectives, sub-, or mini-objectives. In ad-hoc multi-touch play, players .rst try to .nd out what can be done with a certain virtual object within an interactive envi­ronment. This step, which is normally just a part of learning a game, becomes part of the game in ad-hoc play and should be thus treated di.erently. According to our observations and previous .ndings [12], people .rst passing by a tabletop display just watch other players play. Most hesitate to interact until they feel to know what to do according to what other players do, or based on design implications and similarities to real-life objects. Then they try to induce activity to an object, like pushing a button, moving an object around or changing orientation and scale. They are more likely to apply touch gestures if they know them from other devices or when they receive hints from the system. The next step is to combine one object with another ob­ject, like moving objects close to each other, e.g. a key to a lock. While in the beginning a player might primarily act on his/her own, eventually the target object might be in use by another player, leading to collaboration of two people. Another way to induce this is to include functionality in an object that clearly implicates usage by multiple users, e.g. creating a bucket with three handles instead of one or two. Collaborating users later on might organize their activities. In summary, objectives, the underlying procedures, and rules should be designed for the following three di.erent scopes, so that each object bears functionality on its own, when combined with others, and when collaborating with other players. Extending this concept to the complexity of interaction, we propose the following three contextual stages of public play: 1. Ad-hoc play: Almost automatic gameplay that in­vites spectators to simple interactions; very little know­ledge about the game world is needed. 2. Committed play: More elaborate interaction try­ing to support single player gameplay with multi-touch features that have to be learned and have an impact on the game world. 3. Involved play: Deeper game interaction together with other players to combine di.erent tasks to col­laboratively achieve a group outcome. Table 1: A basis for design game mechanics in ad-hoc multi-touch gameplay Formal Elements Description Options Touch patterns Design the according interactions not for each single touch vs. game, multiple individual player but based on the proposed set of touch touches vs. game, touch vs. touch, interaction patterns unilateral competition, multilateral competition, cooperative touches, team competition touches Contextual objectives, Design multiple sets of objectives, procedures ad-hoc play, committed play, involved play rules, and procedures and rules, in order to support the three di.erent contextual stages of play involvement Spatial con.ict and The game should o.er di.erent tasks at spatial con.ict, resource management of attention resources di.erent locations and make use of the touch interactions, visual and auditive con.icts and resources speci.c to multi-touch attention, individual performance vs. group play awareness Ad-hoc boundaries Overcome boundaries by o.ering outcomes short-time group play, score-collecting bases and outcome that allow for organized or continuous play for individuals or groups, intrinsic motivation through magic moments 3.3 Spatial Con.ict and Attention Resources One aspect of large display games for multiple players is that one player can only focus on a certain part of the display and can interact with two hands and ten .ngers in maximum reach. His/her attention and the triggering of touch events are limited resources that have to be managed. With each touch event the probability for the next touch event gets lower with distance to the .rst event. Previous studies fur­ther show that users separate regions into personal, group, and storage territories which all serve di.erent purposes in a design process [21]. This behavior depends on the social context and the people involved, e.g. children do not hesi­tate to reach over to other children s areas [20]. Still, from the amount and spatial alignment of touches at di.erent locations, to be visualized in activity maps, a game could estimate areas that are easily accessible or hard to reach by the players. This aspect can be used to balance the game throughout play. Previous work states the necessity to design visual ele­ments in order to make them recognizable by all players in all directions of the table [6]. Instead, we propose to regard spatial alignment and orientation as a method to create con­.ict and challenge. As an example, it should be di.cult for players to identify and match equal human faces in di.erent orientations. Two important aspects in mastering novel interaction in a cooperative setup are feedback to individual actions and group awareness. We identi.ed di.erent characteristics for the two modalities vision and audio: Visual feedback either relates to particular touch events and possibly a.ects only one or few players, or it a.ects the whole display to catch attention of all players. Regarding group awareness, it is often unclear who of the other players might have noticed a certain visual event, as it would require to watch other players gazes to .nd out about their current focus. This gaze awareness often implicitly occurs in co­located environments [22]. However, its occurrence is not predictable and is not reliable in providing group awareness. In contrast, auditive feedback is appropriate to create group awareness, as it is normally heard by everyone. De­spite, giving auditive feedback to an individual user input causes irritation among other players, if they are not aware of that input. Thus, auditive feedback mostly a.ects all players at the same time, unless each of the players has his/her own speaker or the sounds are being coded di.er­ently for each user, e.g. through di.erent levels of pitch [10]. There are two shortcomings of such a solution: .rst, each player has to learn the information coding, which is dif­.cult when the visual focus does not include the origin of a sound. Second, too much auditive information not relevant in the .rst place is likely to be overheard as noise, especially considering environmental noise in public places. Thus, the trade-o. between group awareness and individ­ual feedback can be controlled through volume levels, as the higher the volume, the more likely the events get noticed by other players. Although note that increased awareness on other players activities reduces individual performance [10]. These aspects can also be combined in systems that al­low for multi-modal interaction such as speech-extended ges­tures, as Tse et al. show with Warcraft III and The Sims [22]. But, regarding multi-touch systems lacking such multi­modal features, mode changes or events that e.ect all players should cause high volume auditive feedback. System feed­back to local changes or touch interaction should be visual. In conclusion, group awareness and individual attention can both be treated as limited player resources that in.uence each other. This impact can be controlled through visual and auditive game design that manages spatial con.icts. In this regard, the prediction of touch occurrence can be used to balance gameplay. 3.4 Ad-hoc Boundaries and Outcome The main boundaries to enter a game in ad-hoc gameplay are related to the social context of public play. As described before, people just stumble upon such a multi-touch game in a public area and hesitate to join ad-hoc play. Besides actively inviting them to join the game, virtual characters who demonstrate gameplay can help to cross the boundaries. This can also be achieved through creating promising out­comes. Designing outcomes in collaborative ad-hoc game­play is a.ected by these social issues. Hence, players may want to enter or leave the game at any stage. One solution is to have .xed rounds of short durations, where people play in teams until a certain outcome is reached or the time is over. Other players wait in a cue to join the game. One advantage is that the team outcome can be eas­ily measured in a score, hence teams are motivated to beat previous scores. However, continuous play is not possible. Measuring a score for a single player in continuous play is di.cult, when there are no user identi.cations associated to the touch events. One solution is to create a base for each player or team to collect points. Succeeding in game activi­ties then creates score objects or points that can be moved to the base. When joining or exiting the game, a player can register or turn in a base through a gesture or through ex­ternal triggers. Besides maximum points, shortest time to collect a certain amount of bonus items can be measured. Another way to allow for continuous gameplay is to create intrinsic outcomes. Through play, the users create events or magic moments of surprise or fun, that induce emotions. These magic moments must pass by, so that players want to create them again, or that other players strive to experience the same. One solution is to have the game continuously threaten or destroy a certain status of the scenario and let the players clean up the mess. Other intrinsic sub-outcomes are to discover emotional states or hidden features of game objects, which may also trigger magic moments. Of course, motivation may recede when all magic moments have been experienced. In summary, ad-hoc multi-touch games should o.er out­comes that allow for easy management or seamless integra­tion of by-passers into the course of the game, i.e. through short periods of group play, player base-objects to collect score, or through intrinsic motivation in magic moments. 3.5 Multi-touch game creation Creating ideas for new game concepts can be achieved through di.erent techniques, such as brainstorming, paper prototyping, or by playing game creation games [14]. Re­garding the special properties of large multi-touch tables, previous work primarily concerns creating non-game collab­orative applications: One approach is to speci.cally look at possible interactions the target group (e.g. children) is ca­pable of [1]. Another is to look at the exact a.ordances and the context of the table to create a tabletop design with the right software interface, physical form and connectedness to other devices [23]. Instead of thinking of the interactions in the .rst place, we propose to start creating the game mechanics based on the previously proposed adjustments of formal game design elements. That means creating game mechanics based on touch patterns, contextual objectives, rules and procedures, spatial con.ict and attention resources, and ad-hoc overcom­ing boundaries through inviting outcomes. Table 1 gives a summary of these design factors and the possible options. We propose to apply all kinds of creative techniques avail­able and feasible in the respective process while keeping these aspects in mind. 4. CASE STUDY: MAGIC GARDEN Based on our analysis, we conducted a student project to create a multi-touch game for a large tabletop display allow­ing for ad-hoc play in public places. As apparatus, we used a capacitive multi-touch table by Art+Com (www.artcom.de) of 2.0 x 1.0 meters in combination with front-projection. The Figure 1: The Magic Garden with (a) .ower-beds, (b) clouds, (c) a well with a water gun, (d) seeds on the grass, and (e) a lake with with a frog and (f) a plug. A little dwarf (g) fell asleep in the center. sensor was connected to a Windows-PC. Data was trans­ferred to the game using OSC (opensoundcontrol.org) and the Bespoke OSC library 1.3 (www.bespokesoftware.org). The game prototype was written using the Microsoft XNA Game Studio 3.1. Besides some technical constraints given by the applied technology we set the requirement to allow continuous play in public places, especially for kids. Other than that, we had no creative limitations such as forcing educational use or a certain theme. 4.1 Concept Creation We conducted regular design sessions starting with a brain storming session, inducing some impressions by presenting multi-touch interaction videos. The students were asked to each create an individual concept on their own and after a pitch to the whole group let them vote for their favorite ones. The top concepts included hunting insects who crawl all over the table, digging the table for magic treasures, using di.erent properties of animals to get beyond obstacles, and cleaning up a nature scene of litter. We then faced the problem that each concept on its own was either too simple to stand for its own or way too com­plex to adapt easily in an ad-hoc situation. As a result, we created a common theme, a garden, that would include the existing mini-game concepts such as digging, hunting insects and taking care of the nature. The most intriguing concept from the start was hunting insects. Imagining the table full of crawling creatures and trying to stop them seemed promising, but required .nding a good reason to stop them (other than being an ugly insect). As bugs and vermin in general are known to threaten plants, we chose to let them attack plants in a garden scenario. As we needed plants, we changed the digging task to focus on digging holes to plant a seed instead of the treasure hunt. Growing from a seed to a plant requires a lot of sun and water. So the students came up with a watering game of combining clouds of di.erent humidity levels to rain clouds. Another idea featured watering through a water hose, taken from previous concepts. In the end, we combined these three mini-games, i.e. dig­ging holes and planting seeds, watering the seeds to grow plants and .owers, and hunting insects that threaten the plants. We .nally added some objectives and rewards and a background story. Thus, regarding the game design we gave up the initial approach to create a single complex game with an elaborate (a) Dig three times to create (b) Move a seed into the a hole. hole. (c) Digthreetimestoclosethehole. Figure 2: Growing plants can be achieved by dig­ging holes and placing seeds into them. gameplay and a supporting narrative as this collides with the ad-hoc approach aiming at an easy entry in the game. This turned out to be a decision bene.cial to the goals of ad-hoc public gameplay. The mini-games support an overall theme, the magic garden, but actually manage to o.er dif­ferent levels of complexity concerning the objectives, rules and procedures. Referring to the three stages of public play proposed in section 3.2, we tried to achieve an increasing involvement of the players turning them from spectators to multi-players. Each mini-game has its own objective, pro­cedures, and rules, but the boundaries, some resources and con.icts are interconnected. They all fall under the thematic umbrella of the magic garden with the common objective to take care of it. Nice animations and sounds o.er magic mo­ments for intrinsic motivation to invite to continuous play. For playing, our students created a set of interaction tech­niques inspired by the di.erent touch patterns. These and the resulting game are described in the following section. 4.2 The Final Game Alittle dwarf is responsible to take care of the Magic Gar­den, but today he is so tired that he falls asleep and the beautiful garden is left alone to the vermin: Bugs and cater­pillars crawl towards the .owerbeds attacking the plants. This background story is simply told by displaying a dwarf in the center of the garden laying down asleep with an open bag at his side. The garden consists of two .ower-beds, a well with a water cannon, a lake with a frog and a plug (see Figure 1 for an overview). Clouds .oat above the garden. Tiny insects crawl across the grass. The players task is to take care of the garden, thus to .ght o. the insects, to grow plants and help making the .owerbeds beautiful and colorful as they should be in a Magic Garden. Luckily the dwarf also dropped his back­pack and spilled some fresh seeds across the grass. So the players can start digging holes in order to plant seeds to repair damage caused by the insects (Figure 2). To grow plants and .owers requires watering. For this purpose, clouds .oat above the garden. They show di.er­ent levels of humidity (from one to four points) and can be moved around by touching them. Combining two clouds to a .ve-point rain cloud and using a gesture on that cloud (a) Combine two clouds to (b) Squeeze the rain cloud sums of .ve points to create to let it rain. rain clouds. (c) Let it rain above plants. (d) Successful watering cre­ates lovely .owers. Figure 3: Using cloud computing to create rain. Figure 4: The watering gun. invokes rain. Miscalculation causes a thunderstorm that de­stroys the clouds without rain (Figure 3). The rain can be used to water the seeds, a well, or a lake. The well features a water gun that can be used to water plants and to shoot o. insects (Figure 4). The lake is owned by a beautiful mermaid. When the lake is full, the mermaid gives water to all plants, shown through a magical animation sequence (Figure 5). Another reward is achieved by watering .owers, as full­grown .owers are animated and make the garden beautiful. Other seeds grow as carrots. These carrots can be used to attract a rabbit who takes the carrot in exchange for new seeds. These seeds can be used to plant even more .owers and seeds (Figure 6). Meanwhile bugs and caterpillars crawl towards the plants to eat them. Blue bugs can be killed by squashing them through simple touches. As for the caterpillar, rubbing over it transfers it into a magical butter.y that does no harm any­more. Red bugs have to be pushed away through a swiping gesture or by shooting at them with the water gun. If they get nearby the lake, a frog catches the red bugs with his tongue (Figure 7).
