fulltext.ft_body: Digital distribution of games: The players perspective Saara Toivonen Olli Sotamaa Department of Information Studies Department of Information Studies and Interactive Media and Interactive Media University of Tampere University of Tampere saara.e.toivonen@uta.fi olli.sotamaa@uta.fi ABSTRACT The online distribution of games has in the past few years become increasingly commonplace. Currently the brick and mortar retailers and physical copies still hold a dominant position in the overall market but online market including online distribution of full game titles, subscription-based models, downloadable content, virtual commodities and related value­added services is quickly developing. Still we know very little of the player attitudes towards digital distribution of games. Therefore the study at hand focuses on examining the players experiences and notions concerning online distribution. Based on the findings the following factors have a significant influence on how players consider digital distribution: amount of time used on game playing, the social activities related to games, familiarity with other forms of downloadable content. A notable majority of those who had downloaded games highlighted the importance of the following issues: wide variety of games available, ease of finding downloadable games, affordability and simple payment methods. At the same time, more than half of these people announced that they still preferred to have their games as physical copies. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.8.0 [Personal Computing]: General Games General Terms Human Factors, Design Keywords Digital games, Game studies, Players, Digital distribution 1. INTRODUCTION The past few years have witnessed significant increase in online distribution of games. PC games have traditionally been in a pioneering position but the current generation of consoles provides a solid basis for digital distribution as well. As the development costs are spiraling and the risks associated with Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 producing AAA games are increasing, many game developers have directed their creative investments to downloadable games. It is clear that publishers, distributors and retailers need to react to the emerging trend. At the same time we know very little of how players see the ongoing change. The study at hand focuses on examining the players experiences and notions concerning online distribution of games. We find this extremely important as downloading games is currently becoming an everyday practice for an increasing number of players. The data analyzed in this article comes from a survey conducted among Finnish gamers. While the results should not be generalized to larger player populations, they can surely highlight some of the key development trends in the area. The article starts with an overview of the digital distribution of games. Both the recent academic research and marketing studies provided by the industry are used to outline the current phase of the development. After the overview we introduce the practical implementation of the study including the survey method, the sample and the characteristics of the collected data. The analysis of the data is divided to three subchapters. Firstly we examine the variables that defined how actively the respondents downloaded games and other games-related material. We also compare the popularity of game downloading with more traditional forms of distribution. Secondly we contemplate the differences between PC and console downloadables and specify some platform dependent questions. Thirdly we briefly consider the appeal of physical game copies. This discussion is partly based on a further qualitative survey. After this we move on to discuss the potential design implications of our study. Finally the relevance of the central findings is evaluated by contextualizing them to the recent discussions concerning the digital distribution of games. 2. ONLINE DISTRIBUTION OF GAMES When compared to traditional media industries, like music or cinema, digital games appear perfectly suitable for online distribution. Similar to any piece of software, digital games exist from the beginning in digital form and therefore no conversion is needed [4]. In addition, the core audience of digital games has traditionally been relatively computer-savvy. While the game industry has experimented with online distribution technologies at least from the early 1980 s1, the digital delivery models have, 1 For example, CVC GameLine allowed players to download games for the Atari 2600 via a telephone line. PlayCable enabled cable operators to send games for Intellivision Master Components owners over the wire with the TV signal. until recently, had a relatively marginal economical significance. In most cases the game product is still printed to a carrier media, an optical disc or a cartridge. The copies are then packed with instructions in a box and sold by specialty stores, department stores and online retailers. During the past decade, with the advent of broadband internet connections and networked game consoles and the emergence of both massively multiplayer online worlds and casual games, various forms of gaming are increasingly dependent of online components. At the same time the scale of online distribution of games and games-related content has significantly expanded. Games played on personal computers have had a pioneering position in introducing new distribution schemes. Most of the PCs have for years been connected to the Internet and thus enabled both forms of networked play and access to games­related online communities. Furthermore, PC games are traditionally based on common standards, open architectures and non-proprietary technologies and therefore they are open to updates [7]. Thus, PC game players are accustomed to downloading both developer-provided patches and player-made modifications. The console game market has until recently been much more closed in nature. As O Donnell carefully explains, ever since the launch of the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) in the mid 1980 s the console manufacturers have used specific technologies to exert control over the market [11]. In the recent years, the introduction of network connections, hard disks and proprietary services has significantly changed the console gaming scene. While for example the market analyst company Screen Digest forecasts that it will take until the next generation of consoles that the online market can be commercially exploited to its full potential they at the same time admit that the number of active online game consoles is constantly increasing and the players are expected to become increasingly active in downloading games and other games-related content [12]. The brick and mortar retail model is not only challenged by the online distribution of full game downloads. The revenues are increasingly generated also through service subscriptions, game expansion and other downloadable add-ons, micro-transactions and advertising-based strategies. According to the recent marketing study already twenty percent of the money U.S. players spend on digital games goes toward MMOs and game portals, primarily for monthly subscriptions and online credits [1]. In the European countries the share is a little smaller (between 10 and 18 percent) but still relatively significant. The move away from package-good industry necessarily puts more emphasis on providing the players with additional services [4, 2]. These days digital games are often both based on and provide a basis for various kinds of services [14]. We will come back to the central online distribution platforms a little later. In the following we will move on to discuss the details of our study. 3. IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STUDY The survey had a twofold focus. First of all we wanted to collect and examine the existing experiences our respondents had about the different forms of downloadable content. Secondly the aim of study was to map players overall notions and opinions concerning online distribution of games. The questionnaire was divided into a few thematic parts. First of all we had a few general questions concerning one s playing habits, use of digital games and digital content downloads, including music, films, computer programs and games. After this we had more detailed questions about PC games and an almost identical set of questions concerning console games. Finally we had a few questions about browser games. The questions covered for example the following issues: the time and money spent on playing, gaming habits, experiences and opinions concerning downloading games. The online questionnaire consisted of 37 questions, many of which had several parts. The questionnaire was marketed in a few Finnish websites. The selection included a range of different sites: Pelit.fi is the online extension of the biggest game magazine in Finland, Tilt.tv is the website related to the weekly video game television programme and Digitoday.fi is a popular ICT business news site. Respondents of bit different kind were recruited from through the websites of Yhteishyvä and ET magazines. Yhteishyvä is a customer magazine of a large everyday market chain and ET is a lifestyle magazine for seniors and people at late middle age. The 1184 respondents broke up so that around one half of them (53%) were reached via the Pelit.fi site, while other channels provided the rest of the sample. To contextualize the sample, a few words need to be said about the Finnish context. First of all, personal computers are widely used in Finnish households and work places. According to the most recent surveys over 80% of the Finnish households have a PC [17]. Furthermore, 57% of the employees use a computer as part of their work [6]. Therefore it is rather unsurprising that almost sixty percent out of 10 -75-year-old Finns play PC games at least once in a while [5]. While playing digital games is most common among young men and boys, even in the age group between 70 75 years, 17% of people report to play PC games at least sometimes. Console gaming is quite popular as well: one third of the 10 - 75-year-olds play console games at least from time to time [5]. In our sample no fewer than 92% of respondents played PC games (including browser games) at least once a month. Console games were played monthly by 60%. In this respect, it is fair to say that the sample of our survey is obviously biased. While Finns can be seen as relatively active gaming nation in general, it is clear that most of the respondents of our survey exceed the national average time spent on playing digital games (Figure 1). Thus, it is useful to remember that the players consulted in this study are mostly early adopters. With certain exceptions they are white males with unrestricted access to gaming technologies and the required skills to master them. In this respect, it is probably wise to assume that as digital distribution of games becomes more common, the practices will not remain entirely the same (for similar concerns, see [3]). However, at the present, these pioneers and early adopters constitute the best chance we have to examine the player opinions concerning downloadable games and other new distribution models. Altogether, the results presented in the following provide an understanding of how avid Finnish gamers see the different aspects of digital distribution. While these results can surely highlight some of the future directions in the area, they should not as such be generalized to larger player populations. Figure 1: Time spent on playing digital games per week 4. WHO DOWNLOADS AND WHAT? The participants of the survey were in average quite familiar with downloading games. When asked if they had downloaded games during the past six months, 80% of the respondents answered in the affirmative. An alternative way to measure the prevalence of online distribution based on our data is to count together the answers from both the PC and console sections. This approach reveals that no less than 93% of respondents had at least once downloaded games of some kind (from full retail games to freeware games). Furthermore, 66% of the respondents had paid money for game downloads. The majority of participants, however, used less than 10 euros a month for game downloads. The first central observation that can be made based on the data is that the more the respondents play the more they download games. While around one half of those who played games under one hour per week had downloaded games during the past half a year, among the respondents who played over five hours the corresponding figure was over 80% (Figure 2). The correlation exists both in case of PC and console games. It is, however, more clear in relation to PC gaming. Our data further shows that there is a connection between playing times and willingness to pay for game downloads. Those who play more than 10 hours a week prefer to buy their games as downloads more often than others. In addition, the amount of time spent on playing also had a noticeable linkage to the sum of money used. The survey also explored how active the respondents were in game cultural activities other than mere playing. The survey included four claims exploring these activities. The claims were presented as five-point Likert items (choices ranging from Completely agree to Do not agree ) and read as follows: I usually talk about games with others , I actively follow online game forums , I actively take part in conversations on online game forums and I m a member of a game community . These were used to build a sum variable that was compared with other variables. As a result we can say that the more active the respondents were in these activities, the more likely they had downloaded games. When only 22% of the least active respondents had downloaded games in the last half a year, in the most active group the corresponding number was 89%. Figure 2: Correlation between the weekly playtime and the familiarity of digital distribution Figure 3: The first choice option for buying digital games The readiness to accept game downloads has a linkage to other related activities. Those who had downloaded music, films or computer programs, had more likely downloaded games as well. While this may not be a very surprising result the interconnection seems to be rather strong when we examine the downloading habits from the past six months. Out of those who had not downloaded any other forms of digital content, one third reported that they had downloaded games whereas over 80% of the respondents who had downloaded other content had downloaded games as well. Another related finding is that those respondents who had downloaded some other content than games be it free or chargeable had more likely paid for the game downloads. These days digital games compete of the attention of consumer with many other commodities. Therefore, the buying habits of the respondents were also explored. Interestingly enough, the income level had no correlation with the amount of money used to downloading games. Furthermore, when asked whether the low prize of downloadable games was an important factor, the income had no significant influence on the answers. We also asked if the respondents had used peer-to-peer file sharing services. These services, based on BitTorrent protocol, have spawned some controversy as they provide links to a variety of digital content, including copyrighted material. The media conglomerates are often heard to claim these services for the declining sales figures. Interestingly, our data shows that those who had downloaded any content from BitTorrent services had more often paid for their game downloads. They also used more money for downloading games than the others. As we were interested in knowing how online distribution platforms rank among the more traditional forms of retail, the respondents were asked to choose their preferred way of buying games (Figure 3). The respondents mostly preferred online stores and specialty game stores. However, 16% of the respondents reported that they rather download games than use any method including physical copies. Interestingly, this group of players is already bigger than those who prefer to buy games from a department store. In addition, there were noteworthy differences between those who had downloaded games and those who had not. 60% of those who had not downloaded games did not buy games at all. Among those, who did buy games but not by download, the most popular forum to buy games was the department store. 5. DISTRIBUTION PLATFORMS The platforms examined in this study included PC and the latest game consoles (Microsoft Xbox360, Sony Playstation 3, Nintendo Wii), but excluded for example mobile platforms. The focus was consciously on sectors in which the traditional retail model has dominated for long. The two markets PC and console are also easily comparable as the selection of games available is partially identical. However, while a slew of multi­platform games are available for download both on PC and on one or more consoles the distribution platforms vary significantly. As it has been recently argued computer and console games differ in use and in the cultures they create because of differences in game-play, game usage, and game type [16]. The differences are not, however, limited to playing itself but the very environments in which the games-related services, downloading services included, are used vary. First of all, while almost all PC:s are connected to the Internet, this is not the case with game consoles.2 Online play and distribution has been prevalent on PC for several years, whereas the only the latest generations of console systems has provided a solid basis for online gaming. This difference is visible in our study as well. Out of those who 2 Microsoft claims that the active user base of Xbox Live online gaming service is over 20 million [14]. In Tokyo Game Show 2009, Sony announced that there are some 29 million PSN accounts. It is, however, clear that many gamers have more than one account as the number of PS3 consoles sold just exceeds 27 million at the time of writing (vgchartz.com). play PC games on a weekly basis, almost three-fourths play online whereas in case of console game players the corresponding number is 45%. We will in the following take a more detailed look at the downloading habits of both PC and console gamers. Out of those who had at least one of the current game consoles in their household 72% had downloaded games (full retail games or smaller games) and 88% had downloaded some content (including game demos, expansion packs, levels, characters and trailers) to their console. In case of PC gaming, 87% of the respondents had downloaded games and 93% had downloaded at least some form of game-related content. One noticeable finding echoing the prevalence of online distribution on PCs was that not less than 88% of the PC gamers had downloaded updates and patches to their games. The console game sector is clearly moving to this direction as well as the players are already routinely asked to download updates not only to the individual games but also to the operating system. Despite the differences in the platforms the PC gamers and console gamers were surprisingly unanimous when asked about the matters they found important in relation to downloading games. Both in case of PC games and console games, over 75% of those who had downloaded games found the following claims important: finding games is effortless, a wide variety is available, the game is affordable, paying the purchase is simple. The theme of the game seemed to be relatively unimportant as only under 25% of the same groups found a familiar theme or an experimental approach important. Possibly the most significant difference between platforms is that while almost three fourths of the console owners found the easy access to game demos important, among PC downloaders the corresponding figure was under 60%. In this connection one has to remember that Nintendo Wii does not support game demos and therefore the Wii owners (out of whom only 45% found game demos important) actually diminish the difference. Therefore, the margin between PC gamers and Xbox360 or PS3 players is even clearer. Furthermore, when compared to owners of other consoles, Nintendo Wii owners less often agreed that downloadable games were easily accessible and that the downloading was easy. The same difference between Nintendo Wii and the other consoles can be found from the recent UK marketing study [18]. While our data offers no straightforward explanation to this finding, it is relatively safe to say that the shortcomings of the Wii online service can be named as the major reason for the difference. Other statistically significant differences between the consoles were very hard to find. This is partially related to the fact that a little over one fourth of console owners had access to more than one console. The proportion does not significantly differ from the numbers presented by a recent study on the North American console owners [10]. In the case of game consoles the distribution of games is integrated to the very user interface of the console and the online marketplaces are easily accessible and difficult to miss. For PC gamers the scene is much more fragmented: one can found dozens of different online services that provide downloadable games. Tellingly, 17% of the respondents said that they do not regularly download PC games because they are not familiar with these services. Out of the existing online distribution platforms Valve s Steam was recognized far more often than any other services. Not less than 92% reported to be aware of Steam and 59% had also used the service. Correspondingly, 39% of the respondents recognized Direct2drive and 27% were familiar with Gametap. The casual game sites included in the survey were rated around the same as 38% of the players recognized PopCap Games and 26% of them knew Big Fish Games. When compared to the other platforms Steam is in its own class, as all the other sites were used by less than 10% of the PC gamers. 6. THE APPEAL OF PHYSICAL COPIES When asked about the reasons why they had not used the online distribution platforms, one fifth of the respondents stated that they do not like downloading games. Practical issues like limited internet connections can partially explain the answers but in any case it is notable that so many players were ready to make such a strong statement. Even more strikingly, a little over one half of the respondents who had at some point downloaded games still found it important to own their games as physical copies. This finding is somewhat surprising, especially as we are talking about players who rank above average in playing time and awareness of the available services. Our data provides some preliminary explanations for the wide appeal of physical copies. First of all, physical copies allow relatively easy returns and refunds. This, however, seems not to be the case with digital copies as only ten percent of the respondents found returning easy. Secondly, the second hand market of digital copies is practically non-existent. Contrary to the physical copies, in the downloadables market there is no easy way to sell further the games you do not play any more. One third of the respondents mentioned this as a reason that affects their willingness to download games. Furthermore, every single participant who preferred to buy games from other players had at least once downloaded games, so ignorance is not to blame here. Finally, around one half of the respondents (55% of the console owners and 41% of the PC players) were afraid that the downloaded copies may vanish in case of system malfunction. As mentioned earlier, digital games would for many reasons appear perfectly suitable for online distribution: they are software after all and consumed by a relatively computer-savvy audience. In addition, the recent studies show that it is increasingly commonplace for consumers in general to invest money on virtual goods and items [8]. At the same time, based on our data large player populations still seem to be strongly attached to physical copies. These mutually conflicting development trends indicate that the issue deserves more scholarly attention. While the practical issues discussed above are surely related to the remaining popularity of physical copies in the digital games market, alternative explanations can be found as well. To gain more information on the subject, we implemented a complementary survey. Altogether 33 respondents of the original survey were recruited for this qualitative study consisting of 11 open questions. All the respondents had downloaded games but still for a reason or another preferred physical copies. The participants were asked to elaborate the differences between physical copies and downloads and the daily practices related to them. The early results from this further study indicate some intriguing findings. The data supports our hypothesis of the importance of such practical issues as refunds, reselling and loaning but there are other interesting issues as well. Related to the physical copies, a majority of the respondents expressed that they appreciate the opportunity to look and touch the game cartridges and booklets. This gives them a concrete feeling of ownership, different from the one connected to digital copies. Many of the informants also emphasize the reliability and safety of physical copies. This is a somewhat intriguing find as one would assume that the avid players are aware of the limited life span of the game discs and the widespread opportunity to re­download the lost digital copies. In this respect, the feeling of reliability cannot be entirely reduced to technical aspects. This leads us to consider the often mentions aspects of collecting and identity building. The centrality of collecting in the answers is somewhat surprising. While collection building can surely direct the behaviour of gamers, digital items seldom gain a status of a rarity [13]. Most of our informants denied to be game collectors as such. At the same time they still often listed quite a catalogue of memorable game cartridges, had a separate place for them or actively showcased some of the games to other people. In many ways gathering and controlling meaningful objects can work to gain one an improved sense of self. As games are intimately tied to the personal histories of players, the physical copy becomes a sort of symbolic guarantee that they can even after years return to the significant experiences. Based on our data, same kind of attachment was rarely associated with downloadable games or other digital content. We suggest that a deeper understanding of player s experiences and their behaviour in and outside the virtual playgrounds can have an important contribution to the design of the distribution platforms. As discussed earlier, the role of related value-added services is accentuated once the distribution moves to the web. In the following we discuss some of the implications our findings can have for the development of distribution services. 7. POTENTIAL DESIGN IMPLICATIONS As we have discussed, the global game industry has recently introduced a variety of online distribution platforms, subscription based business models, and other innovations that make games, more or less, available as services . Similar to other knowledge­intensive industries, games business is transforming from selling fixed items with set features and a one-time sales value to providing platforms with virtual commodities, upgrades and value-added services. Online distribution of games turns the focus away from the carriage media and accentuates the significance of additional services that build a mutually beneficial and long-lasting relationship between the platform holder, developer and the player. Established platforms like Valve s Steam and the current generation consoles have already showed that online distribution is not only about providing access to games but serving the players in a very comprehensive manner. Our earlier contribution to the subject [14] divides player services into five major categories. These categories are as follows: maintenance of environment, support of initiation, facilitation of playing, assistance of play, and socialization of player. While various existing services can be identified in all of these categories many potential areas still remain uncommercialized. Most of the services associated with current games (see five-part model above) are in use during the game session but the services provided before, after and between game sessions may be at least as important for the long-term success of the game. Based on the findings we suggest four potential application areas: 1) Virtual game collections. Our survey results indicate that surprisingly many active players still hang on to physical game copies. According to the informants only the physical copy can produce the feeling of really owning something: they can be touched and showed to others. Furthermore, reselling and loaning is relatively simple. First of all, as long as the secondary markets for downloadable games are next to non-existing, there are good reasons to stick with the cartridges. Furthermore, many players highlight how the traditional physical game collection allows them to return to the significant game experiences by only looking at the cartridges. They are also easily demonstrated to friends or anyone interested in knowing what kinds of games one prefers. So far the design of online distribution platforms has rarely taken these kinds of aspects into account. 2) Player identity management services. Many players spend a lot of time and effort in customizing their player characters, properties and other aspects of the gaming experience. While for players it would be natural to transport the results of their investments (ranging from user names to valuable virtual items) between the game worlds and services this is seldom possible. Currently players can access a variety of games with one authentication only within a particular distribution service. A general standard smilar to OpenID would open a variety of new possibilities. 3) Recommendation systems and social navigation. Most online distribution platforms ranging from Xbox Live to iPhone App Store have problems in introducing the games selection in a clear and user-friendly way. This is somewhat surprising as at the same time platform holders and developers have more detailed information about the player behavior than ever before. There seems to be no particularly good reasons why recommendations based on the personal player statistics (already extensively collected by services like xFire) and other players choices (social navigation) could not be provided. 4) Eco-gamer services. One aspect of digital distribution that still mostly remains underresearched are the ecological aspects of virtual consumption. In a general level one can argue that a more sustainable overall development can be supported by replacing physical products with virtual ones. Downloadable games do not consume natural resources in the same way as those based on carriage media. Increasing the awareness of players by developing services like player carbon footprint meter may have a significant influence on the consumer choices. Recently it has been suggested that the effects of digital distribution may not be limited to eliminating the need to physically transport commodities but the new platforms can also support consumer practices that further reduce e-waste [9]. 5) The new forms of tangible. As discussed, one of the reasons why many players still prefer physical copies is the look and feel factor. It is, however, clear that there are alternative ways to provide the tangible experience. Oftentimes the virtual currencies ranging from Xbox Live points to Habbo Hotel credits are delivered with a physical voucher. While these cards normally include just a unique code entered to the system, in some cases the cards themselves can became collectibles and in this sense take the role of the physical cartridge or disc. Similar to music and movies, the game industry has for long provided exclusive collector s editions alongside the standard versions. The special editions facilitate the enthusiasts with tons of detailed background information and special items. For example the World of Warcraft Burning Crusade Collector s Edition includes not only the game but also a behind-the-scenes DVD, soundtrack CD, hardcover art book, set of WoW trading cards and an exclusive mouse pad. It is easy to predict that the demand for the extensive special editions will remain even in the era of ubiquitous digital distribution. One can also predict an increasing exchange between the digital and the tangible levels of gaming. It is not a surprise that The Burning Crusade special edition also includes an exclusive in-game pet. This pet or any other WoW character can be further printed as a 3D miniature an exclusive service provided by the 3rd party company FigurePrints (www.figureprints.com). Altogether, these observations are very preliminary. The application areas mentioned here are most probably not the only ones that need more attention in the future. The findings are, however, empirically grounded and therefore represent the concerns of players in the current situation. 8. CONCLUSION The current forecasts concerning the progress of digital distribution greatly vary. Console manufacturers and distribution platform developers predict a relatively quick end to the traditional forms of distribution. On the other hand, influential retailers have until now mostly shrugged aside online distribution as a marginal market. To forecast the rate of change is not the objective of this article as such. Instead, our findings can help better understand the various aspects that affect the attitudes towards the new distribution paradigm. In conclusion, according to our data, the income level of the gamers seems to have no effect to the downloading behaviour. Instead, such factors as the amount of time used on game playing, the social activities related to games, and familiarity with other forms of downloadable content have a visible influence on the attitudes towards digital distribution. A notable majority of those, who had downloaded games, highlighted the importance of the following issues: wide variety of available games, ease of finding downloadable games, affordability and simple paying methods. At the same time, more than half of these people announced that they still preferred to have their games as physical copies. In many occasions the relation between physical and digital copies is obviously not that of opposition or even alternative. Many popular games build on a hybrid model in which the starter pack is sold as a physical copy but downloading updates or the playing itself requires the players to connect to the official game servers. While models of this kind provide a new role for the physical copy, it seems that the attitudes do not change overnight. Altogether, it seems clear that the wildest game industry manifestos celebrating the death of physical game copies must be taken with a pinch of salt. Resistance of change would, however, be a far too simple explanation. First of all, as long as the rights to refunds, resells and loaning are constricted the allure of digital copies will remain limited. Secondly, no fundamental changes are in the horizon as long as the distribution services fail to take into account the everyday practices of large player populations. Once the art of service design reaches the level required from successful game design we may see more dramatic changes. 9. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS We wish to thank our colleagues Kai Kuikkaniemi and Pekka Räsänen from the Helsinki Institute for Information Technology (HIIT). Their contribution was vital in designing the survey and collecting the data. In addition, we are grateful to Tekes, The Finnish Funding Agency for Technology and Innovation, for funding the Games as Services project during which the study was conducted. 10. fulltext.ft_body: Aristotle Would Have Admired BioShock While Shakespeare Would Have Played Dragon Age David Owen, MA, MFA York University, Initiating PhD Candidacy 9108 80 Avenue Edmonton, AB T6C 0T8 1-403-975-1430 davidowen999@gmail.com ABSTRACT In this paper, I use two current successful video games to illustrate advances in narrative in game design and compare their style to that of two theatrical models from the past. Categories and Subject Descriptors J.5 [Arts and Humanities]: The use of narrative to invoke empathy and immersion. General Terms Performance, Design, Experimentation, Theory Keywords Aristotle, Poetics, Shakespeare, Performance Studies, Video Game Design, Theatre, Immersion, Narrative, Empathy, Catharsis, BioShock, Dragon Age Recent video games provide more elaborate worlds than previous games and, often, more coherent worlds. In combination with the improvements in computer graphics and storage, this results in an increased emphasis on game fiction. [1] I agree with Eric Zimmerman that games are narratives and that the debate over whether they do or can tell stories is moot [2]. The attempt to separate games, especially progression games, from theatrical, cinematic and literary influences seems misguided. As a theatre practitioner, scholar and avid gamer I have marked a tremendous leap forward during the last half decade in the quality and integrity of video game writing as well as its use within games as an integral ingredient in creating immersion, empathy and catharsis. I have noted that as game writing advances and the importance of narrative sets the great games apart from the rest in popularity, emotional involvement and immersion, there are more effective parallels to the great narrative models of the past. However, I am surprised by what I perceive as a need to downplay the power of narrative found in early critical writing on video games that still permeates the field today. There are some excellent and well-tested approaches to performance and story-telling found in theatrical tradition that can both inform and inspire further exploration in the relatively new medium of video games. Why reinvent (or deny the Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. ACM FuturePlay 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, BC. Canada Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7 ...$10.00 usefulness of) the wheel? I will to demonstrate how Aristotle would have admired 2K Games award winning BioShock franchise (2007, 2010) in the same way he admired Sophocles award winning Oedipus Tyrannus. The techniques of reversal of fortune for the protagonist, late point of narrative attack and intensification are all described by Aristotle as essential to creating good theatrical art and are all found in the BioShock games. The three unities of time, place and action, as defined by the neo-classicists based on Aristotle s work, serve the player s experience within Rapture well. In addition and as a contrast I will also demonstrate how effective the non-Aristotelian narrative approach of complex interweaving plots and episodic structure found in Bioware s Dragon Age (2009) has definite parallels to the narrative strategies used by the most produced and arguably most popular playwright today, Shakespeare. I will make comparisons between the Shakespearean approach to storytelling exemplified by some of his iconic plays and characters and choices made by the writers and designers of Dragon Age. These are two examples of many from theatre s rich critical past that are finding new theoretical purchase in this fledgling field of video-game studies. Aristotle wrote The Poetics in the fourth century BCE after watching many plays at the annual play competition during the City Dionysia celebrations. In it he described his six elements of theatre: plot, character, thought, diction, song and spectacle, and how he thought Sophocles Oedipus Tyrannus was the best example of those elements in perfect balance. He talked about the most effective variation of reversal of fortune and how the ultimate purpose of theatre was to provide the audience with a cathartic experience. In the 16th century CE, Lodovico Castelvetro translated Aristotle s Poetics with his own neo-classical interpretations [3] and the three unities of time, place and action were born. This served playwrights like Racine well. In the 19th century, Eugene Scribe went further with the unities, startling reversals and suspense and created what he called, The Well-Made-Play [3]. This formula served playwrights like Henrik Ibsen well. Here in 2010, I will go one step further and say BioShock is a Well-Made-Game. The unity of time dictates the events within the play take place in a 24 hour period. In BioShock the time within the game is roughly the same as the time it takes to play the game with the exception of waking up in Tenenbaum s nursery. How long the character is asleep is unknown but not indicated as significant. The unity of place dictates everything happen in one location. For Aristotle and the French Neo-Classicists that meant strictly one room. BioShock takes place in a confined space an underwater city but definitely in several areas within the city. However, it makes sense to me that the designers for BioShock, located in Boston and Australia - both prior British colonies - would be influenced by British theatrical tradition. According to Wainscott and Fletcher, For the British, unity of place was defined not as a single location, as the French and Italians defined it, but as any set of locations that could be reached within a twenty-four-hour period [4]. With this provision and especially in the context that this is a game, I argue that the unity of place is upheld in spirit within the city of Rapture. Lastly, the unity of action, where every event is directly connected to the super-objective of the protagonist, is clearly demonstrated within BioShock. There are no side-quests or subplots simply to gain experience or wealth. Everything that happens to the player-character Jack is directly connected to his quest to learn his true identity and ultimately gain his freedom or so he, and the player, thinks. The fact that Jack and the player unfolding the narrative through Jack are duped into doing Atlas (aka Fontaine s) dirty work is ultimately part of the over-riding quest for identity and freedom. This game, like a Well-Made-Play is composed of several scenes (areas), each with a miniature climatic structure that reveals new information driving the plot forward. Several scenes together create an act. There are fifteen areas or scenes in BioShock and the game is divided roughly into three acts of five scenes each. Killing Andrew Ryan with the golf club is an example of an end of an act climax. Going forward into the next act, the player s perception of the game world is altered by the experience. Using the three unities BioShock has made excellent use of the intensification afforded by a late point of attack and condensing all the dramatic (and actual) action into the tightest package possible. The downfall of a late point of attack is the necessity for exposition to explain the significance of the situation and back story of the characters. The 2K designers were very clever in using the convention of voice recorders for the player to find that provide contextual information. Alternative methods are lengthy dialogues, flashbacks and cut-scenes that interfere with the action and have plagued many previous games (as well as plays and movies). Let us turn our attention to Aristotle s six elements and his thoughts on reversal of fortune and catharsis. I choose to return to Aristotle s original ideas instead of borrowing the neo-Aristotelian work of Michael Mateas and Brenda Laurel before him to make the point that emotional involvement by the player will ultimately lead to deeper immersion within the game experience. In Mateas article Preliminary Poetics for Interactive Drama and Games he not only changes the definitions of Aristotle s six elements but also alters their names to better suit their application to the specific game model he is exploring [5]. His highly engaging and insightful work tends to downplay the importance of game-story in favour of game­mechanics. A well-constructed plot should, therefore, be single in its issue, rather than double as some maintain. The change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad. It should come about as the result not of vice, but of some great error or frailty, in a character either such as we have described, or better rather than worse. [6] Plot, Aristotle s first and most important of his six elements, should be singular and consistent. Each episode (scene/act) should advance the plot and contain some form of recognition or reversal for the protagonist. As Aristotle states above, the most effective form of reversal of fortune is from good to bad due to an error or weakness in the protagonist, his or her tragic flaw. In BioShock the protagonist Jack endeavours to learn his true identity and escape the challenging environment of Rapture but is brought low several times to the point of being forced to kill Andrew Ryan with a golf club and later become a Big Daddy. In Sophocles play Oedipus is blind to the truth because he is too proud. His tragic flaw is hubris. In Bioshock Jack s tragic flaw (shared by the player) is his gullibility. Atlas/Fontaine deceives the player into thinking he is an ally. The game is monopolizing on the player s assumption that what a NPC says is true! Also, both Oedipus and Jack are setup by forces outside their control. For Oedipus, the fates are against him through the prophecy that he will murder his father and marry his mother. For Jack, the realization that a trigger word is planted in his brain forcing him to obey commands is one of the most significant points of recognition within the plot of BioShock. According to Aristotle characters should be consistent and reflect their station in life. It is true that Atlas and Fontaine are revealed to be the same person but that character is consistently the antagonist of the story. Thought is the third element and consists of a specific theme or idea being explored. Diction is fourth and means not only the character s choice of words but how the words reflect the character. This includes their use of inflection and accents. What the player knows of Atlas and later Fontaine is learned solely through those characters diction heard through the radio. The next element is song and means all patterned sound within the fictional world. Most plays, movies and games contain music and ambient sound throughout most of the experience. Aristotle s sixth and last element, the one he argues is least artistic, is spectacle. That is not to say Aristotle didn t appreciate spectacle in the plays he saw but criticized its use for its own sake and not in support of the other five elements. BioShock has many spectacle moments within the game and indeed, the city of Rapture is visually spectacular, but compared to gratuitous spectacle in other games and especially 3-D Hollywood films, I believe Aristotle would agree the spectacle in BioShock supports the game environment and narrative. When all six elements are in balance, a powerful cathartic release can be acheived. An important distinction must be made here. A videogame differs from a play or film in that the audience is not a passive observer. The protagonist serves a duel role in the sense that the narrative agency of the protagonist is propelled by the direct input of the player. The protagonist the player-character is both an avatar, an index for the player within the game environment, as well as the site of narrative continuity for the player as observer/audience to the unfolding fiction. The player receives enjoyment from executing actions within the game ( I did that!) while at the same time, enjoys the story as it unfolds on the screen (Did you see that?). The empathy felt by relating to a character in a fiction can be strengthened greatly by blurring the identity of the player with that character in a well constructed game like BioShock. BioShock was the first video game to make me cry. I am no softy who cries at just anything (except Pixar films, of course). The catharsis I felt at the conclusion of the game was real. It was not the completion of the boss battle at the end against Frank Fontaine but the unexpected emotional reward of the little girls (I saved) emerging, finishing off the monster and rescuing me. The montage of images that followed showed the little girls hands in my battered Big Daddy hand change as they grew, sport wedding bands and hold diplomas. The girls lived to see the Sun for the first time because of me. I was surprised by my own emotional investment in the fate of those girls. I had expected an obligatory boss fight followed by an equally obligatory denouement showing my return to the surface and normalcy but what I received left me with a deep emotional impression. The game ended with a different world than the one I started in, seemingly better from my efforts, and both my character and I changed from the experience. My catharsis from playing BioShock is in direct opposition with Janet Murray s statement that the story-rich new gaming formats [ ] are certainly more storylike than, say, checkers [but] not more storylike than chess or monopoly. She continues by saying, Games are always stories, even abstract games such as checkers or Tetris, which are about winning and losing, casting the player as the opponent-battling or environment battling hero. [7] I am uncomfortable with this notion that story is merely a fancy rapping around a set of game rules. I have trouble comparing the immersion created through a well constructed narrative in a game like BioShock to the sparse and secondary use of story in games like chess and monopoly. Perhaps Murray s idea is better applied to a game like Doom III (Id Software 2005) where the only difference in the protagonist between the start and finish of the game is the size of his gun. It was a first person shooter (FPS) based on the cinematic model of going into the basement alone horror trope. Playing BioShock immediately after Doom III the difference in narrative approach was substantial. The storytelling in BioShock created much more than just an abstract setting like the one found in monopoly. The belief that the game-story is a ubiquitous yet secondary aspect within games is further undermined by RPGs like Bioware s Mass Effect, Bethesda s Fallout III and more recently, Bioware s Dragon Age. There are many differences between Aristotle and Shakespeare. Not the least is the fact Aristotle was a critic and philosopher while Shakespeare was an actor, playwright and shareholder in the Globe Theatre, hence the title Aristotle Would Have Admired BioShock While Shakespeare Would Have Played Dragon Age. If Shakespeare were alive today I imagine him as an avid gamer and successful game designer. I am comforted in knowing that Dante s Inferno lead game creator Jonathan Knight stated in a recent Wall Street Journal interview that he also believes Shakespeare would also have made a great game designer [8]. Shakespeare s plays are produced now more than any other time in history and the episodic narrative structure of his plays is similar to most of today s role­playing games (RPGs). Shakespeare s plays do not adhere to the three unities of time, place and action. In Othello the play jumps from Florence in one scene to Cypress in the next. In Hamlet the title character is sent to England in one scene and reappears a couple scenes later after supposedly sailing the high seas, being taken captive by pirates, jumping ship and sneaking back into Denmark. Lastly, Shakespeare s plays abound in complications arising from intertwined plotlines. Romeo and Juliet would have had a much better time of it if hadn t been for quarrelsome Tybalt and Mercutio feeling obligated to carry out the feud between the Capulets and Montegues, for the influence of the eager but misguided Friar, and the enthusiastic Paris pressuring Capulet to allow him to marry Juliet. If it were possible to remove those characters, each with their own story arcs, Romeo and Juliet s stars aren t nearly so crossed. What is more, Shakespeare s plays use very little exposition and all exhibit early points of attack. The audience learns about the characters in real time and some of the stories take place over several weeks or even months in the case of Hamlet (including the trip to England and back) and MacBeth (with news of the death of the King spreading and an army massing and invading from a neighbouring country). Lastly, Shakespeare doesn t fit with Aristotle s description of good playwriting or the neo-Classical ideal of verisimilitude because of his use of fantastic and supernatural elements like the witches in MacBeth, the ghost of Hamlet s father, or the sorcerer, Prospero, in The Tempest. If these descriptions of Shakespeare s plays evoke thoughts of RPGs you have played, it should. Most RPGs are episodic in structure: take place in several locations (sometimes other continents, worlds or dimensions), span weeks, months or even years (ie. In Fallout III the player is literally born at the start of the game and finishes the game as an adult), have many subplots and side-quests that may be related but are not central to the main story-arc, use early points of attack in the narrative and most all include fantastic, magical and supernatural elements. The best example of recent advances in this style of storytelling is found in Bioware s Dragon Age. A real effort has been taken to create a braiding of several plots that intersect at pivotal points within the game while at the same time providing a richly varied experience depending on which story/origin-arc the player chooses to explore. The experience is further varied by which party companions the player brings into the different instances. The Dragon Age story is epic in the Homeric sense but its narrative approach is Shakespearean in the way it is structured into a series of scenes moving a clear plot progression forward culminating in acts marked by major shared plots points. The fantastic elements found in most RPGs of the use of magic and presence of monsters, undead and demons is taken further in this game with the ever-present influence of The Fade, a parallel/superimposed dream dimension inhabited by creatures that have a real influence on the fate of the player-character(s). Lastly, Dragon Age takes the RPG genre forward and is more akin to Shakespeare in the sense that every character encountered in this world has a story, a purpose and a goal. Not all the characters are good including the player if he or she chooses as is true in Shakespeare s plays (ie. Richard III, MacBeth, Aaron, Iago, Claudius, etc.) but they are all true to their motivations and alignment. For example, Leliana, Morrigan and Wynne all have (and express) different world views and ideas of fairness and justice based on their personal histories and experiences. The attention and development that went into the game regarding the like/dislike mechanic and the different dialogue possibilities between characters creates a sense of these characters pasts and reinforces the reality of the game world. Shakespeare made use of language in a similar way by creating complete worlds not through sets and costumes but through dialogue and the power of the spoken word. I offer these two theatrical models applied to these two games as examples of the rich artistic and theoretical groundwork available to interpret and even inspire further advances the use of narrative within games. We should move beyond denial of the importance of story in game-play, especially in games of progression, as shown by the advances in game writing in the last five years. I believe writing for games and game development is an artistic medium. Aristotle s insights into effective storytelling do not need to be simplified or reinvented to fit interactive media like games. Game development and writing has matured to the point where Aristotle s model, Shakespeare s example, and many others can be applied insightfully to great advantage. For example, the horror/survival game genre could benefit from the nightmare visions of symbolist drama. Also, I think it would be very interesting to see a Brechtian take on a first person shooter or a Grand Theft Auto-type game to make the player aware of and question the socio-economic forces at work putting the player character in those desperate situations. Arguing over definitions and whether games and story can mix is moot. Why reinvent the wheel? I know where there are lots of wheels to choose from. This fledgling field of game­studies/ludology/cyberdrama/interactive media is a little more than two decades old, allow it to borrow from a discipline that is more than two millennia old, the original interactive media, theatre. article_rec.title: Single webcam 3D tracking for video games

abstract.par: This contribution presents an easy to implement 3D tracking approach that works with a single standard webcam. We describe the algorithm and show that it is well suited for being used as an intuitive interaction method in 3D video games. The algorithm can detect and distinguish multiple objects in real-time and obtain their orientation and position relative to the camera. The trackable objects are equipped with planar patterns of five visual markers. By tracking (stereo) glasses worn by the user and adjusting the in-game camera's viewing frustum accordingly, the well-known immersive "screen as a window" effect can be achieved, even without the use of any special tracking equipment.

fulltext.ft_body: Single Webcam 3D Tracking for Video Games David Scherfgen1, Rainer Herpers1,2,3, Timur Saitov1 { david.scherfgen, rainer.herpers, timur.saitov } @ h-brs.de 1 Bonn-Rhein-Sieg University of Applied Sciences, Dept. of Computer Science, St. Augustin, Germany 2 York University, Department of Computer Science, Toronto, Canada 3 University of New Brunswick, Faculty of Computer Science, Fredericton, Canada ABSTRACT This contribution presents an easy to implement 3D tracking approach that works with a single standard webcam. We de­scribe the algorithm and show that it is well suited for being used as an intuitive interaction method in 3D video games. The algorithm can detect and distinguish multiple objects in real-time and obtain their orientation and position rel­ative to the camera. The trackable objects are equipped with planar patterns of .ve visual markers. By tracking (stereo) glasses worn by the user and adjusting the in-game camera s viewing frustum accordingly, the well-known im­mersive screen as a window e.ect can be achieved, even without the use of any special tracking equipment. Categories and Subject Descriptors H.4 [Information Systems Applications]: Miscellaneous; I.4 [Image Processing and Computer Vision]: Appli­cations General Terms Human Factors, Performance Keywords 3D Head Tracking, Visual Markers, Pose Estimation 1. INTRODUCTION Webcams have become a common part of contemporary PCs, and most notebooks sold within the last years have an integrated camera. However, these cameras are mainly used for chatting and recording videos only. Very few com­puter games make use of webcams beyond these purposes. They rarely, if ever, use a webcam as an input device, except for some that focus entirely on that aspect. Nevertheless, at least one commercial camera-based head tracking system for computer games exists1, but it requires purchasing special 1TrackIR: http://www.naturalpoint.com/trackir/ Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. Future Play 2010, May 6-7 2010 Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 hardware and operates in the infrared domain. This may seem surprising, since by applying some image processing and computer vision methods, even a webcam of low qual­ity can be turned into a valuable and intuitive interaction device. Most games cannot utilize all of the processor cores a mod­ern computer system has to o.er. Therefore, the spare com­puting power can be well used for a task like detecting an object in a webcam video stream. The algorithmic ground­work for real-time 3D object tracking using only a single camera has been laid by researchers mainly from the .elds of augmented reality (AR) and autonomous systems. For an example, see the ARToolKit2 . In this context, 3D track­ing implies determining the three-dimensional position and orientation of an object over time by processing the camera images. The resulting data can be used by a game as a way of user interaction. The goal of this contribution is to make game designers and developers aware of the possibilities so that future games will take advantage of them, and to show that even without years of experience in the .eld of computer vision, an as­tonishingly well functioning solution can be implemented in short time. First, we present the 3D tracking algorithm that we implemented. We then discuss its performance and usefulness on the basis of an example application. Finally, a number of additional proposals about how this approach could be used in actual computer games will be given. 2. TRACKING ALGORITHM We start with a discussion of the trackable patterns de­sign and then continue with the detection and tracking of markers in the video image. After the markers have been detected, the algorithm tries to identify the known patterns of the trackable objects. In this step, the algorithm makes use of the concept of p 2-invariants (perspective and permu­tation), which will be brie.y introduced. Given the mapping from image points to trackable markers, one can deduce the object s pose. 2.1 Trackable patterns The presented algorithm works with coplanar con.gura­tions of .ve visual markers, where no three markers are allowed to be collinear. The markers themselves are dark squares on a bright background with a bright dot in the center (see Figure 1). This will allow them to be detected in the image easily and in a robust way, even in changing il­lumination situations. Symmetric con.gurations of markers 2http://www.hitl.washington.edu/artoolkit/ should be avoided, since they can lead to ambiguities and possibly unstable results. Figure 1: A .ve-point planar trackable pattern in the form of glasses that can be worn by the user. It is necessary to know the coordinates of the markers very precisely, as any error will negatively in.uence the 3D tracking accuracy later. Therefore, we recommend drawing trackable patterns using a graphics program and printing them. The coordinate system on the trackable can be de­.ned arbitrarily. For multiple trackables to be used at the same time, their patterns should be distinct. Three well distinguishable patterns can be created by having .ve, four and three points on the pattern s convex hull (see Figure 2). Figure 2: Three well distinguishable marker con.g­urations that di.er in the number of markers inside and on the convex hull. 2.2 Camera calibration When detecting a marker in the camera image, one is usually not interested in its pixel position, but rather in the direction of the ray beginning at the camera and passing through the point where the marker is located in 3D space. For an ideal camera, that direction can be calculated easily from the observed pixel position. However, real camera im­ages are distorted in several ways, and in applications that rely on high precision, these distortions have to be taken into account. Therefore, we assume that the camera has been calibrated properly. This is a standard procedure in computer vision, which is usually achieved by showing a special calibration pattern from various perspectives. It has to be performed only once for a given camera and can be done easily also by non-experts. 2.3 Marker detection In each frame, the algorithm analyzes the camera im­age (converted to grayscale) to directly detect markers in it. Since the dark squares on a bright background produce strong edges, we begin by applying the Canny edge detector [2]. This results in a binary image in which white pixels indi­cate the presence of an edge, as shown in Figure 3. It may be a good idea to keep the thresholds used by the Canny .lter adjustable by the user to .ne-tune the algorithm s perfor­mance under di.erent illumination conditions. The next step consists of extracting closed contours, that is loops of connected white pixels. For each contour, we have to test if it contains a marker or not, by checking it against a number of criteria. Area: Usually, one can make reasonable assumptions re­garding the minimum and maximum area (in pixels) that can be covered by a marker. We discard any contour if its area does not fall into this range. Shape: Fit a minimum rotated rectangle to the contour (for example, using the rotating calipers method [5]). If the ratio of the rotated rectangle s area and the original con­tour s area or the ratio of the rectangle s longer and shorter side is too big, then the contour is not considered being a square and can also be rejected. Contrast: The contour s pixel contents should exhibit a certain contrast due to the bright dot in the center of the dark square, and the number of bright pixels should be less than the number of dark pixels. Every contour that ful.lls the criteria may contain the image of a marker. In the next step, we try to locate the white dot inside of it with sub-pixel accuracy. The algorithm iterates over the pixels within the contour and computes a weighted average in which every pixel s position is weighted by the pixel s intensity, provided that it is high enough to be a part of the center dot. In our example implementa­tion, the center dot s position is computed according to the following formula (where minIntensity and maxIntensity are the minimum and maximum pixel intensities within the rectangle rect): 1 threshold = · (minIntensity + maxIntensity) 2 weight(x, y)= max{0, image(x, y) - threshold} (x, y) · weight(x, y) x,y.rect center = weight(x, y) x,y.rect Figure 3: The original camera image, the result of the Canny .lter and an enlarged view of the area surrounding the dot. The white circle indicates the sub-pixel accurate center position. Figure 3 shows the result of this step for an example im­age. Note that the marker s dot only covers very few pixels in the image. 2.4 Marker tracking In comparison to more expensive cameras, webcams typ­ically o.er very small apertures and are therefore relatively insensitive to light. That means that in order to collect enough photons for an image with an acceptably low noise level, the exposure time must be long. Hence, movements tend to lead to strong motion blurring, which poses a prob­lem for the direct marker detection approach. In a blurred image, the edges may not be distinct enough any more to be detected reliably without introducing false positives (see Figure 4). For this reason, we apply a variant of the Lucas-Kanade optical .ow method [1]. It estimates the optical .ow .eld Figure 4: Due to motion blurring, moving markers are di.cult to detect directly in the image. (the 2D velocity vector of objects in an image) based on the current and the previous image frame. We use it to track markers from the last frame and .nd them again in the current frame. This is achieved by following the optical .ow .eld and .nding an area that is similar to the marker s neighborhood in the last frame. 2.5 Matching Once the markers have been extracted from the image, a mapping between these markers and the .ve markers of trackable objects must be established (correspondence prob­lem). Only then it is possible to compute the object s pose relative to the camera. Let Oi be the observed markers (detected or tracked) and Ti the markers on a trackable. Assume that |O| >5 (due to false positives in the detection stage, this is possible) and that there is only a single track­ |O|! able object in the image. Theoretically, there are (|O|-5)! possibilities for the mapping. Testing all of them would be too expensive for larger numbers of markers. Using p 2-invariants (perspective and permutation), one can reduce the number of possible mappings considerably. For a given planar con.guration of .ve points P1...5,a.ve­dimensional vector J can be computed (see [3, 4] for a de­tailed discussion): J = j(µ),j(.),j( µ .) ,j . - 1 µ- 1 ,j µ(. - 1) .(µ- 1 with 2.6 - 6.5 +9.4 - 8.3 +9.2 - 6.+2 j(.)= .6 - 3.5 +3.4 - .3 +3.2 - 3.+1 .(P1,P2,P4) · .(P1,P3,P5) µ= .(P1,P3,P4) · .(P1,P2,P5) .(P2,P1,P4) · .(P2,P3,P5). = .(P2,P3,P4) · .(P2,P1,P5) The . function gives the signed area of a triangle. The computed vector J has one interesting property: the possi­ble values its elements Ji are independent from the ordering of the points (permutation invariant) and independent from perspective transformation (perspective invariant), and each Ji is associated to the i-th point of the pattern. Thus, re­gardless in which order the markers are detected and from which view the trackable object is shown to the camera, the values are always the same. However, J is sensitive to devi­ations in the input values (the marker s pixel coordinates), so the values vary in reality. This leads to the following approach: beforehand, com­pute the J vector for the trackable object (= JT ) using its ideal marker coordinates. Then, iterate over all .ve-element subsets of O. We call such a subset C a candidate, and we will determine if its .ve markers correspond to those of the trackable. To do that, compute the candidate s J vector (= JC ). Now test if for every JiT there is at least one JjC [] that is close enough to it (JC . JT ,JT ), and that jimin imax no candidate marker would have to be assigned to two dif­ferent trackable markers. The amounts of deviation allowed in the JiC should be determined in a prior training phase. If such a mapping exists, then these .ve candidate markers might represent the trackable. In the ideal case, this test () |O| reduces the number of possibilities to 5 . For example, consider allowed deviations of ±0.05, a track­able vector JT =(0.2,0.24,0.61,0.77,0.81) and a candidate vector JC =(0.59,0.85,0.18,0.22,0.79). For T1, there are two possibilities, as both J3 C =0.18 and J4 C =0.22 fall into the range [0.2 - 0.05,0.2+0.05]. That means that T1 corre­sponds to either C3 or C4.For T2, T3 and T4 each, there is only one possibility (C4, C1 and C5). For T5, the candidates are C2 and C5. So there are four possibilities in total, but it turns out that only one of them is valid: if we choose C4 for T1, then we cannot choose C4 again for T2. The same applies to T5: if we choose C5, then there would be no candidate marker left for T4. Additional tests further reduce the candidates for a track­able. For example, one can compute each candidate s convex hull and count the number of points inside it. If that number is di.erent from that of the trackable pattern, then the can­didate can be rejected. Also, neighbor relations of the points on the convex hull must be the same as on the trackable. 2.6 Pose estimation Given the 2D image coordinates of .ve markers and their 3D coordinates on the trackable, one can compute the track­able s position and orientation. This is known as the per­spective n-point problem (PnP), in our case with .ve copla­nar points. Many solution approaches to that problem have been proposed in literature (for example, see [6]). For every candidate marker set that passed all previous tests, we compute its pose and project the points back to the image. The mean square distance between the back­projected image point and the observed image point serves as an error measure for the match. Among the candidates, the one with the lowest error (below a certain threshold) is chosen as the .nal match. 2.7 Implementation Hint The OpenCV library3 provides implementations of all the necessary tools used by the algorithm (from camera cali­bration to PnP solving). It may serve as a quick starting point for concept evaluation, before designing optimized im­plementations for the particular application. 3. EXAMPLE AND EVALUATION Using the presented algorithm, a head tracker has been de­veloped as an example application. The user wears anaglyph stereo glasses with a printed marker pattern as shown in Figure 1, and the webcam is placed on top of the screen. A simple 3D environment is rendered to the screen using anaglyph stereo graphics. When the user moves his head, the virtual camera is adjusted accordingly, so that the screen acts as a window into the virtual environment (Figure 5). For this to work, the glasses pose must be known relative to the screen, but the algorithm computes the pose relative to the camera. The pose can be transformed from camera space to screen space by measuring the screen rectangle in the camera coordinate system. A straightforward solution 3http://opencv.willowgarage.com/ Figure 5: Example head tracking application. The virtual camera is adjusted to the user s head position to make the screen act as a window. to that is using a pointer equipped with a trackable pat­tern. The position of the pointer s tip must be known in the trackable s coordinate system (for convenience, it is lo­cated at (0, 0, 0) in our application). Then, by successively pointing at the corners of the screen, its dimensions and its pose relative to the camera can be retrieved. The procedure is easy to perform and has to be repeated when the camera was moved. Figure 6 shows the three coordinate systems. Figure 6: Overview of the three coordinate systems involved in the example application. Although extensive evaluations regarding the system s ac­curacy, robustness and latency have yet to be carried out, the example application showed that it is well suited for the head tracking task. Our unoptimized prototype (using OpenCV) is able to track .ve markers at roughly 50 frames per second using a video resolution of 320 × 240 pixels, running on a single core of an Intel Pentium Core2Quad at 2.4 GHz. At typ­ical camera distances, we achieve sub-centimeter precision. Stationary markers are reliably detected directly, and the tracking can well handle typical head motion. Since the algorithm doesn t bu.er any frames, latency generally de­pends on how fast the camera can deliver video frames. Due to unavoidable image noise, there are small amounts of jitter. Introducing a .lter helps, but at the cost of la­tency. The position data is less a.ected by the jitter than the orientation data. However, su.cient illumination is necessary to achieve these results. Otherwise, high exposure times lead to blurred images and make it di.cult to detect and track the markers. The required amount of light depends on the camera used. 4. FURTHER APPLICATIONS We already proposed using the tracking system to achieve the screen as a window e.ect. Aside from that, some more use cases may be worth investigating. Look-around in .ight simulators: In realistic .ight simulators, the player s .eld of view is mainly occupied by cockpit instruments, which often do not even .t on one screen. Usually, the player look around using the coolie hat on top of the joystick. However, this is a digital input device that can only be pushed in nine distinct directions. Simply turning one s head slightly (so that one can still look at the screen) is a more intuitive solution for this task. Dodging: Video game players, especially those with little experience, often move their head when they are about to hit an obstacle in a racing game, trying to avoid the collision. Using a head tracker, the player s vehicle could be given a slight additional push according to the head movement. A similar approach is possible for dodging projectiles in a shooter game. Leaning: First-person shooters often allow the player to look around corners. It is straightforward to implement and intuitive for the player to use the head tracker for this action. 5. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK We have presented an easy to implement visual tracking approach that works with a standard webcam and is there­fore less expensive than some of the commercial systems that require special cameras. Trackable objects are equipped with a planar pattern of .ve simple visual markers. These markers are either directly detected in the video image or tracked over multiple frames by applying the Lucas-Kanade optical .ow method. Using p 2-invariants, the correspon­dence problem is solved e.ciently. Then, a standard PnP algorithm is applied to compute the object s pose. Given su.cient illumination, the algorithm can well handle typical head movements. We implemented the screen as a window e.ect as an example application and think that the system provides an intuitive input method for computer games. We re planning to add support for trackable objects with more than .ve markers for increased reliability (so that not every marker has to be visible all the time). 6. REFERENCES [1] J. Bouguet. Correspondence of coplanar features through P2-invariant representations. In ICPR94, pages A:196 200, 1994. [5] G. Toussaint. Solving geometric problems with the rotating calipers. In In Proc. IEEE MELECON 83, pages 10 02, 1983. [6] Y. Wu and Z. Hu. PnP problem revisited. J. Math. Imaging Vis., 24(1):131 141, 2006.

article_rec.title: "Oh-No! Banjo"
article_rec.subtitle: a case study in alternative game controllers

abstract.par: Alternative video game control devices have played a role in the success of music/rhythm games, as well as the success of video gaming consoles like the Nintendo Wii. This paper provides a brief background of alternative game controllers with respect to education and describes the process of creating "Oh-No! Banjo"---a banjo videogame controller and accompanying game created for Rochester Institute of Technology's experimental seminar course in Alternate Game Interfaces. The experimental controller and game received accolades in the press and offers a "roadmap" for others seeking pursue similar innovations.
