fulltext.ft_body: Oh-No! Banjo A Case Study in Alternative Game Controllers Mike Ey Joe Pietruch David I. Schwartz Dept. of Interactive Games & Media Dept. of Interactive Games & Media Dept. of Interactive Games & Media Rochester Institute of Technology Rochester Institute of Technology Rochester Institute of Technology Rochester, NY 14623 Rochester, NY 14623 Rochester, NY 14623 Telephone number, incl. country code +1-585-871-9162 +1-585-475-5521 eymike[at]gmail[dot]com percipient24[at]gmail[dot]com dis[at]mail[dot]rit[dot]edu ABSTRACT Alternative video game control devices have played a role in the success of music/rhythm games, as well as the success of video gaming consoles like the Nintendo Wii. This paper provides a brief background of alternative game controllers with respect to education and describes the process of creating Oh-No! Banjo a banjo videogame controller and accompanying game created for Rochester Institute of Technology s experimental seminar course in Alternate Game Interfaces. The experimental controller and game received accolades in the press and offers a roadmap for others seeking pursue similar innovations. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.6 [Simulation and Modeling] Simulation and Gaming; J.5 [Arts and Humanities] Music Simulation Games General Terms Design, Human Factors, Legal Aspects Keywords game design, music games, education, interfaces 1. INTRODUCTION As interest in game education continues to grow, academics study a variety of aspects of games: design, development, critique, culture, and more. This growing body of work tends to focus on what s in the game, what makes a better game, how people react, and so forth. Since players interact with games via controllers, what is the state of that work? Consider a popular text on game design [1] with only a few pages devoted to controller design. Some other design textbooks follow suit. But with numerous and recent innovations, we believe that game controllers offer tremendous opportunities for innovation and study. Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. ACM FuturePlay 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, BC. Canada Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7 ...$10.00 1.1 Videogame Interfaces Does a player actually play a game? Even for board games, a player may roll dice, move pieces, write notes, and communicate with other players. These actions serve as inputs into the game. With videogames, the interface typically involves the game controller. Although there is no official standard (other than the keyboard and mouse for computer games), the winged controller has emerged as the de facto standard. Actually, the game controller history is quite varied and documented in great detail elsewhere [2-4]. For the purpose of this paper, we choose to look at the other controllers alternative controllers. Given no formal standard, technically every controller can be classified as alternative, especially when considering different/new consoles. However, for the purpose of this work, we consider controllers, such the WiiMote, guitar controllers, and others that depart from the standard defined above. 1.2 Music and Rhythm Games The music and rhythm game genre has gained attention in the last few years in the west due to the success of games, like Guitar Hero [5] and Rock Band [6]. The genre is much older than these two games, however, and has been popular in Japanese arcades since the mid-to-late 1990 s. Games from Konami s Bemani division, such as Guitar Freaks [7], Drummania [8], and Keyboardmania [9] foreshadowed the rise of the full-band experience. These games allow multiple people to play the same song in an arcade on linked machines, effectively forming a simulated band. These simulationist games are preceded by simpler, more purely rhythm oriented games, like Beat Mania [10] and Dance Dance Revolution [11]. One might even consider the Simon toy to these kinds of games, offering light-up buttons and distinct tones without checking timing or rhythm. Rhythm and music games are in some ways converging with real instruments. The skills required to play the drums in Rock Band do not differ greatly from the skills required to play actual drums. Japanese games, like Drummania and Keyboardmania integrate an actual Yamaha electronic drum kit and 30-key keyboard into their respective arcade cabinets, further blurring the distinction between gaming and music. The case study described below continues to explore this converging space: bringing music video games closer to actual instrument playing, thereby making music more accessible. 1.3 Game Hardware and Education Given the consumer interest in alternative controllers, an experimental seminar ran at our institution in 2009. Following a similar approach to hardware-oriented reverse engineering courses [12], students disassembled and analyzed existing controllers to design and make their own. In fact, various experimental controllers have appeared in the literature (e.g., [13]; see also [14­17] for music-oriented projects). For each, students and/or researchers posed improved ways to interact with certain kinds of games, either to innovate the game design and/or facilitate player interactions. 1.4 Overview In the experimental seminar one team produced an innovative game controller that received international attention: a banjo game controller. By explaining the technical development, we hope to inspire other educators and researchers seeking to try their own innovations. Below, we explain the initial motivation for choosing a banjo. The next sections explain the hardware and software evolution, as a banjo game required significant iteration that affected the final design. A key issue, the interface, greatly influenced the game. Finally, although the banjo proved a tremendous success, various aspects to improve the controller and experience remain open. 2. MOTIVATION FOR BANJOS Oh-No! Banjo is one project created as part of the experimental seminar [18, 19]. This final project was a group effort to create a game that used a non-existent controller and to create it if possible. The popularity of rhythm games was used as a starting point, and the desire to more closely emulate the multiple-stringed nature of the instruments led to banjos which are known for their complex finger-picking play style. The university s president is a known banjo collector and aficionado, which also influenced the decision to make a banjo game. 3. HARDWARE DESIGN 3.1 Design Evolution Modern guitar controllers all simulate playing a stringed instrument through the use of a strum-bar. The strum-bar is a hinged piece of plastic positioned and sprung such that when it is tilted up or down, it trips an electronic switch. Strum-bar assemblies are large, and the team did not have the resources to manufacture one. They considered two alternatives: strings and arcade pushbuttons. At first, the team attempted to create a system that would simulate actual strings. It utilized the internals of a click-top pen, using the spring to hold the tip against a metal pick up. The flexible ink well tube formed the string. When plucked, the tip would move away from the contact, opening the switch. The team abandoned this design because of completion time, mechanical complexity, and physical durability. The other option considered involved standard, Japanese style arcade pushbuttons, which are compact, reliable, and readily available to the team. They come in a variety of colors, which could be matched to the on-screen graphics for ease of use. Reliability and ease of use were the deciding factors, and so, the team constructed the banjo using arcade push-buttons wired into the circuitry of an existing Rock Band wired guitar controller. 3.2 Final Design As shown in Figure 1, the team constructed the Oh-No! Banjo controller from an Xbox 360 wired Rock Band guitar controller, a tambourine, some MDF board, six Japanese-style arcade buttons, and assorted parts. The tambourine had its cymbals removed and top reinforced with MDF. The team drilled holes into the tambourine, and snapped and glued buttons into place. The Xbox 360 Wired Rock Band guitar conveniently has a common ground, which permits grounds to be daisy chained across the buttons. The buttons were wired to the leads connected to Up, Down, Left, Right, Back, and Start . The first five would be the strumming buttons, and Start would pause the game during play. Using the Back button for regular gameplay departs from standard Xbox 360 usability guidelines but was necessary to get the strum input for the last of the five strings. The neck of the Rock Band guitar was left intact and mounted to one end of the tambourine. Banjos have five strings, and the Rock Band controller has two sets of five buttons on the neck for simulated fretting. The team left these intact and unmodified to allow the banjo controller to maintain its original Guitar Hero or Rock Band functionality. 4. SOFTWARE DESIGN 4.1 Platform Oh-No! Banjo was written in C# and XNA 3.0 for Windows. C#/XNA permitted and extremely rapid development cycle and aided in created a data-driven application. Principle advantages included the following: ready-built sprite routines robust support for interacting with Xbox 360 controllers a content pipeline system 4.2 MIDI/Song Data Oh-No! Banjo uses a compile-time data driven architecture. The XNA content pipeline encourages the creation of modules that build application data into an intermediate format, doing heavy processing work at build time so that run-time data loading is fast and optimized. This model allowed the team to build modules that process MIDI files to drive the game. Each MIDI file processed contained twelve tracks, composed of: one track for the actual song audio ten tracks for the fret and strum notes for each of the five difficulties in Oh-No! Banjo the last track to drive the slide shows The MIDI processor looked for specific MIDI Note On events in the stream that indicate specific in-game events. MIDI format was chosen because it would be easy to synchronize actual audio to note charts core to the game play. The packages did not support direct MIDI playback. So, the MIDI was audio rendered into a wave file which was loaded and played through XACT3. Nevertheless, using the same track to render the audio and drive the game s note charts ensured no synchronization issues. The note bricks aligned with the audio well. As MIDI is a widely recognized format, there are also many MIDI editors that we were able to choose from to create note charts. An application known as TabIt!, a tabbing application for guitar and bass players, provided an excellent note chart editor. Song lists and slide shows were parameterized via XML, leading to a relatively complete separation of code and data. Adding a song, slide show, or other in game data required one to change a set of XML files and recompile the content project. With a compile-time data driven design, an end-user could not edit the content easily, but this approach made development quick and easy, especially considering the course deadline. 4.3 Scoring The game s scoring mechanisms subscribe to events exposed by the note highway (the path taken by notes before the player hits them), update the score, and track the song for failure. Upon song completion or failure, the score screen is displayed. 5. GAME INTERFACE Creating the GUI for Oh-No! Banjo became an interesting challenge. The team needed to communicate ten different buttons to the player five for chords and five for finger-picking. The team also wanted it to feel similar to note highways found in existing rhythm games. The interface could not feel overwhelming and should be intuitive. The interface started as a Flash animation prototype to demonstrate the concept for development into the functional XNA version. When playing the banjo, the focus for one hand is on complicated finger-picking, while the other hand performs relatively simple chord changes. To emulate actual banjo play, the team decided to: communicate the finger-picking similarly to the note gems found in established rhythm games, and add shading to the background of each track when its corresponding chord button was active as part of a chord. Thus, the finger-picking gems made up the foreground and carried the majority of the visual emphasis, whereas the chord shading was de-emphasized so as not to overwhelm the player. The resulting interface was very dense, communicating the additional chord information in the same amount of screen-space used in existing rhythm games. Figure 2 shows a screenshot of the complete game s interface. Shaded regions on each note track indicate which fret buttons should be held to form chords. The note gems indicate which finger-picking buttons to press in time as they cross the line. The player can see all of the necessary instruction without having to look to another portion of the screen, making the game interface easy to read at a glance. Impromptu interviews conducted during demo sessions demonstrate anecdotally that players took a short amount of time to grasp the new interface. These players also reported that they understood the interface fully and knew which buttons to press. Any difficulty experienced during gameplay resulted from unfamiliar mechanics of finger-picking indicative of a lack of practice playing with the controller and not a lack of understanding what the game was asking them to do. 6. LEGAL ISSUES The primary legal issue faced by the team was gaining the permission to use music that has not yet entered the public domain. The first song added was Ode to Joy simply because there was no question as to its legal status. Members of the team spoke with RIT s legal counsel to determine exactly what was permissible with regard to song content and copyrights. The decision was to use public domain or creative commons works, largely because of the potential for public demonstration at the 2009 GDC Expo superseded any allowances for academic fair use. The team took additional steps to contact some artists directly, and permission was granted in some cases to use songs not belonging to public domain or creative commons. 7. POST-MORTEM 7.1 What Went Right The team produced a game project and controller that withstood rigorous public demonstration over the course of a few days. The project was displayed and playable at the GDC 2009 on the expo floor [18], and was shown at the Imagine RIT Festival. In both cases, the game and controller operated continuously for up to eight hours at a time without crashing or breaking. C#/XNA greatly aided the creation of this stable software project. The content pipeline extensions greatly facilitated integrating everyone s work. Using arcade buttons made the controller sturdy enough to endure several days of public play without breaking. 7.2 What Went Wrong The rapid development produced a code project that is a bit hairy in some places. The code tends not to be modular or reusable. It would be difficult to maintain. Performance of the game could still be refined. A re-work of the rendering routines would allow the project to function nicely on lower-end hardware. The project was written with XNA for Windows, but XNA can also target the Xbox 360. Work could be done to allow Oh-No! Banjo to run on the Xbox 360 as well, though this would likely require significant re-writing of the existing code base. 8. FUTURE WORK The complete team reports and other resources are available to the public for any curious about extending this work [19]. There are a number of avenues left to explore for the banjo game. A primary area is the idea of a stringed banjo design. The use of actual strings on music simulation games is an area that has not been widely considered as of yet. Attempting the approach in a robust way could help drive the genre forward. 9. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS Oh-No! Banjo was the combined effort of the following students listed alphabetically: Dominic D Aniello, Mike Ey, Sela Davis, Alex Lifschitz and Joe Pietruch. They operated under the direction of, and drew inspiration from, Professors David I. Schwartz and Jay Alan Jackson. We also thank RIT s President, Dr. William Destler, for his support of the project and love of banjos; Cory Doctorow for the exposure gained from his boingboing.net article [14]; Bob Finnerty for his article in RIT s University News [15]; members of Harmonix for their feedback during the 2009 GDC Exposition; visitors to our booth and play­testers at the 2009 Imagine RIT Innovation and Creativity Festival; and our instructors and classmates in the Alternate Controllers seminar for their feedback and suggestions. 10. article_rec.title: THEEMPA
article_rec.subtitle: simple AR games using layar

abstract.par: Augmented Reality (AR) Games have been investigated for several years, but have only been deployed by the research community and in special installations. However, the advent of inexpensive phones and PDAs with sophisticated sensor and graphics hardware allows AR games to reach a much broader audience. For developers to quickly deploy AR games, they will need tools to abstract much of the difficult work away. We investigate on such tool, Layar, a geotagging system, in this paper. While no games have been published using Layar to date, it provides a rich set of AR tagging tools. We explore the possible scope of games designed with Layar, and present an implementation. Recommendations for AR toolkit designers are presented in the discussion.

fulltext.ft_body: THEEMPA: Simple AR Games Using Layar Farjana Z. Eishita and Kevin G. Stanley Department of Computer Science, University of Saskatchewan Saskatoon,SK S7N 5C9, Canada {farjana.eishita, kstanley@cs}.usask.ca ABSTRACT Augmented Reality (AR) Games have been investigated for several years, but have only been deployed by the research community and in special installations. However, the advent of inexpensive phones and PDAs with sophisticated sensor and graphics hardware allows AR games to reach a much broader audience. For developers to quickly deploy AR games, they will need tools to abstract much of the difficult work away. We investigate on such tool, Layar, a geotagging system, in this paper. While no games have been published using Layar to date, it provides a rich set of AR tagging tools. We explore the possible scope of games designed with Layar, and present an implementation. Recommendations for AR toolkit designers are presented in the discussion. Keywords Augment Reality (AR), APK, POI. 1. INTRODUCTION People have made magic window and immersive AR games before; however, the advent of powerful media-capable phones and PDAs allows AR magic window games to reach millions of users. Software tools that provide frameworks for developing AR applications will be a critical part of the success or failure of magic window AR games. We create a simple game and evaluate the utility of one such tool, Layar, a client-server system for delivering geotagged AR content, which allows developers to deploy geotagged points of interest with a layer of AR content. We have named our work THEEMPA which is the abbreviation of the games Treasure Hunt, Easter Egg, Maze, Puzzle and Adventure. When the Layar APK was launched, a web service was introduced which included categories for published layers. At the beginning of February 2010, despite hundreds of published layers, the Games category remained empty. When the website was upgraded in March 2010, the Games category was removed entirely. Given the potential for magic window AR games on the current generation of smart phones, this was puzzling, particularly given the rich set of AR capabilities provided by the Layar APK. This paper presents an analysis of the scope of games possible using the Layar APK v3.0.4, validates these assertions by making a simple prototype and makes recommendations for simple extensions to the toolkit to Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 facilitate game development. 2. RELATED WORK Work on augmented reality started in the early 90s particularly based on the work of Azuma [2] where he described the application of augmented reality applications in medicine, manufacturing, visualization, robot path planning, entertainment and military aircraft design. Another survey was written by Azuma, et al. [1], several years later. Among the work reviewed was the groundbreaking work by Kato and Billinghurst [7], which introduced fiducial markers. Later they launched their work as a tool for developing augmented reality environment (ARToolkit1). Later, significant work has been done using this tool including the Magic Book [3], and 3D visualization and collaboration services for ubiquitous computing in cars [8]. Later, this technology was implemented in handheld devices like PDAs or smart phones. A mobile phone-based Augmented Reality application for 3D scene assembly was proposed by Henrysson, et al [6]. Here they have described 6 DOF isomorphic interaction technique for manipulating 3D content. An AR user interface framework particularly designed to explore disparate data sources through a single application server has been presented by Mooser, et al. [9]. Henrysson and Ollila have shown that smart phones can be used for AR without server assistance [5]. A conceptual framework for supplementary research in Mobile Augmented Reality was presented, when they ported the ARToolkitto the Symbian platform. Games are a significant application area for AR. ARQuake was one of the groundbreaking games applying this latest technology using specialized technologies [11]. Later this concept was applied in face-to-face collaborative AR environments using mobile phones [4]. Here in this approach two players can play games like tennis simultaneously. A different approach used GPS tracking along with the AR technology in MARA [10]. 3. LAYAR ARCHITECTURE Layar, as the name implies is based on applying a digital layer over the reality viewed through the camera. Points of interest specify the locations where digital artifacts can be viewed. Layers are specified by XML files by default, but other tools exist to aid layer definition, such as PorPoise2. Acting as a server it converts the data sets of all the points of interests into JSON format responses to the client XML files, tab delimited files and SQL databases are supported by PorPOIse. Layar also provides simple PHP code to filter points of interests (POI) based on labels embedded in the XML code, or the distance to the POI. PorPOIse also provides the capability to specify custom filters for the developer s layer. It is a client-server application composed of five basic 1 http://www.hitl.washington.edu/artoolkit/ 2 http://code.google.com/p/porpoise/ components app, server, provisioning website, service providers and content sources 3 . Table 1 describes the components of Layar. The response received from the server is in a simple JSON format. The contents viewable content is provided by the layer content source the final component of Layar. There are two components that are presented to third parties. First, the Layar client API that creates a private linkage between the Layar server and the Layar app. Second, the Layar Developer API which is the interface between the Layar server and the Table1: Components of Layar Component Name Service provided App Client on the mobile device of the user Server Provides the interfaces to the app, the provisioning platform and the external Service Providers Provisioning website A website on which developers can submit new layers, manage their layers and accounts Service providers Created by developers Content Source Provides the content to be viewed in the Layar browser Figure 1: Layar API Architecture Layar service providers. The API is used to fetch live data about the layer. Figure 1 presents the detailed structure of the Layar API. 4. GAME DESIGN The lack of games built using the Layar platform is likely due to the lack of inputs and game state recording capabilities available to the developer. However, with some ingenuity it is possible to engineer around these shortcomings and build a small set of simple games. http://layar.com 4.1. Games in Layar While Layar provides a simple mechanism for AR geotagging, it is limited by the scope of the inputs available. Practically, designers only have three inputs from the player: the player s position, a text box, and a radio box control. However, the radio box is global for a given game, and both the radio box and text box can only be used to build application-specific geo-tag filtering functions. By employing Layar as a game development tool, developers gain a robust platform for AR geotagging, but lose the rich input of a controller and ability to maintain game state. However, a limited set of games can be built using this toolkit. The five simplest game types: Treasure Hunt, Easter Egg, Puzzle, Maze and Adventure are based on manipulating the viewable distance to graphical objects and providing clues embedded in the displayed art or sound at each target location. Limited input is provided to the player in the form of text strings, which unlock other portions of the map. The fifth category, Adventure, allows for player input, via a text box and can be used to create AR variants of classic adventure games in the style of Zork or King s Quest. 4.1.1. Easter Egg In a classic Easter egg hunt, candy is scattered though out an environment for children to discover. In a Layar Easter egg hunt, AR artifacts are scattered throughout the environment. Players are given a starting node location, which provides information about the hunt, such as clues to what is hidden, (eg. three tiny rhinoceroses, a polka dotted horse and a giant rabbit can be found here). Players are then challenged to find them all. For the hunt to work correctly, a short distance filter with respect to the size of the play area is required. To bound the play area, virtual walls or signs can be placed to inform the player that they are leaving the play zone. This game works well collaboratively, as it is essentially a free exploration game where children can look for digital artifacts. 4.1.2. Treasure Hunt In Treasure Hunt, players have a limited vision of the nodes around them. Each node contains a graphical representation of a character, and a visual or audio representation of a clue. Clues should, as in the classic children s game, provide a general idea of the location of the next point, for example, under the tree or behind the shed. As players approach the object of the clue, they enter the tag area and an icon representing the target is presented. Once sufficiently close to the waypoint, the next audio or visual clue will be displayed. While it is possible to implement a simple treasure hunt using Layar without specialized filters, level designers must take some care. In particular, the path should contain no overlapping areas within the radius of the filter. This is particularly problematic for a traditional loop-style treasure hunt as the destination would be visible from the start. This problem can be overcome with a little ingenuity and use of the text entry capability. If every node is assigned a secret code, then the clue could contain the code for the next node. By entering the secret code and using the code as a filter, only a single node would be visible at a time. This is an effective but somewhat inelegant solution. 4.1.3. Maze Maze employs a similar mechanic to Treasure Hunt, using codes, entered in the filter, to sequentially display sets of nodes. In essence, the maze is a set of connected subgraphs. A code will display a set of geographically collocated nodes. Nodes in a maze can either be connected to other subgraphs, specified by a code, or be dead-ends. The game then is to find the node connected to the destination node, and enter the code to make the destination node visible. All the filtering is performed by the code entry, and the viewable distance can be set to encompass the entire playing field. While an ability to reveal nodes based on geographic location exists by reducing the distance filter, virtual walls offer no impediment to motion in the real world, and the player could employ an exhaustive search pattern to find the destination, ignoring the nodes entirely. While the code entry mechanic is clunky it preserves the connectivity of the virtual maze in the real world. 4.1.4. Puzzle The Puzzle game type is similar to the Maze game type. In a Maze game, the player must solve a specific puzzle, the path through a linked graph, whereas in the Puzzle genre, a broader class of puzzles can be explored. In Puzzle, we look at games similar to combination discovery games common to RPGs, where players must walk about an area tuning the state of a set of environmental variables, like the orientation of statues, to unlock a door or reveal secret passage. Players are confronted with the same problem as in Maze, but we allow nodes to be in the same spot, providing the illusion that individual nodes are changing. The set of codes that are entered in the text field is then and index to a state record, which encodes the entire set of possible configurations of the puzzle. Each move is made by the player by entering a new code based on information contained in the images. This code would then filter tags to a specific state. Note that this not only requires that each state be mapped in the internal representation, but that each state be given a unique label. 4.1.5. Adventure The adventure genre is a combination of all of the above concepts. Designers could interleave exploration, puzzle solving, and leveraging the built environment as setting. As in Puzzle, the state of the game must be uniquely encoded in the codes that the players enter. While it is possible to build an adventure game in this manner, the requirement to uniquely encode all possible game states, and the inability to store information locally, places practical limitations on the possible size of the game. 4.2. Game Implementation We implemented a simple treasure hunt game in the Layar API. This game is easily extensible to Easter Egg and can be tweaked to create simple mazes of puzzles. Several points are tagged with 3D avatars displaying information on the location of the next clue. At the starting point the player will be able to view one or two points of interest (POI). A 3D object character will occasionally provide clues to the player. After reaching a designated POI the player will receive a hint along with a piece of an image. The player will be able to view next 1 or 2 POIs based on the distance filter. Based on the hint s/he must decide the next location to explore. If the user is standing at a dead end s/he must return to the previous POI and will have to choose a different path. After finding the eight designated POIs the user will receive the final piece of an image, showing the final destination. Merging all the pieces reveals a picture of the location of the treasure. The basic platform of THEEMPA is the Layar APK, which provides the service of geo-tag enabled data. First, the client side code will send request for several POIs to the service provider. PorPOISe a point of interest server for Layar --has been used for converting the data sets of POIs into responses to the Layar client. An XML file served as the definition of our layer. Another XML file has been defined to fix the points of interest associates with the 3D objects. We used an http server on a remote machine with Linux Mandriva 2010.1 as host. After the coding was complete we tested our layer using the API Test Page provided by the Layar developer website. Finally, we developed our layer using the Layar APK on Google Android Dev Phone 2. Figure 2 presents an image of the game. Figure 2. Player with the game interface 5. DISCUSSION Layar is a web-enabled platform that provides a platform for working with geo-coded data. The structure for our games -THEEMPA - uses location information to allow players to hunt for virtual treasure using the AR interface that Layar provides with the real time camera view, which makes the game more immersive and adventurous. Layar also provides the facility to use the Google maps to encode and explore geo­tagged data in the environment. Adding the 3D models makes the game more colorful and fanciful. The puzzle we created used cropping and merging of images, a feature provided by Layar that allows encoding of the game s end state. However, a major limitation of developing game in Layar is lack of possible interactions. Layar is also limited by GPS accuracy, which can lead to disconnect between clues and encoded locations. 5.1. Utility of Layar Games While we have outlined several possible game types that could be implemented with a geotagging tool like Layar, we have not addressed the utility of Layar as a game development tool. In some ways, games in Layar are like early HTML or DVD games, where only hyperlinks were available as game mechanics. Like these early games, the experience will always be less compelling than what can be achieved through more sophisticated techniques. However, like the early HTML games, Layar abstracts significant portions of development 6. CONCLUSION process, allowing developers to focus on quickly generating content. We feel that the Layar could be successfully used in: Family Games: Technically savvy parents could replace a traditional treasure hunt with a virtual one. With the additional of a simple web-based level editor to automatically generate the XML file, the reach of this application could be extended. Location-based Advergames: While small Flash games have become a staple of online advertising, these games are divorced from the location of the client. For manufacturers like Nike, this is less of an issue, but for brick and mortar stores and restaurants this could be less desirable. It is not difficult to imaging McDonalds restaurants adding a simple AR Easter Egg hunt to compliment their adventure playgrounds, complete with brand-aware avatars eating digital fries. Educational Games: Significant work has been done in educational AR games. These games employ the contextual presentation of information as a primary mechanism; a natural fit for technically proficient educators to expand the presentation of their curriculum. While Layar in its current form will not become a standard tool for game development, for a specific subset of location-based games, and in a small subset of the location-based game market, Layar s integrated AR capabilities might justify a more limited palette of game design tools. 5.2. Game Development Recommendations The current implementation of Layar provides capabilities which transparently allow developers to geo-tag locations with AR artifacts. However, there has been no uptake of this technology for the creation of even simple AR games. While we have demonstrated that it is possible to implement simple games in Layar, and have identified a few niche markets where this might be desirable, the potential for game development using this technology is limited. We believe that the following simple assets need to be added to Layar for game development. Local Memory Management: If developers could access some form of local memory to store game state, more robust and compelling implementations in the Adventure Genre are possible. Integrated Scoped Input: With state management, context sensitive input is possible. Simply moving the text box to the main view would provide significant benefit. Allowing in-view context-sensitive radio buttons would provide even stronger benefits. Implementing these two simple changes would make Layar a potentially useful lightweight AR game development platform. Implementing the following changes would extend the functionality to allow for more robust game play. Animation: Currently only static models can be displayed. Models with looped animations would be more compelling. Additional Input Modalities: Adding a click capture would allow aim sensitive actions, and open several more game genres. Better Position Mapping: Currently, Layar s position accuracy is limited to commercial GPS resolution. More sophisticated position mapping would allow better game design, and open the possibility for multiplayer games. Augmented reality makes the imagination visible. Applying AR in a game gives the opportunity to feel the thrill of adventure in an everyday environment. We developed such a game based on the real time augmented reality platform Layar, which provides the convenience of geo-coded data, and in doing so explored the utility of geotagging based development environments for building ubiquitous AR games. Based on this analysis we made recommendations for additional capabilities to the Layar environment to make it suitable for the development of casual AR games or AR advergames. 7. ACKNOLEDGEMENTS The authors would like to thank Robert Kapiszka for building the 3D objects for the game. They also would like to thank Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) funding for research. 8. article_rec.title: Breaking boundaries
article_rec.subtitle: learning by ARG within an academic conference presentation

abstract.par: This paper discusses the experiences of the three authors during their alternate reality game (ARG) session at the 2010 Digital Media and Learning Conference. Taking the conference theme "Diversifying Participation" literally, the aim of this ARG event was to advance conference learning to a new level of involvement by employing a problem-solving and experiential method of presenting. Our intent was for attendees to collectively experience how participatory digital media learning works. Within the context of the ARG, we transformed the traditional conference room setting into an immersive ludic environment closely corresponding to the social media preferences of today's youth [4, 5, 6, 9]. We argue that ARGs exhibit pedagogically desirable qualities that are ideally suitable for learning purposes, even though their dynamic and unpredictable aesthetics require specific preparation beforehand and intense follow-up thereafter. In planning an ARG for the novel and unexpected context of an academic conference, our team engaged in a learning process that touches upon the biases inherent within the juxtaposition of play and academia [1, 12, 14]. We critically examine these experiences using a self-reflexive method and offer specific guidance for employing ARGs in diverse contexts for educative purposes.

fulltext.ft_body: Breaking Boundaries: Learning by ARG within an academic conference presentation Mela Kocher PJ Rusnak Ken Eklund CRCA, UCSD University of British Columbia Writerguy 950 Felspar St. EDCP, Faculty of Education 526 Fuller Avenue San Diego, CA 92109 Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4 San Jose CA 95125 +1 858 610 0140 +1 778 688 2252 +1 408 280 1441 mela_kocher@yahoo.de pj@pjrusnak.com writerguy@writerguy.com ABSTRACT This paper discusses the experiences of the three authors during their alternate reality game (ARG) session at the 2010 Digital 1 Media and Learning Conference. Taking the conference theme "Diversifying Participation" literally, the aim of this ARG event was to advance conference learning to a new level of involvement by employing a problem-solving and experiential method of presenting. Our intent was for attendees to collectively experience how participatory digital media learning works. Within the context of the ARG, we transformed the traditional conference room setting into an immersive ludic environment closely corresponding to the social media preferences of today s youth [4, 5, 6, 9]. We argue that ARGs exhibit pedagogically desirable qualities that are ideally suitable for learning purposes, even though their dynamic and unpredictable aesthetics require specific preparation beforehand and intense follow-up thereafter. In planning an ARG for the novel and unexpected context of an academic conference, our team engaged in a learning process that touches upon the biases inherent within the juxtaposition of play and academia [1, 12, 14]. We critically examine these experiences using a self-reflexive method and offer specific guidance for employing ARGs in diverse contexts for educative purposes. 1. INTRODUCTION ARGs are cross-media experiences, often massively collaborative, that utilize the real world as a gaming platform to tell a story that takes place in real time and evolves dynamically according to participants' ideas and actions. During the past decade, ARGs have steadily increased in both popularity and importance within the educational sector, in conjunction with research findings that reveal meaningful possibilities for games-based teaching and learning purposes [1, 8, 11, 14]. ARGs are an established viral marketing tool for corporations, an expansive playground for grassroots inventions, and growing in demand by museums [13] and non-government organizations such as the World Bank Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. Copyrights for components of this work owned by others than ACM must be honored. Abstracting with credit is permitted. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ GDC Canada, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 2 Institute. In this paper, we analyze the realization of an ARG in an environment new to this ludic genre of experiential learning: the academic conference. th On February 19 2010, we delivered a 75 minute presentation "Storytellers, Storymakers and Learning by ARG" at the Digital Media and Learning Conference at UCSD, La Jolla, California. Our aim was to foster dialogue about the pedagogical affordances and constraints of ARGs by linking theory and empirical study with participant experiences. As we strongly believe that it is most productive to personally experience an ARG prior to examining its potential, we planned a participatory ARG to engage and stimulate lively debate amongst our attendees. This paper presents a case study of our ARG from the designers' diverse points of viewing, investigating the following questions: What assumptions did we take for granted in the planning phase? What learning processes and behaviors did we expect from the participants and from ourselves? How does our open storymaking and experiential design framework relate to various forms of social learning and conference capital? Most importantly, how does the genre of ARG with its dynamic, playful and unpredictable nature suit or clash with the rigorous learning environment of an academic conference? 2. THE DESCRIPTION OF Our session "Storytellers, Storymakers and Learning by ARG" was listed as a regular panel amongst all other conference panels, therefore the game started at the scheduled time in the designated conference room. The fictional scenario was set up by Eklund s 3 opening address to the 40 session participants: Kocher, one of the speakers, got lost on the UCSD campus whilst on her way to the presentation. She contacted fellow speaker Eklund, anxiously asking for help, however her android phone was malfunctioning and she was unable to hear his directions. Eklund advised communication via Kocher s twitter page, which he projected on the conference screen, but then suddenly became inflicted by a "Stress-Induced Narcoleptic" attack (see Figure 1) and fell fast asleep for as he was just barely able to announce 20 minutes. The game scenario was clearly problem-based and goal oriented, however the rules of the game and the game play were ambiguous by design. Intending for the conference participants to become storymakers in this ARG, as opposed to the more common storytelling ARGs [8, 10, 14], our game play was purposefully left wide open for participants to come together and figure out: what to do about this unexpected situation; how to communicate with the lost speaker; and how might the sleeping speaker react to people trying to wake him up? The only prescribed story elements were that: one speaker was lost, one speaker was sleeping on the floor, and the other two speakers were conspicuously missing-in­action. Our storymakers were free to participate according to personal interests, technological devices on hand, and varying levels of comfort with social media. While a few left the session, every empty seat was quickly filled with the doorway bystanders. Creative role-play was a major part of the game s social experience: everyone role-played his/her self but pretended to believe in the story, therefore playing a version of his/her self. Although there was evidence of indirect competition, such as the race to be the first one to digitally locate Kocher s whereabouts, the wholeness of the game event was collaborative and participatory. Within the interactive learning space of this session, the opportunities were diverse and numerous for players to contribute their knowledge and ideas, for example: to twitter directions to Kocher, to visually search on the campus maps scattered throughout the room, to start a Facebook Group for "Finding Mela", to create a Wikipedia entry on "Stress-Induced Narcolepsy", to send out a person to search the campus for Kocher, and/or to try sneaking Eklund's mobile phone from his sleeping hand. The two other presenters, Petrina and Rusnak, were staged incognito in the audience as observers, ready to act as trouble-shooters. They did not need to intervene, however, thanks to the collective efforts of our actively engaged storymakers who were successful in finding Kocher and bringing her to our shared learning space. Figure 1: Game Poster created by game master Ken Eklund 3. THE MAKING OF Not only was the ludic procedure of the ARG a participatory act this was also the course of its creation, beginning with the formation of the team of puppet masters via the DML conference wiki, to the planning of the session, to the actual performance. Establishing a team consisting of four people with diverse educational backgrounds (but sharing similar goals for creating an interactive experience at an academic conference) began an interesting journey in collaboration. Since the authors reside in three different cities, we were bound to apply for the conference, create the ARG, and coordinate formal presentations via e-mail. In this regard, the storymaking method of our "making-of" phase was very similar to the storymaking learning process that we intended for participants to employ during the conference game. Eklund presented the initial game plan and suggested individual roles, then each team member took liberty in designing and probing his/her part in loose association with the team. From our experiences, this non-hierarchical and online-based procedure bears risks if instant coordination in the planning phase is needed, or for presenting a fixed and unified presentation. Face-to-face collaboration, as we believe, cannot be completely replaced by participatory co-creation online however, we were fortunate that Petrina and Rusnak work closely together at the same institution, and Eklund and Kocher were able to meet at the conference location (which coincidently is where Kocher works). Overall, this mixed approach proved to be flexible and efficient insofar as endless small adjustments might have optimized the game design in respect to increased acceptance and relevance to the anticipated players. Ultimately, the controversy of storymaking versus storytelling accompanied us from the very start choosing open spaces where productive chaos was welcome rather than having controllable, certain and closed processes corresponding to the aesthetics of ARGs that we believe are productive to learning. Whereas the traditional conference presentation isolates its material to be delivered, an ARG places its content within the pedagogical context of participatory experience [8, 10, 13]. 4. THE EXPERIENCE OF In this section we discuss diverse learning experiences from the perspectives of the three authors role-playing characters. Ken Eklund, presenter of ARG and "in game" character "From a procedural point of view, my role was very simple: explain Kocher's predicament, show how to view the photos she was posting live from her lost position (projected for all the audience to see), give out her phone number for texting, and then explain that I am prone to stress-induced narcolepsy (SIN) and, indeed, 'I feel an attack coming on now' and by removing my conscious self from the room, handing solution of the problem over to the collective action of the audience. From a gameplay point of view, however, the role is much more nuanced. The audience immediately dissects my performance for clues as to how they should perform." "Because I could tell the audience was aware this was a game, I was able to pitch my own performance as 'this is not a game' [10, 11]. By doing so, I hoped to encourage the audience to act likewise and thus to focus on innovating their own solutions to Kocher's lostness, not on finding the right solution to the game." "As an alternate reality game designer, I frequently lecture about ARGs, and often say 'ARGs are easier to play than they are to explain.' Our game, Kroblerfon, was a test of that idea, and I came away feeling that it did indeed communicate the core of the ARG concept better than 20 or even 40 minutes of lecture." Mela Kocher, "in game" character "I played the 'speaker in distress' who got lost on campus (see Figure 2) and needed to be redirected to the conference site by the participants. Part of the fictional setup was that my phone (a Belgium Kroblerfon) was 'malfunctioning' in its texting and calling functions, which left me the sole option of sending photos to reveal my whereabouts." Figure 3: Screen capture of twitter activity, Feb 19, 2010 "Even though I had previously tested the software on campus, the wifi showed some weak spots at unexpected places during the live ARG (e.g., in front of the library), causing the ping application to shut down several times. In those disconnected moments, each of the photos I was transferring got lost. Ironically, the fictitious malfunctioning of the phone became real! I was unable to keep track of which pictures were missing and there was no time for retakes: I had to be on-the-move to keep players engaged. Since my photos were the only possible feedback to the players' various directions, game communication tended to lack in coherence." "In response, I adjusted my character behavior by moving closer to the conference site and by making sure to look very lost in my gestures and facial expression, in case the participants would try to search for me in person. I was relieved to receive help from an 'innocent bystander' who escorted me to the session room where the engaged participants cheered upon my entrance." "I am still amazed by all the creativity that flourished within the very simple but restrictive frame of our ARG which we ended up calling Kroblerfon due to the faulty mobile phone." PJ Rusnak, observant and stand-by trouble-shooter "My primary directive was to be a guiding voice: not to come up with ideas about what to do, but rather to lend my support when others offered ideas, as well as to stimulate conversation amongst those trying to solve the game problem. I was ready to perform my role, however, the game community was able to function independent of my efforts, with several active players and others participating as spectators." "In my role as observer, I was offered a tantalizing glimpse at watching a participatory digital culture emerge whilst players and technological devices connected to act more intelligently together than apart. Despite the impossibility of creating a real, functioning community in a mere 20 minutes, the ARG experience went beyond my expectations for generating a new kind of conference learning one that is specifically attentive to the challenges and rewards of collaboration between diverse people and networked technologies." "While I generally observed a positive response to the chaotic and free form experimental approach of our session, the stakes were quite high. The prevailing conference currency is measured by academic knowledge, not participatory experiences: the exchange is such that attendees offer their time and presence with the expectation that the speakers will provide them with intellectual gems to take away. I wonder, however, as social media increasingly becomes a vital component of our academic lives: what is the role that a conference session should play in cultivating community and in engaging networked publics? Although we individually wrote papers and prepared formal presentations, we had insufficient time to share our research with participants. Their learning, however, was not bound by the session s time constraints, evidenced by those who continued to email, blog, tweet, text, share, ask, network, follow, friend and participate together about our session, after our session." "The evanescence of stress-induced narcolepsy, a fading last echo of the missing speaker, the storied shadows of an ARG event and the experiencing of it all? Not ever in error, only in matter of (in)significance." 5. THE LEARNING OF The genre of ARGs represents an umbrella concept for a variety of games [8, 10, 13]. The following learning features of our ARG are typical for the genre, as much as they correspond to factors well-known for engaging learning [1, 2, 3, 5, 9]: strong story, situated learning context, problem-solving scenario, collaborative goal, game orientation, variety of social networking technologies, creative role-play, dialogical reflection, (indirect) competition, and participatory learning processes. The ARG we conducted was unstructured, to a large extent, as we wanted an open storyline for the participants, our storymakers. All we proposed was a collaborative problem with a 20-minute time frame to solve it. After the game was over, we realized that we needed more time than we scheduled for debriefing and Q&A for the presenters' benefit (since we were curious to receive feedback), but mostly for the participants' benefit: the need for sharing their experiences and for asking questions was acute. We therefore recommend planning sufficient time for the ARG, as well as the debriefing and Q&A. Another common knowledge that, in retrospect, became crucial to our own learning process is the tendency of technology to malfunction. We advocate, especially for shorter ARGs, that the puppet master team: 1) keep technological requirements to a minimum, and 2) be ready with a back-up plan in the event technology malfunctions or other unexpected things occur. One of the most important aesthetics of ARGs is the principle of "TINAG" (This Is Not A Game) [8, 10, 11], meaning that the game tries not to signal its fictional nature in an obvious way. Depending on the game design and the media skills of players, this can result in a blurring of the border between "in game" and "out of game" zones, meaning that participants might not know exactly where the magic circle of the game starts and where it ends. To avoid ethical and legal issues, we strongly advise designers of educational ARGs to have clear fictional sign-posts for the participants (else, have trouble-shooters standby in case players do not comprehend the alternate reality situation). In our ARG event, we left it up to the participants to find out that Kocher actually worked on the UCSD campus (as indicated in the conference program), which therefore made it improbable for her to really "get lost". When Eklund had a dramatically staged narcoleptic fit that "would last for 20 minutes," the fictional signposts were clear and revealed in a humorous manner. Further ludic indications include the conspicuous fact that the two other speakers were missing. As our session abstract notified an ARG was planned, therefore participants were prepared for an experience, even though they did not know what it would be, or when to expect it. Very attentive attendees noticed the "in game" posters (see Figure 1) which we displayed around the conference site, urging viewers to "get the facts" on "Stress-Induced Narcolepsy" at the same date, time and place as our session. 6. THE FUTURE OF We consider Kroblerfon successful in its experimental nature and interactive ARG format as highly suitable for an international conference themed "Diversifying Participation". As one participant concluded in her blog review: "The first Digital Media and Learning conference was intended to integrate participatory behavior and to challenge the normal one-to-many model of 1 passive spectatorship at conferences . Nothing may have shown this collaborative learning principle more dramatically than 'Storytellers, Storymakers and Learning by ARG' with Stephen Petrina, Mela Kocher, Ken Eklund and PJ Rusnak." [7] In our session, collaboration occurred in various ways amongst "in-game" players, but also between participants and presenters after the live ARG. We believe that our approach to "learning by play experience" provoked a longer-lasting and more meaningful effect than a formal "presentation about learning by play" could have possibly ever achieved. It will indeed be interesting to observe future reporting of research on games-based learning: will it continue to be topically discussed in formal conference presen­tations, or will the collaborative and participatory nature of games influence upon the inherent structure of the conference itself? 7. REFERENCES [1] Moseley A., Culver, J., Piatt K. & Whitton N. In Press. Observing the users of digital educational technologies: Theories, methods and analytical approaches, New Review of Hypermedia and Multimedia, 13(2), 87 91. [7] Losh, L. 2010. Bedtime Story. Virtualpolitik. http://virtualpolitik.blogspot.com/2010/02/bedtime-story.html. [8] McGonigal, J. 2007. The puppet master problem: Design for real-world, mission-based gaming. article_rec.title: Improving content download performance in online virtual worlds

abstract.par: Virtual worlds differ from other online game services by providing features and services that allow users to create their own unique graphical 3D content to dynamically modify the virtual world. These features place significant demands on servers, clients, and the network. As virtual worlds evolve to support more users, interactions and higher-resolution graphics these demands will continue to increase. This paper describes an experimental implementation of a user-generated content download/cache management technique. This technique was tested against a commercial virtual world service and demonstrated effective in reducing network load without introducing additional inefficiencies. This work has shown it is possible to reduce the network demands of user-generated content on virtual world services entirely through a more efficient loading scheme without increasing the speed of graphical or network processing hardware or bandwidth.
