fulltext.ft_body: I mproving Content Download Performance in Online Virtual Worlds Carl Symborski EtherNexus csymborski@ethernexus.com ABSTRACT Virtual worlds differ from other online game services by providing features and services that allow users to create their own unique graphical 3D content to dynamically modify the virtual world. These features place significant demands on servers, clients, and the network. As virtual worlds evolve to support more users, interactions and higher-resolution graphics these demands will continue to increase. This paper describes an experimental implementation of a user-generated content download/cache management technique. This technique was tested against a commercial virtual world service and demonstrated effective in reducing network load without introducing additional inefficiencies. This work has shown it is possible to reduce the network demands of user-generated content on virtual world services entirely through a more efficient loading scheme without increasing the speed of graphical or network processing hardware or bandwidth. Categories and Subject Descriptors C.2.4 [Computer-Communication Networks]: Distributed Systems Client/Server; K.8.0 [Personal Computing]: General Games General Terms Algorithms, Performance, Experimentation, Theory. Keywords Online games, networked games, massively multiplayer online games, MMOG, virtual worlds, content management, networked graphics. 1. INTRODUCTION Virtual worlds and Massively Multiplayer Online Games (MMOGs) are two broad categories of online three-dimensional avatar based environments in which users can interact with other players. Services such as Second Life [3] and There.com [8] are examples of virtual worlds. World of Warcraft [1] is an example of an MMOG. A key difference between the two genres is that virtual worlds enable users to customize the world with the Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 introduction of new content that users create themselves. The problem of delays or lag in downloading player-created content to the user client can significantly degrade both the game play and the graphical quality of the experience. Regardless of graphical resolution or intensity, the technical demands to support dynamically changing user-generated content significantly exceed those of MMOGs. These demands will impact the design of future game middleware, backend and game development tools to meet this challenge. Recent research has proposed a caching strategy called Content Reconciliation that may help reduce some of the processing and network demands presented by virtual worlds. [7] This paper presents the results of an experimental implementation of the Content Reconciliation technique when tested against the performance of an existing virtual world service. The results suggest that changes in game client content cache processing can reduce client-server communication and processing loads in virtual world services thus reducing the lag in loading of graphics and enhancing the end-user experience. 2. The Impact of User-Generated Content Virtual world computation and communication requirements are greater than that of MMOGs. For example, a virtual world can generate at least 10 times more network bandwidth measured at a client than an MMOG. [7] As another example, MMOGs typically can support several thousands of clients per server where the Second Life can handle about 40 clients per server. [2] Some insight as to drivers of these differences can be gained by considering aspects of how these services process content interactions. Both MMOGs and virtual worlds must handle real-time avatar interactions with the online graphical world. To the extent that both MMOGs and virtual worlds must deal with real-time avatar interactions the processing and network bandwidth requirements should be similar. Support for user-generated content is a feature where the processing and networking bandwidth requirements of each differ. Users of virtual worlds can create and introduce into the world a wide variety of content including clothing, buildings, trees and other textures or three-dimensional objects. Further, users can add, remove and modify the placement of these objects at any time. This flexibility increases the demand on processing and network bandwidth load on servers since they must process a dynamically changing world in addition to real-time avatar interactions and communicate the results to the clients. When processing user inputs from clients the server must perform a visibility computation for each client to determine which objects are visible based on where the objects are physically placed in the world. This information is communicated to the client that must then determine if any visible object is missing from its local cache of content files. The client will request the download of missing content files from the server, another significant bandwidth demand. This processing is in contrast with MMOGs which implement a static set of world content and graphical content that reside entirely on the client machine and does not require real-time dynamic download. An MMOG server need only communicate small amounts of data associated with real-time avatar updates during game play. 3. Reconciliation of User-Generated Content To manage the dynamic nature of user created content, virtual worlds implement content caching techniques rather than a full download of all content to the client. Content is downloaded to the client for storage in the cache on an as needed basis. This is appropriate due to the dynamically changing nature of user content and also the aggregate size of the content files that makes it impractical to store all content at the client. Recent research has shown the effectiveness of caching content in a prior study where a control avatar made repeat visits to the same location in a virtual world. It was found that even with caching, the client needed to download and process user content related messages from the server even when no content changes occurred between visits. The study proposed a content reconciliation technique to further reduce the demand on network bandwidth. [7] The content reconciliation technique described in the study publication improves performance by caching on the client all data related to user content, including placement information. This approach leverages the mid-term static nature of user­generated content within a defined geographic area of a virtual world. Even though virtual world content can be dynamically changed; elaborate user in-world creations typically remain in place for months without major revisions. [6] The content reconciliation technique attempts to strike a balance between the virtual world and MMOG content download approaches. This technique manages the cache with a hierarchy of summary descriptors such that the client can determine that its cache contains all data needed for a given geographic area with a single message exchange with the server. Using content reconciliation the client is given local knowledge about the placement of objects in a region. With this knowledge a client can display these objects to the user with minimal server interaction much like in a MMOG. The virtual world server only needs to inform the client of real-time avatar interactions and short term content changes that occur in a given area. A more complete description of content reconciliation descriptors and processing is available in the referenced publication. [7] The summary descriptors define aggregate content lists of all objects placed in a specific region of a virtual world. For example There.com and Second Life implement user owned zones, lots or sims that can be used to define these regions. Applying the technique, a virtual world server would use compilation routines to periodically process user content placement information and generate the summary descriptors. Using these descriptors, the client will invoke a reconciliation routine to look for changes whenever an avatar enters a new region. If there are no changes the client can proceed to render objects from the cache with minimal server interaction. If there is missing content in the cache, the client will request the new or changed objects from the server. [7] A Content Delivery Network (CDN) [5], can also be used to supply the objects to the client, further offloading traffic from the server. Using the content reconciliation approach the server should send fewer messages to the client as an avatar moves in world. Less data is transferred between the server and client. Further, the client can perform a local visibility computation and start to render objects into the scene without waiting for messages from the server. 4. Implementation Approach The content reconciliation approach was experimentally implemented to demonstrate performance of the technique. This was accomplished through modification of an existing game engine with additional code and data structures to implement content reconciliation on both the client and server. A commercial game engine from The Multiverse Network, Inc. was used as the basis of the test implementation since it supports the addition of custom software to both server and client. [4] Core Multiverse client and server processing software is provided only as executable programs so some cases workarounds were required to prevent normal Multiverse processing from interfering with content reconciliation processing. Even so the Multiverse client/server architecture was sufficiently adaptable to the changes necessary to produce an initial implementation of the content reconciliation architecture. As defined by the data reconciliation technique, a hierarchy of reconciliation descriptors is used to support cache management and guide cache synchronization between the server and the client. The Multiverse game engine, typical of the MMOG genre, supports offline placement of world content and creation of asset files which are downloaded from the server prior to user login. To adapt the output of these tools, an asset compiler was coded which can read Multiverse world descriptor and asset files, generate the hierarchy of reconciliation descriptors required by the content reconciliation technique and add them to the Multiverse asset repository. A reconciliation process was coded to implement the data reconciliation routines. The reconciliation process is able to read the compiled reconciliation descriptors and use the information obtained to guide the download of content from the server to the client. The Multiverse client was modified to perform a local visibility computation and when the player avatar enters a new visibility region invoke the reconciliation process to download any missing content. 5. Test Approach The modified game engine was tested and a comparison made with equivalent tests run against unmodified Multiverse processing and also the There.com service. Key download related differences between these implementations are shown in Table 1. A three way comparison provides a variety of perspectives including the comparison of the modified versus un-modified Multiverse system, the comparison of Content Reconciliation (modified Multiverse) with a commercial virtual world service that supports dynamic user generated content, and also a comparison of Multiverse that does not support dynamic user generated content with two implementations that do. Table 1: Content download implementations tested Service/Engine Dynamic User Content User Content Download Trigger There.com Yes As avatar explores Content Reconciliation Yes As avatar explores Multiverse No Prior to avatar login In order to compare network bandwidth performance, a common in-world scenario was required. The Shorah Community in the There.com service was selected to be the model scenario. This community is physically defined in There.com as a square zone, 660 by 660 meters in size and is hosted on a dedicated server. It is geographically isolated from other built-up areas within There.com. A survey of the zone identified 1,039 user object placements used as decorations. The aggregate size of these objects was determined through inspection of the client cache. A similarly sized zone was created in Multiverse for comparative tests. Four reconciliation regions were defined in the zone within which the reconciliation technique would operate. It is not practical (or legal) to replicate the exact same user objects from There.com into Multiverse for use in this test. Nor is this required since content download processing is sensitive to the total number of objects and size of the data being downloaded, not what the objects look like. For this testing hundreds of custom objects were created, replicated and placed at 1,039 random spots within the zone to produce an equivalent sized cache as that observed in There.com. In the test environment separate computers were used for the server and client, which ran either the modified or un-modified Multiverse software as required for the tests. These computers were connected to a controlled local area network for measuring results. For Multiverse (modified or unmodified) implementations, software and configuration parameters were set to disable all system features except those related to download and avatar in­world interactions. Similarly, the There.com client includes numerous control options that were set to eliminate extraneous server/client messages. Of particular concern are audio streams from in-world virtual radios, voice, background sounds and system alert messages. These features were all disabled to not contribute to the traffic being measured. Steps were also taken to prevent the environment from being changed or influenced by avatars outside of the zone under test. In addition, traffic measurements were taken over multiple trials and averaged to obtain a baseline level of traffic that represents messages generated when simply running an avatar through an empty zone in all three implementations. These empty region average measurements have been subtracted from the results. 6. Comparative Test Results To analyze network communication load from the test worlds, the client PC was equipped with a network traffic measurement application. This was used to log traffic transmitted and received by the client PC during all tests. The general approach was to run each test scenario multiple times on multiple days and average the overall results. Two performance comparisons are discussed here. 6.1 Result 1: Empty Cache Scenario This test scenario measured the network traffic received by the client during a full load of content of the baseline zone in There.com, Content Reconciliation (modified Multiverse), and with un-modified Multiverse with the client cache initially empty. For all worlds an avatar was logged into the service, teleported to a corner of the test region and then walked in a spiral pattern to ensure the avatar encountered all objects in the zone. For the There.com service, objects were downloaded under control of the There.com server as each object came within the visible range of the moving avatar. For the Content Reconciliation test implementation, objects were downloaded under control of the client side reconciliation routine on entry of the avatar into each of the four reconciliation zones. The unmodified Multiverse implementation downloaded all objects when the client connected to the server prior to the avatar entering the world. The results are shown in Figure 1. Overall the There.com and Content Reconciliation download trials completed in 17 to 19 minutes with an average total traffic of 54,535 Kbytes (There.com) and 53,936 Kbytes (Content Reconciliation). The unmodified Multiverse loaded all content up front in less than 5 minutes as a batch operation for a total of 53,472 bytes. Figure 1: Equivalent traffic performance of the Content Reconciliation technique compared to There.com and Multiverse in an empty cache scenario The results indicate that the three techniques are roughly equivalent in terms of total traffic generated for the initial download of user content. As expected the unmodified Multiverse loaded all data upfront. Content download for There.com and Content Reconciliation is triggered by avatar interaction in the world and thus spread out over time. The results suggest that the Content Reconciliation technique is as traffic volume efficient as There.com for incremental download of user created content. 6.2 Result 2: Full Cache Scenario This test scenario measured the network traffic received by the client during multiple visits to the baseline zone in There.com, Content Reconciliation (modified Multiverse), and un-modified Multiverse with the client cache fully loaded with all content. For all trials, the client was started and then an avatar was logged into the service, teleported to a corner of the test region and then walked in a spiral pattern to ensure the avatar encountered all objects in the zone. For the There.com service, bursts of messages were received from the server during the first pass through the zone as each object came within the visible range of the moving avatar. Once the avatar completed a full circuit, message traffic was seen reduced to the baseline level of traffic as when the avatar moves through an empty zone. The reduced traffic persisted as the avatar visited previously encountered objects. For the Content Reconciliation test, the reconciliation routine checked for cache consistency with the server every time the avatar entered each of the four reconciliation zones. The server sent no other user content messages since the cache had all files necessary including in-world placement information. Results for the unmodified Multiverse include the overhead of downloading a manifest file that is used to verify consistency of the client cache with that of the server prior to allowing an avatar login. Since this is the normal mechanism Multiverse uses to update content on the client it is reasonable to include this in the results since There.com and Content Reconciliation also include server verification that the client cache is up-to-date. Once the avatar was logged in, messages were received from the Multiverse server telling the client where to display objects as each object came within the visible range of the moving avatar. Figure 2: Improved performance of the Content Reconciliation technique Compared to There.com and Multiverse in a full cache scenario Figure 2 shows the total download traffic received at the client for seven separate five-minute trials. No user content was changed between these trials and the average server traffic for a five­minute avatar run through an empty zone has been subtracted out. The traffic volume shown for There.com is representative of the server messages observed during avatar visits to the test zone after login. This is clearly more traffic than the cache reconciliation messages of the Content Reconciliation technique. The traffic volume for unmodified Multiverse is much greater due to the cache manifest file download when the client connects to the server. This represents about 700 Kbytes of the totals shown. The rest of the Multiverse traffic, about 400 Kbytes, is representative of the server messages observed as the avatar traverses the test zone after login. Taken together, the average total traffic received from the server to revisit a fully cached area is 380 Kbytes (There.com), 54 Kbytes (Content Reconciliation), and 1116 Kbytes (Multiverse) over a five-minute measurement period. The results indicate that the content reconciliation approach is seven times more traffic efficient than There.com. This suggests the content reconciliation technique can provide improved networking performance when revisiting areas that have not changed or only have incremental changes. 7. Conclusions Virtual worlds such as There.com, provide features and services that allow user-generated content to be dynamically added and modified in real-time. These features place significant demands on virtual world servers, clients and networks. This paper described the implementation of a user-generated content reconciliation technique proposed in the literature. [7] The user­generated content reconciliation architecture was implemented as an extension to a commercially available MMO game engine. It was tested against the There.com service and the un-modified Multiverse game engine and demonstrated effective in reducing network load. The results showed a seven fold performance improvement for services that support dynamic user generated content. Continued research of performance improvements for dynamic user content download will play a role in the design of future game middleware and backend development tools to meet the challenge of evolving virtual worlds. 8. fulltext.ft_body: Virtual World Professionals and Avatar Appearance Codes Victoria McArthur Interdisciplinary Studies York University Toronto, Ontario vickymc@yorku.ca ABSTRACT In this paper we discuss the results of a pilot study aimed at virtual world professionals in Second Life. This study was conducted in order to investigate the role avatar appearance may play in maintaining business relationships in virtual worlds. We also describe avatar appearance codes corporate policies that govern the appearance of employee avatars. In our pilot study we found that only 13.5% of participants are subject to such a policy. The details of policies are discussed below. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.7.0 [The Computing Profession]: General. General Terms Design, Human Factors. Keywords Avatar, Second Life, interloper effect, virtual reality experiences 1. INTRODUCTION Virtual worlds such as Second Life are becoming commonplace for virtual business, research, and learning [14]. Real world companies such as IBM have established a virtual presence within Second Life [3]. Employees of these companies have adopted virtual bodies, called avatars, and represent their company within the virtual world. In this paper we discuss the role avatar appearance plays in maintaining business relationships in virtual worlds. We also describe the emergence of policies which govern the appearance of employee avatars. We refer to this policy as an avatar appearance code [7, 8]. In considering these policies we discuss one possible side effect of an overly corporate avatar appearance code the interloper effect. We conducted a pilot study in order to investigate the issues concerning employee avatar appearance and present the results of our survey in this paper. Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00. 2. AVATARS In the context of virtual worlds, an avatar is an interactive, social representation of a user [9]. Avatars in virtual worlds are most often graphics-based humanoid embodiments, but also can be non-humanoid graphical forms [10], or text-based entities [4]. The creation of a graphics-based avatar is mediated by the tools provided in the virtual world s interface. These are often referred to as character creation interfaces, or avatar editors. Virtual worlds such as Second Life offer a high fidelity avatar editor, allowing users to fine tune the appearance of their avatar. In addition to the tools provided by the avatar editor, users of Second Life can buy and create items that can be applied towards their avatar s appearance, including custom skins, hair, clothes, and gestures. It is important to note that the avatar is considered an important component of the user s online identity. As such, avatar creation and modification is considered a very meaningful process [13]. 2.1 Employee Avatars In considering the professionals being deployed within virtual worlds, we must categorize their avatar as a special type of avatar in order to investigate issues of virtual world professionalism. As such, we recognize employee avatars as a special sub-class of avatar. Employee avatars are an interactive, social representation of a virtual world professional. These avatars are created, piloted, and maintained by a representative of a company or institution for the purpose of achieving corporate presence within a virtual environment [7, 8]. The mechanics of configuring the appearance of an employee avatar are the same as any other avatar in Second Life. Virtual world professionals can utilize the avatar editor and purchase additional items to complete and modify their avatar s appearance. How should these employee avatars look? Goffman stresses the importance of both verbal and nonverbal cues in our ability to generate impressions of ourselves in social situations [6]. For this reason, it is not uncommon for companies to create policies to govern employee conduct and appearance in order to maintain the company s image. Goffman s work is from 1959, but it describes many of the social norms that are still at play in our physical world. When one considers the plasticity of avatars, especially avatars in Second Life, one can easily imagine how a dress code could extend beyond attire to include rules about the avatar s physical appearance. We have used the term appearance code [7, 8], an extension of the notion of a dress code , to describe a policy that may govern various aspects of employee avatar appearance. Related work has identified a number of motivating factors that contribute to the choices users make when customizing their avatars (e.g., see [5]). Some users wish to create an avatar that represents idealized versions of themselves, others wish to explore alternate identities [11]. The desire to experiment with identity in virtual worlds is common [5], but what if the employer prefers accurate representation from his or her employees? To what degree should avatar appearance codes dictate employee avatar appearance? If we begin by considering an avatar appearance code that governs attire, we can then consider a possible sub-categorization of employee avatars: employee-identified avatars [8]. An employee­identified avatar is an avatar an employee avatar whose corporate presence is expressed partially by their avatar s appearance. This could be through the use of corporate attire (e.g.: a company uniform) or through the use of group tags a piece of text that floats above the avatar s head and affiliates them with their company. An example of this type of avatar is illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1. An employee-identified avatar We hypothesize that employee-identified avatars may elicit a negative reaction from members of the virtual world community. We use the term interloper effect to describe this phenomenon. 2.2 The Interloper Effect Within the field of evolutionary biology, a particular phenomenon has been identified with respect to interlopers. The phenomenon concerns the differences among attributions of sexual interest among different perceivers. If the perceiver is a person who is in a committed relationship with the target of the sexual interest, then the degree of sexual interest is perceived as much greater than if the perceiver is outside of the relationship. In commonplace terms, the perception of the threat is heightened for the party which is actually facing the threat, as opposed to a bystander. Therefore, the interloper effect refers to the heightened attribution of sexual interest to a potential interloper by a person who is in a committed relationship [15]. In the context of evolutionary biology, the interloper is one who challenges the monogamy of a committed relationship. To extend this term to virtual worlds, one could consider that the interloper is the one who challenges the ideals of members of the virtual world community [8]. Since virtual world communities are co-constructed to some degree by the users who inhabit them [4] the idea that an interloper threatens the community s ideals is not so far fetched. In the case of employee-identified avatars, an overly corporate avatar may have a negative effect on a virtual world professional s social interactions. This can occur if the appearance code is simply a direct mapping of real life ideals of professionalism onto virtual world professionals, where the members of the community who are not there in a corporate capacity may have intentionally left these ideals out. We therefore hypothesize that an appearance code could have a negative effect on how virtual world professionals are received by members of the community. In addition to these concerns, we are also interested in how the malleability of avatar appearance may effect professional interactions in virtual worlds. 3. RELATED WORK The analysis of the motivations and mechanisms of avatar customization is a burgeoning area of study (e.g., [5] [11] [13] [16], [12]). While these mechanisms have been widely discussed within the context of a general user population, little work has been done to explore these mechanisms in the context of virtual world professionals. Interest in virtual world professionalism is a relatively new area of study. Issues concerning the logistics of moving operations into the virtual world [1] as well as issues surrounding employee avatar appearance have been identified (e.g., [7], [8]). The results of this study contribute to the body of literature by investigating whether or not virtual world professionals are subject to avatar appearance codes and what some of these policies entail. 4. RESEARCH QUESTIONS The concept of policies governing the appearance of employee avatars has been discussed within the literature, but do they even exist? In this study we hope to answer the following research questions: 1.) Have companies implemented appearance codes for virtual world professionals? 2.) If so, what are the details of some of these policies? 5. METHOD This work falls in the zone of similar studies conducted by Ducheneaut et al. [5] and Bessière et al. [2] in which members of the virtual community were asked to fill out an on-line questionnaire. Our questionnaire consisted of short-answer, two­alternative forced choice, and Likert-scale questions. The Likert­scale questions were based on a 7 point scale where a 7 indicated strong agreement with the statement or question and 1 indicated strong disagreement. The questionnaire was hosted on SurveyMonkey and was designed to gather data about the participants opinions regarding the importance of avatar appearance in virtual world professionalism. Specifically, we are interested in the role avatar appearance may play in maintaining business relationships in virtual worlds, and whether or not participants are subject to avatar appearance codes. 5.1 Participants There were 37 respondents in total. Participants were recruited in two steps: first, by invitation of two Second Life mailing lists: the Second Life Research Listserv and SL Educators. Then, a second criterion was applied: those who had employee avatars (i.e., they were deployed in-world by real-life organizations for the purpose of representing that organization in Second Life at the time of the survey). Those who met this criterion were invited to participate. It is important to note here that, although 37 participants is a relatively small number compared to other surveys of virtual world users (e.g., [5]), we feel as though it was ultimately our criteria for participation, as well as the relatively low number of virtual world professionals in Second Life, that resulted in such a low number of respondents. This may seem contradictory to statements made above regarding the prevalence of virtual worlds in these professional spheres, but we believe that this might simply be a reflection upon the current popularity of Second Life. The somewhat recent economic crisis could also have led many companies to discontinue services in virtual worlds as well. Therefore, while these numbers make it difficult to make conclusive statements about the trends noted in our results, they do, nevertheless, provide us some data upon which to facilitate discussion about avatar appearance codes and virtual world professionals. 5.2 Results and Discussion Questions 1 2 were included in order to obtain information about respondents accounts. In the first question participants were asked how long ago they first joined Second Life. The answer to this question varied greatly among participants, ranging from less than 6 months to 4+ years ago. Participants were then asked if they first joined Second Life for their company either at the company s request or as a volunteer. Of those surveyed, 27% first joined Second Life on behalf of their organization. Questions 3 7 dealt specifically with the effects constantly changing one s avatar s appearance may have on professional relationships in-world. Questions 8 12 were presented only to participants who are currently governed by an avatar appearance code. In question 3, participants were asked if strong business relationships in virtual worlds are dependent on familiar faces. For this question, 27.0% participants indicated a 6 on the Likert scale (mean = 4.05, SD = 1.93). In question 4, participants were asked if they feel disoriented at all if someone they interact with regularly in Second Life changes their avatar appearance frequently. Responses to question 4 were bi-modal, with 21.6% participants indicating 1 that they do not feel disoriented at and 21.6% indicating some degree of disorientation with a mode of 5 (mean = 3.54, SD = 1.92). Question 5 addressed whether or not an avatar appearance that accurately represents your physical appearance is important to professional interactions. This question was intended to investigate the aforementioned phenomenon noted in the work of Nowak et. al, in which the authors suggested that accurate representation in virtual worlds may be a mechanism that reduces uncertainty between users [12]. In the context of virtual worlds, accurate representation is an avatar that has been constructed to closely resemble the user who controls the avatar. For this question, 45.9% of participants indicated 1 that this is not at all an important factor in professional interactions (mean = 2.73, SD = 2.04). Those participants who felt as though accurate representation was important were presented with an optional, open-ended question. Specifically, they were asked if they felt as though a business relationship is negatively effected by disconnect between avatar appearance and real life appearance when interactions move from Second Life into real life. Subsequently, 13 participants responded to this question with 7 indicating that they felt the effect would not be significantly negative. The remaining responses were mixed, but indicated a possible negative effect, depending on the client s perception and the degree to which the bodies did not match. For example, one participant stated that, I do feel more continuity between on-line and off-line interaction when the avatars have a similar appearance to their typist. Another participant suggested, I think there could be a negative effect, but I feel that my freedom to look however I like in SL is something to stand up for. It is something I would not be willing to compromise for. So while the transition for some may be made easier by utilizing the powerful appearance editor to match real­life bodies, there seems to be a desire among others to utilize the power of the avatar appearance editor for expression, rather than facsimile. In the seventh question, participants were asked whether or not their company currently had a policy for avatar appearance in Second Life. Questions 8 12 were presented only to those participants who answered yes to this question. Of the 37 participants, 5 are deployed by organizations that currently use such a policy. 5.2.1 Companies with Appearance Codes Of the 5 participants who are subject to an avatar appearance code, 3 indicated that the avatar policy was implemented after the company had moved into Second Life. When asked if the policy addresses non-human avatars, all participants indicated yes, with 3 indicating that non-human avatars are allowed by the policy. It is interesting to note that none of the policies neglected to address the issue of non-human avatars. Since we expected the specifics of each policy to vary, the last three questions of our survey were open-ended questions. In question 10, participants were asked simply to describe the appearance code. Some participants stated that their company expected that representative avatars be human with professional or business-casual attire. Other participants stated that the policy only required that avatars be clothed and that representatives use common sense when making decisions regarding how their avatar looks and behaves within the virtual world. In question 11, participants were asked how much this policy has evolved over the course of its use. All participants indicated that the policy has remained substantively unchanged since its inception. In question 12 we asked participants whether or not they felt as though their company s policy is suitable for virtual world professionals deployed within Second Life. Responses to this question varied greatly. Two participants indicated agreement with the statement. Two participants suggested that the appearance codes were not very suitable for 3D virtual worlds, but understood that the policies had been implemented so as to avoid offending clientele. The remaining participant expressed a lack of personal interest in such policies, stating, I really don t care since I am not very fond of being an animal or any other being. I like to be myself in-world. 6. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK The fact that there are a few organizations implementing avatar appearance codes is very interesting. While the details of these policies vary, they do have something in common: a need for the existence of such a policy was identified by someone within the organization. The fact that none of these policies neglected to mention anthropomorphic avatars is also interesting and warrants further investigation. The results reported in this paper belong to a larger body of work which investigates the ways in which virtual world professionals use avatar appearance editors, and how the appearance of these avatars affects their interactions with the members of the virtual community. We feel as though the implications of this research are not limited to employee avatars researchers who intend to work directly with members of a virtual community may also be subject to the interloper effect. The next goal of this research is to further investigate the relationship between avatar appearance and professional interactions in Second Life. We plan to survey users of Second Life to determine if they have their own perceptions of professionalism in virtual worlds and to further investigate the interloper effect in this context. We hope that information gathered in these surveys can assist organizations in their development of avatar appearance codes for virtual worlds. 7. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS I would like to thank Dr. Melanie Baljko and Dr. Barry Joe for their input and feedback. This work is funded by the Social Science and Humanities Research Council of Canada. 8. article_rec.title: Exergames for adult users
article_rec.subtitle: a preliminary pilot study

abstract.par: This paper examines fitness videogames (exergames) and factors surrounding their adoption by novice users over 40, first through a literature review and then by discussing a pilot study. Digital games have been promoted as a way to reduce the barriers to embracing an ongoing exercise program. However, understanding the game's instructions also affects a novice player's gameplay experience. In the pilot study, reactions of novice players to two commercially available games with exertive interfaces were systematically analyzed so obstacles to communication between players and software could be identified. The social affordances of game design for adults over 40 are also discussed in order to develop protocols for a larger study analyzing how digital games can be used to sustain exercise adherence over time.

fulltext.ft_body: Exergames for Adult Users: A Preliminary Pilot Study Lorna R. Boschman Simon Fraser University School of Interactive Arts & Technology Surrey BC Canada lornab@sfu.ca ABSTRACT This paper examines fitness videogames (exergames) and factors surrounding their adoption by novice users over 40, first through a literature review and then by discussing a pilot study. Digital games have been promoted as a way to reduce the barriers to embracing an ongoing exercise program. However, understanding the game s instructions also affects a novice player s gameplay experience. In the pilot study, reactions of novice players to two commercially available games with exertive interfaces were systematically analyzed so obstacles to communication between players and software could be identified. The social affordances of game design for adults over 40 are also discussed in order to develop protocols for a larger study analyzing how digital games can be used to sustain exercise adherence over time. Categories and Subject Descriptors K 8.0 [General]: Games General Terms Performance, Design, Human Factors Keywords Exergames, fitness videogames, Wii Fit, Dance Dance Revolution, adult fitness, exertive interface and fitness program. 1. INTRODUCTION Contemporary sedentary lifestyles have been cited as a primary factor in a social situation of physical inactivity a majority of North American adults do not engage in fitness activities on a regular basis [7,9]. Although numerous studies have linked regular fitness activities to improved health benefits and national public health agencies have long prescribed more exercise, people are stubbornly resistant to changing their personal habits [9]. Public information campaigns that promote active daily living are not successful in social transformation because a lack of information is not the reason for exercise resistance. Perceived justifications for inactivity are well documented and include suggestions that individuals do not have enough free time to exercise and that exercise is not fun [9]. Digital fitness games offer players an opportunity to undertake lifestyle changes that may include exercise, healthier eating habits Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 and food choices, and strategies to control stressors. Games like Wii Fit can counter perceived barriers to fitness because they may be played in short bursts at the convenience of the user. Further, exergames offer a variety of fitness activities and often support social exchange, factors that can increase the commitment of players. Whitson et al. assert that game controllers with exertive interfaces are neo-immersive, support social engagement and build on embodied knowledge of exercise activities [14]. The popularity of videogames with children and adolescents has been well documented. Sedentary gameplay is frequently blamed for inactivity among young people, but resistance to exercise is based on multiple factors for adults as well as youth. A study comparing the exercise habits of women with and without children cited lack of time because of family obligations as the most significant factor for mothers, although both groups stated that work and other obligations were impediments to fitness [9]. Unfortunately, many people enthusiastically begin an exercise program but few embrace daily fitness activities as a lifelong practice because of perceived barriers, including the lack of an exercise partner [9]. In 2009, industry publications reported that the average age of a Canadian gamer was 35 years and that the most popular serious game was the Wii Fit [3]. The entertainment value of digital gaming has spread to adults, who are replacing traditional pastimes like television viewing with interactive alternatives. According to the Canadian Entertainment Software Association, almost half of adults 35-54 and a third of adults over 55 played a videogame in the past month. An important factor in continued videogame usage was the opportunity to socialize while gaming. Among adults, a third said that their first entertainment software purchase was an active game like Wii Fit or Dance Dance Revolution, indicating that this demographic is open to a digital exercise experience. In the next section, a discussion of the relationship between fitness games and social interaction will be presented. In the following section, exercise adherence strategies aimed at adults, including prototype fitness games designed to increase player engagement, will be reviewed. Finally, a pilot study of novice adult users of commercially available fitness games is discussed. 2. SOCIAL AFFORDANCES OF GAMES In a comprehensive review of the social factors that inhibit exercise, McElroy [9] describes the importance of community­supported fitness activities. She argues that individuals will increasingly engage in physical activity if they are reliant not only on their own self-efficacy, but are also supported through collective efficacy. If fitness is embraced as a social norm, then individual use of active games can become part of a fitness strategy that may also include a partner or group, social conditions that could increase emotional attachment to exercise activities. With respect to digital videogames, de Kort and IJsselsteijn [2] argue that the social interactions among players contribute significantly to the medium s popularity. Depending on the affordances of the game structure, both co-located and distributed online play offer opportunities for users to socialize with each other. Attention to players is also paid by the game itself through devices such as the voice-over commentary and audience vocalizations embedded in Konami s Dance Dance Revolution (DDR). When playing games like DDR with friends, the player becomes a performer, and the co-located individuals become an audience, a role that shifts depending on who is dancing on the sensor-laden mat that acts as an input device. A game like DDR becomes a spectacle where the play experience extends to include the audience, who might also be dancing without the mat, mimicking gameplay in order to share the excitement of performance. The concept of immersion in videogames is framed differently depending on the researchers interpretive model and the type of game under scrutiny. By studying how players characterized their experiences, Ermi and Mäyrä [4] developed a model that includes sensory, challenge-based, and imaginative immersion. Sweetser and Wyeth [12] characterized player enjoyment as GameFlow, a concept that includes immersion among its elements. They note that while social interaction is clearly part of game enjoyment, it is seen as disruptive to the flow experience in games. Whitson et al. [14] have characterized games with an exertive interface as neo-immersive. Neo-immersive games like DDR or Guitar Hero, and many games using the Wii console encourage social interaction during play, and work to disrupt the trance-like flow experience that some describe as being part of gameplay [14]. Neo-immersive games increase feelings of embodiment because the larger physical movements of players are reflected in feedback from the game [14]. Social aspects of the game are enhanced so that players feelings of belonging to the group and sharing a collective experience are highlighted [14]. In order to facilitate social support for exercise, Consolvo et al. [1] developed a mobile phone application Houston that allowed users to share their daily step count with friends. By using technology to encourage physical activity, the researchers hoped to contribute to the strategies that will overcome the global overweight and obesity epidemic [1, p. 458]. Step counts were shared between existing social networks of 4-5 women who wanted to increase their physical activity levels. Groups who shared their step counts were significantly more likely to reach their goal. Factors in exercise adherence included the social pressure to perform up to the expectations of peers and the support of other group members. Goals that were set too high tended to discourage participants because they seemed too hard to achieve; the researchers suggest that more work be done to understand the relationship between setting reasonable (achievable) daily goals and sustaining exercise activities over time [1]. Although the Houston study used a pedometer to count steps, not all physical activities can be quantified in this manner. In the next section, strategies to increase exercise adherence are discussed, followed by a review of studies that examine the use of videogames by adults over 40. 3. EXERCISE ADHERENCE STRATEGIES Although many studies have linked lack of exercise to an increased health risk, only recent work has examined the effect of videogames on exercise adherence. In a study involving college­aged males who initially exercised fewer than 120 minutes per week, Warburton et al. [13] compared a group who exercised on a conventional stationary bicycle with those who played a videogame connected to a stationary bike. Arguing that the largest decrease in exercise activities occurs immediately after attending high school, the team hypothesized that participants would prefer to exercise while gaming, and that increased adherence would result in a reduced risk for chronic illness associated with a sedentary lifestyle [13]. The group who incorporated gaming with exercise attended sessions close to 80% of the time, while the group who used traditional equipment attended less than half the time. The increased exercise adherence, along with an attendant drop in blood pressure and lower body mass index (BMI) readings for the gaming group, show that videogames provided a strong incentive to exercise for the young adult males in this study [13]. Before digital exergames were available, commercial interventions into the home fitness market included VHS distribution of exercise programs led by celebrities or trainers, home gym equipment, and printed instruction guides. Because of the health risks associated with a BMI over 25 kg/m, Jakicic et al. studied overweight women by looking at the effects of using home exercise equipment on weight loss and exercise adherence [7]. One group exercised in long bouts, one group exercised in short bouts and one group exercised in short bouts with home exercise equipment (a treadmill). Over an eighteen-month period, women who used home exercise equipment lost more weight because they exercised more often [7]. Individuals who exercised more than 200 minutes per week lost more weight than those who exercised from 150-200 minutes, while those who exercised less than 150 lost the least [7]. Women were trained to increase their level of exercise to 40 minutes per day/ five days per week as part of a medically supervised behavioral weight-loss program [7]. Exergames allow people to engage in short bursts of exercise, offering players an opportunity to exercise at times that are convenient while accumulating sufficient total minutes for fitness. When videogames are designed to encourage exercise with friends or with a social network, fun will increasingly become a component of the exercise experience. In the next section, prototype exergames designed to include social interaction are compared to illustrate two additional approaches. 3.1 Designing Games for Exercise Drawing on literature from the exercise motivation field, Yim and Graham [15] argued that exergames should incorporate significant features: music, instructions for novice players, realistic short and long-term goals, disguised fitness levels to counter low self­efficacy, and encouragement for players to form alliances with other users (fitness partners or teams). The authors developed a computer-aided fitness game, Life is a Village, using the PlayStation2 platform connected wirelessly to a stationary bicycle. The game allowed players to work cooperatively to construct a village [15]. Another approach acknowledges the importance of social relationships while gaming, using a core mechanic of table tennis to connect players who are distributed geographically. Mueller et al. [10] designed Table Tennis for Three to enhance social activity while playing through an exertive interface. The authors assert that an exertive interface (one that requires players to exert physical effort) can promote greater social interaction than a traditional keyboard and mouse interface due to the shared physical experience [10]. In a situation similar to live competitive sports, an emotional response to other players developed while playing virtual table tennis together. By providing a method for players to communicate verbally as well as playing physical matches, the game facilitated social exchange among geographically distributed users [10]. Although the strategies previously mentioned built affordances into their prototypes by supporting physical exertion, building relationships among players, and facilitating social networking, these approaches have not been analyzed for use by adults over 40, an emerging group of gamers who have different design requirements than a younger audience. In the next section, several papers that look at the requirements of older gamers are examined. 3.2 Gaming for Adults Over 40 A groundbreaking study of 300 gamers from the Baby Boom generation conducted by Pearce [11] noted that 98% of the participants played online games on a PC, not on a console. Console play was deemed appropriate for teens, although one participant admitted that he played DDR with his children [11]. At the time of Pearce s study, the multi-generational Wii console was not yet released. Fitness games were not mentioned as favorites by any of the participants in her 2006 study. A study of postmenopausal women looked at exercise interventions using video dance games because this demographic has an increased health risk associated with sedentary behavior [6]. Dance is a form of exercise that has relatively high levels of adherence for older women, and helps to increase strength, coordination and balance, as well as being associated with weight loss [6]. After a session with video dancing, women held small group discussions about the advantages and disadvantages of this form of exercise. All groups agreed that video dancing was fun and improved their coordination, but some worried that learning to play was frustrating and that purchasing the equipment was too expensive [6]. For adult players who have a console in their home because other family members own it, the expense would be limited to the cost of the software title and dance mat. In addition to addressing usability issues related to physical and cognitive changes in elderly users, IJsselsteijn et al. [5] call on game designers to create games that are interesting to this population. While the number of gamers over 65 is growing as the general population ages, commercially available digital titles are limited primarily to games designed for younger players [5]. As well, some adults over 65 are retiring having never used a computer at work. Because of inexperience or lack of training, these users approach learning digital games differently from the trial and error approach favored by many younger players. Inexperienced users are more inclined to worry that they will break the game by pressing the wrong button and have a greater tendency to consult a manual than younger players. The authors [5] suggest that individuals who are beginning to use digital entertainment after retirement be given adequate training and be actively supported while they learn to participate. When playing socially, the benefits for elder players include expanding social networks, in much the same way that non-digital games like cards have traditionally brought individuals together for entertainment. Because videogames have traditionally been marketed to younger users, use of these games by adults over 40 has not been studied in depth. The sedentary lifestyle of adults who exercise infrequently contributes to an increased risk of chronic and acute illness, making them an important demographic to study. If designers can understand the conditions under which adults will use exergames, games with an exertive interface can be used to help persuade adults to exercise more, controlling or preventing the effects of chronic conditions like cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes (in conjunction with other healthcare strategies). 4. INTRODUCING GAMES TO ADULTS 4.1 Research Methodology The author of this paper has a background as a video director and editor, and is investigating how practices from those fields can contribute to videogame research. Through systematic analysis of video recordings of participants, participant exit interviews, and researcher field notes, the conditions under which adults over 40 played exergames were comprehensively reviewed. The current pilot study builds on previous work by Knoblauch, [8] who describes his approach to interpretive video data analysis as videography, a method that focuses ethnographically on a situation using video recordings to support a sequential microanalysis. He states that video documentation is best interpreted in conjunction with other data sources like interviews, written materials or participant observation [8]. While traditional ethnography looks at larger social exchanges occurring over a longer period of time, video analysis examines specific interactions (like adults playing exergames) using digital data that often requires lengthy data processing. The videography method has been adapted here to take advantage of the sequential and temporal qualities of video recordings and digital games, characteristics that support structured audiovisual analysis. 4.2 Research Methods & Data Sources A group of six adults agreed to participate in a sixty minute fitness videogame session, affirmed that they had no medical reason to avoid exercise, and signed a release form in accordance with ethical research policies of Simon Fraser University. The research sessions were conducted in the common room of an apartment building where many of the participants reside. While one camera recorded the movements of players, the other camera recorded an audiovisual output from the game console. Both images were synchronized using the video editing software Final Cut Pro. A total of 12 hours of footage was analyzed in the pilot in order to develop protocols for a larger mixed methods study. During the pilot study, players self-selected Wii Fit exercises for 20 minutes and then played and compared two specific games. Subsequently, participants danced to a specific DDR song (three times in Game Mode and three times in Training Mode) so that their response to visual display distracters could be compared. Following their workout, players were briefly interviewed. The videography method was used as a guide to interpret videotaped footage of adults playing exergames as a fitness activity. Video recordings of the kinetic and verbal responses of players to the games were synchronized after the research session to recordings of the gameplay instructions as they appeared to participants. This reconfiguration enabled the researcher to match the game s instructions with user performance, and to compare each instance of gameplay with subsequent attempts in order to observe patterns of play response. In addition to an exit interview, the researcher s observations were informed by videotaped social interactions that took place between formal gaming sessions, and the recombined audiovisual gameplay recordings. 4.3 Discussion The scope of the pilot study was limited to a small number of participants in order to develop analytic methods with a smaller data set. Qualitative data was used to inform potential standards of measurement. Players mentioned enjoying games when their scores were higher, and disliked games that they failed. Game scores in the six attempts at a DDR song were used to determine whether background distracters in the screen display made a difference to the score (an indication that players can follow and respond to game instructions). While first time players scored better in the simpler interface of the Training Mode, the absence of game-ending failure indicators may also have affected their slightly higher scores in this mode. Although first time players stated that they didn t see the visual distracters in the monitor display, more experienced novices stated that they saw the background images but ignored them, suggesting that game familiarity may lead to a more relaxed visual response. Older players mentioned that the display monitor was too small for their visual comfort, an important future consideration. The novice player with the highest DDR score watched the participant before her receive instructions. She also practiced steps while the other participant worked on the dance mat. During her study session, the most successful novice asked for further instructions from the researcher between each attempt at the song. If self-efficacy means taking actions with an expectation of meaningful results, then this participant modeled efficacious behavior. 5. FUTURE WORK Although the pilot study included only a small number of adults, the need for substantive instructions and encouragement for videogame novices was strongly suggested. Potential metrics within a larger study of adults using exergames as part of a program of physical activity include examining changes over time to: BMI and weight measurements, standardized survey measuring self-efficacy, and self-reported minutes per week of exercise. Future work will compare the impact of self-efficacy and collective efficacy on exercise adherence in adults using exergames and will examine how social support for exergame use can increase an individual s overall fitness activities. Research procedures for collecting and interpreting video data in combination with participant interviews and field observation have been demonstrated in a small study. The procedures can now be used to build protocols for a larger study of adults over 40, a group whose levels of physical inactivity place them at greater risk for chronic illness. 6. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS Thanks to Lyn Bartram (SFU, SIAT) for facilitating the pilot study, and to Tom Calvert (SFU, SIAT) and Suzanne de Castell (SFU, Education) for reviewing this paper. 7.
