fulltext.ft_body: A Framework for the Online Evaluation of Serious Games Velian T. Pandeliev Tech. for Aging Gracefully Lab (TAGLab) University of Toronto 40 St. George Street #7230 Toronto, ON, Canada vpandeli@cs.utoronto.ca ABSTRACT The number of serious games designed to improve abilities such as cognition, physical fitness, or language proficiency is growing faster than scientific validation of claims being made by the vendors of such games. This is partly because validation is a costly and difficult process typically relying upon in-person experimental protocols. We propose an alternative a framework for conducting validation studies online and present the motivation, core principles and challenges in building such a system. Categories and Subject Descriptors J.4 [Social and Behavioural Sciences]: Psychology research methods, online experimentation, validation. General Terms Measurement, Experimentation, Human Factors, Verification Keywords Serious games, mental fitness, experimental protocols 1. INTRODUCTION Over the last ten years, the gaming industry has evolved to appeal to a wider and wider demographic. Today s gamers are male and female, young and old. Video games are becoming a common mainstream pastime. This is partly due to the proliferation of the serious games genre, which offers games that are not primarily geared towards entertainment, but have other aims such as education, physical fitness and improving and retaining mental capabilities. When such games are accompanied by a claim of a positive outcome of some sort (e.g., improved memory, better social skills, or mastery of a language), scientific validation of such claims is necessary. We propose in this paper a framework for conducting validation studies online and outline the motivation, core principles, and challenges in evaluating such studies. Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 Ronald M. Baecker Tech. for Aging Gracefully Lab (TAGLab) University of Toronto 40 St. George Street #7228 Toronto, ON, Canada rmb@kmdi.utoronto.ca 2. SERIOUS GAMES When we are faced with the desire to improve ourselves or gain a new skill, there is a great range of products available at our disposal including memory and speed-reading books, fitness classes, language training software, and self-learners on topics ranging from deck building to muffin making. It is interesting to note that very few of these products have been marketed to the general public in game form. However, with the proliferation of increasingly agile gaming technology, and the growing interest from a generation that has grown up playing video games, the mainstream consumer market is beginning to adapt and give rise to the field of serious games . The definition of 'serious game' is fluid and encompasses any game that does not have entertainment as its sole or primary purpose [13]. This includes games created by the military for tactical or training simulations, persuasive or advertising games, disaster response games, educational games for children, language learning games, online worlds like Second Life, exercise regimens such as Wii Fit, and a growing number of mental fitness games. Mental fitness refers to the concept that cognitive abilities such as memory, planning and visuo-spatial awareness can be improved the same way physical abilities can through the use of active training regimens [2]. Nintendo s BrainAge is perhaps the most widely-known mental fitness game, and it includes memory, numeracy and reasoning trainers . This sector of the serious gaming industry alone was valued at 265 million dollars in 2008, and that number is expected to grow to 1-5 billion by 2015 [17]. As the number of serious games available to the public grows, and the customer is faced with deciding which one to choose, a crucial factor that can set successful games apart from unsuccessful ones will be scientific validation the ability to make and substantiate claims about the beneficial outcomes of such games. This is especially important in the mental fitness field, but it applies to any game that aims for something other than entertainment. Nintendo s Wii Fit program is an example of an immensely popular serious game that has significant anecdotal evidence of success (for example, [10]) and yet lacks sufficient scientific validation. The game was marketed as offering an alternative and enjoyable way to exercise. However, when its benefits were independently verified by the American Council on Exercise, it was determined that while Wii Fit activities improve physical fitness more than playing sedentary video games, they do not provide the same intensity as other forms of exercise, and therefore offer limited health benefits [5]. Furthermore, some evidence has surfaced of stress injuries caused by the Wii Fit program [7]. Evidently, even games as popular as Wii Fit could use more rigorous validation. 3. METHODS OF SCIENTIFIC VALIDATION OF SERIOUS GAMES 3.1 Traditional Methods of Validation The concept of validation is fairly new to the gaming industry. Traditionally, games have not had to substantiate scientific claims to sell well. But this is changing for the domain of serious games. For example, in the mental fitness field alone, a simple Internet search yields dozens of products that make claims to improve cognitive status. Figure 1 shows excerpts from some typical advertisements. Figure 1: Examples of brain training claims Mental fitness games would greatly benefit from being able to make claims to objectively improve mental faculties, but only if such claims were validated using research methods known from experimental psychology. However, with a few exceptions such as appear in [11] and [14], most such claims have not been scientifically validated. While well-established and valid, most cognitive experimental protocols require a controlled setting and the presence of an experimenter to guide the participant through the experiment. Such face-to-face studies are costly and difficult to arrange and conduct. For instance, a recent ACTIVE study [20] which used cognitive training to treat depression involved ten in-person one­hour sessions with over 2000 participants aged 65 and over. Participants completed the interventions in groups of 3-4, but even so the study required over 5000 hours with a highly trained and certified experimenter present. This incurred a huge cost in rented space, staff training, working hours and participant travel. Similarly, in an as-yet unpublished study involving an attention and goal-switching game called Space Fortress[15], 40 elderly participants commuted to Columbia University, sometimes for up to two hours a day each way, to participate in a one-hour lab session. They did this three times a week for 12 weeks, spending up to 144 hours in transit for a 36-hour intervention. 3.2 Online Experimentation A plausible alternative to in-person testing is online experimentation. The ability to conduct a study entirely online, taking participants from recruitment through intervention to debriefing in the comfort of their own homes, without having to worry about their geographic location or willingness to travel, would be very helpful in alleviating some of the issues outlined above. If successful, the benefits of such an approach could include lower cost, larger and more diverse sample sizes, and a degree of ecological validity (most of these mental fitness regimens are deployed online, so it is beneficial to evaluate their effectiveness online). However, the well-established cognitive experimental protocols that would lend validity to an in-person study do not have equivalents in the virtual world. In order for online experimentation to be possible, a robust and well-validated protocol for conducting online studies is urgently needed. Several companies such as CambridgeBrainSciences [4] and Lumosity [11] have made strides towards online assessment and experimentation for mental fitness, while Bolt|Peters [3] has conducted innovative research on game testing and surmounted some of the pitfalls of in-person assessment. For example, a recent online study by the MRC Cognitive and Brain Sciences Unit [12] found no transfer of benefits gained by training on a set of mental fitness tasks to other, untrained tasks. The results of the study were immediately questioned [9] on account of potential design issues such as the duration of the intervention and possible confounding factors due to the online nature of the study. This illustrates the importance of enabling such research to be conducted soundly, cost-effectively, and transparently. We are therefore investigating the entire process of online experimentation. We are creating a framework that builds on previous work and systematically explores the challenges involved in online participant studies. This paper describes these challenges and outlines plans to address them. 4. OUR APPROACH We are designing and implementing an online validation portal, which shall be used to conduct a pilot study that will compare several commercially available mental fitness games with a few well-established standard board games and an active control. The aim of the study will not be to rigorously assess the effectiveness of these interventions in improving mental abilities, but rather to provide sufficient evidence that we have identified and addressed the key issues of conducting such experiments online. We discuss these issues in depth below. 4.1 Recruitment, Screening and Identity Finding participants in a chosen demographic and ensuring they are suitable for the study is a challenge for any scientist. The Internet can be a valuable tool in tackling this issue social networking and electronic word of mouth could free recruitment from the burden of geographic proximity. Although biases do exist when recruiting seniors, they are expected to decrease in future years as Internet use by seniors is constantly growing. Once a sample of participants has been gathered, they would need to undergo a screening process, where individuals with confounding medical conditions or those not in the chosen demographic are excluded. We intend to use a version of the Telephone Interview for Cognitive Status cognitive screening questionnaire [6] and adapt it to be administered over a desktop video conferencing platform. This technique would also serve to help verify the participants identity, tackling the issue of the inherent anonymity and potential deceptiveness of an online presence. 4.2 Ethics, Consent and Privacy With experimental mental fitness interventions, there can be a small measure of risk to the participant s cognitive health. An example of this is the recent recall of Baby Einstein DVDs by the Disney Corporation in response to a 2007 study showing evidence of media viewing having potentially detrimental effects on the cognitive development of toddlers [21]. Obtaining informed consent online and ensuring that a study is ethically sound is a crucial step. Techniques to ensure that the participant is informed of the risks of the study could include a videoconference or phone briefing, or a wizard-like step-by-step informed consent document with a quiz at the end. The advantage to the first approach is that it allows participants to ask questions as they arise and the experimenter has a chance to respond. Just as important as ethics is the issue of data security and privacy. Care must be taken with sensitive participant information and data it should be safeguarded using a combination of methods, including offline storage, encryption and disassociating data from participant identities. 4.3 Intervention, Assessment and Instrumentation How will participants actually play these games, and which games will they play? Deciding on the different conditions to be investigated and the choice of a control (baseline) condition depend on the goals of the study. More importantly, games deployed for experimental purposes must be thoroughly and unobtrusively instrumented to record participants performance and interactions, and an easy way for them to provide feedback as they encounter issues must be included. We envision a one-click feedback box where participants can type comments that are logged along with the state of the game at that moment. Initially, we intend to use the GameSoup game development environment [16] to generate traditional board games. We also plan to obtain two commercial mental fitness games from a collaborating vendor. One significant challenge we are not tackling immediately is to be able to monitor participant performance on particular games without having access to the source code of the games themselves. To measure improvement after playing these games, a suitable and well-validated online neurocognitive battery must be utilized to measure the desired cognitive skills (such as memory, planning, or visuo-spatial reasoning). This battery would be administered before and after the study period, and changes in performance would be analyzed to measure improvement due to the intervention. We are currently seeking partners to collaborate on the creation of an appropriate battery. 4.4 Monitoring Confounding Activities Due to the nature of the study, care must be taken to identify and account for confounding factors. To have confidence in one s findings, one should keep track of any other activities that participants may engage in during the study period that may influence the results of the study. These would include both online and offline activities. When monitoring online activities, we have the advantage of using pre-existing technology for unobtrusive monitoring. Naturally, this raises further privacy concerns. The participant should be informed of the type of information being logged about his or her online or local computer-based activity. Monitoring offline activity is much more challenging, as it would rely on self-reports, day reconstructions or questionnaires all methods that are participant-dependent and that have known drawbacks and inaccuracies. However, based on experience in prior research projects, we know that we can improve the data collection process by making use of mobile devices and online reporting mechanisms. 4.5 Incentives and Feedback A crucial component of mental fitness games, as well as many other serious games, is entertainment. Enjoyment is a significant factor and it can make or break the success of a game. If an intervention is enjoyable, if it is played rather than worked at, there is a much higher chance that it will be used for a longer period of time, and there will be a higher chance of the user seeing its benefits. A crucial step, therefore, to generating and retaining a user base, is to make these games fun and engaging. However, that may prove to be insufficient in the verification stage. The casual user is under no obligation to play a game for any significant length of time, but a study like the one we are proposing requires a minimal amount of participation, which makes motivating users to commit to it a difficult task. While many studies involve only a few sessions and take a short amount of time to complete, the interventions we are testing will require a significant commitment over several months. Convincing people to participate, and, more importantly, motivating them to continue participating until the study is done, are key challenges. In a recent study, American insurance company AllState offered a PC-based driving training program to a sample of its clients. Only half of the people who signed up and installed the software finished the study [19]. We have encountered evidence [18] that we can minimize participant attrition by utilizing one of the strengths of in-person research: we will schedule regular (perhaps bi-weekly) live sessions with participants to ask them about their progress. We hope that this technique will improve participation rates by making users accountable to a real person, and will also assure them that their contribution is valuable and that the experimenter is interested in their progress. It is of value to the experimenter as well, as it allows her to gauge the level of participant motivation and respond to questions that may have arisen in the preceding two weeks. Furthermore, the online nature of these studies creates opportunities for new participant reward and appreciation mechanisms. An economics study conducted in 2006 [1] reaffirmed the motivating potential of commitment contracts and led to the creation of stickK.com, a website where individuals can set goals, stake money or reputation on meeting those goals, and nominate a referee to track their progress. If they fail to meet their goals, their stake goes to a predetermined recipient, such as an individual or group they do not wish to support. This approach has been shown to motivate participants to achieve their goals more than goal-setting alone, and we believe it can be modified to help provide the incentive necessary to complete interventions online. 4.6 Persistence of Effects Although a particular mental fitness intervention may provide temporary improvements immediately after the study period, these improvements could be due to training effects and they could fade when the training stopped. It is necessary to test whether these interventions improve cognition in a lasting, stable and task­independent way. This is accomplished by conducting follow-up assessments some time after the end of the study, and measuring how well the improvements have been retained over the period of inactivity. Another study from the ACTIVE clinical trial [8] is a great example of long-term follow up they conducted a follow­up assessment five years after the initial intervention. However, for most studies the follow-up period is typically no more than three months. We believe this is insufficient to properly determine the long-term effects of interventions, and that follow-up assessments should be conducted several years after the end of the study. This involves storing participant data longer, and introduces further motivation challenges. The benefits, however, are significant games that can claim transferrable, lasting improvements would have a clear market advantage. 5. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS While we have outlined a framework that aims to solve the issue of validation specifically for games for mental fitness field, the issues outlined above are universal and domain-independent. Hence research on other kinds of serious games can also benefit from this work. Work on implementing the framework has begun, and we aim to complete a pilot study by the end of 2010. With this framework, we hope to seed and spur the development of rigorous online experimentation, and to make it a trusted, useful, and inexpensive alternative for conducting scientific research on the benefits of serious games. 6. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS The authors would like to acknowledge the contributions of Yaakov Stern, Ph.D., Professor of Clinical Neuropsychology at Columbia University s Taub Institute, and Joshua R. Steinerman, M.D., Assistant Professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. We also extend thanks to everyone who contributed ideas and expertise, mainly David Smith, Kevin Tonon and Khai Truong, Ph.D, and to NSERC for their financial support. 7. fulltext.ft_body: PiNiZoRo: A GPS-based Exercise Game for Families Kevin G. Stanley, Ian Livingston, Alan Bandurka, Robert Kapiszka, Regan L. Mandryk Dept. of Computer Science University of Saskatchewan Saskatoon, SK {first.last}@usask.ca ABSTRACT Obesity is a growing problem among children, due in part to their sedentary lifestyles. Time spent engaged in physical activity is decreasing, while time spent playing computer and video games is on the rise. We leverage children s interest in digital games to encourage families to engage in purposeful walking. We present a GPS-based game, played on a mobile device that uses walking as a primary gameplay mechanic. Our game, PiNiZoRo, includes a fighting game, triggered at points along a real-world route, and a map editor that allows parents and recreation specialists to create custom routes in their neighbourhoods. Results from an initial focus group with parents were positive, as they showed enthusiasm for the concept, implementation, and gameplay. Categories and Subject Descriptors H.5.1 [Information Systems]: Information Interfaces and Presentation multimedia information systems. General Terms Design, Experimentation, Human Factors. Keywords Exercise games, ubiquitous games, GPS, children, families, persuasive games, location-based games. 1. INTRODUCTION Among children, obesity is a growing problem with far reaching consequences to their future health and wellness. Data from the Canadian Population Health Initiative reveal that from 1981 to 1996, overweight and obesity rates tripled among boys aged 7-13 (to 32.6%) and doubled among girls aged 7-13 (to 26.6%), with the greatest increases occurring in the youngest age groups (7-9 year olds) [13]. One explanation for the rise in the prevalence of overweight and obese children is the accompanying decrease in their physical activity levels in the same time frame [13]. The recent decrease in physical activity has been linked to various environmental, social, cultural, and behavioural factors including the increased time spent in sedentary leisure activities such as watching television and playing video games. A 2003 study showed an increased risk of being overweight or obese among 7- Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 11 year olds who watch television or play video games [15]. Given that 68% of American households play video or computer games [5], the negative potential impact of digital game play on physical activity levels and resulting obesity levels is clear. Parents have enormous influence over the lifestyles of their children. An accelerometer-based study revealed that children of physically-active mothers are twice as likely to be active, children of physically-active fathers are 3.5 times as likely to be active, and children are 5.8 times as likely to be active if both parents are physically active [12]. Although parents may be concerned about the sedentary lifestyle of their children, recent data from the Entertainment Software Association show that 63% of parents believe that games are a positive part of their children s lives [5]. Our research investigates the use of video game play to motivate physical activities in families. Our solution for parents is a two­pronged approach: first, we integrate video game play into physical activity experiences to draw electronic-age children into being active; second, we design a game where parents exercise together with their children. The video game approach provides parents with a way to engage their children by offering a fun activity that doubles as a mechanism for exercise, promoting healthy habits among the entire family. Our game called PiNiZoRo is a GPS-based exercise game, played on a mobile phone, which uses walking in the real world as a primary gameplay mechanic. Targeted at children aged 4-12, our game includes a fighting minigame, triggered at certain points in the route, which provides a deeper level of play experience to ensure children remain engaged. Finally, the game is designed to allow parents, educators, and recreation specialists to create custom routes in their neighbourhoods. We tested our game through a pilot study focus group performed with four adult participants, each a parent of a child in our target age group. Participants played the game, and participated in an interview discussing their experience with PiNiZoRo as a potential family activity. Initial results showed that the game has promise, although additional evaluation is still required. 2. RELATED WORK Ubiquitous games have received significant attention in the literature, as have persuasive games aimed at increasing activity. Our particular contribution lies at an intersection between persistent location-based ubiquitous games, and persuasive physical activity or exergames. One popular class of ubigames is games that respond to a player s location [2]. Persistent location-based games (PLBGs) are distinct from standard ubiquitous games in that locations are tagged with game play elements in perpetuity, which does not expire when a play session or event ends [1]. Coulton et al. describe two simple persistent location based games: MobSpray, a grafitti game and MobHunt, a treasure hunt in [4]. Li et al. describe a pervasive version of the game Monopoly, where a subdivision is given a new set of property values which players can buy, sell or rent as they walk about the neighbourhood, using traditional Monopoly mechanics [8]. A more general overview of location-based games is given in [7], and ubiquitous games in [10]. Persuasive games are intended to alter people s behaviors in healthy ways through gameplay. Recently, games intended to increase physical activity have been created and evaluated. Fish n Steps is a social computer game that links a player s daily foot step count to the growth and activity of an animated virtual fish, creating competition and collaboration [9]. In Neat-o-games players activity is monitored through an accelerometer and controls an avatar in a virtual race [6]. In the Ubifit Garden players physical activity improves their virtual garden, showing their progress on a glanceable display [3]. In Gemini, players cumulative activity affected their levels in a collaborative chess game played later on a PC [14]. Many pervasive games use a variant of hide and seek or tag as their fundamental play element. Magielse and Markopolous [11], and Vogiazou et al. [16] have both proposed tag-based opportunistic games. Magielse and Markopolous focused their game on children. 3. PINIZORO PiNiZoRo is a location-based game built to encourage families to exercise and explore the outdoors together, by providing additional digitally-mediated play to traditional outings. In the following sections, we describe the game concept, design, and how to edit game maps to create local PiNiZoRo experiences. 3.1 Game Concept PiNiZoRo is based on a fanciful and family-friendly concept of an ancient shadow conflict between pirates, zombies, ninjas and robots (PiNiZoRo), or according to our game documentation: The secret underworld of pirates, ninjas, robots, and zombies has been hidden from society for hundreds of years. Their epic struggle has been but a whisper on the tongues of bards and madmen. No normal person would have any reason to believe that these creatures of myth even exist. But they do exist... and their violent and terrible war, the Hidden War, is poised to spill into our world, wreaking havoc on society and the world as we know it! There is one group of mortal men and women who have dedicated their lives to keeping this war hidden from the world. They are the Letalis Vis or simply The Society. However, with the escalation of the Hidden War, the Society has grown weaker, decentralized, and leaderless. Operatives now work independently, documenting their work with detailed maps and notes, in hopes that others will join and take up the mantra: "nos es Letalis Vis Congregatio ", or "We are the Mortal Force Society". Players, expected to be children between 4 and 12 years old, are cast as members of a secret and elite police force tasked with subduing the pirates, zombies, ninjas and robots that have infiltrated their neighborhood. To find and combat these infiltrators, players must follow maps left by others describing a beat known to house illegitimate members of the pirate-zombie or ninja-robot alliances. Players are not alone in their quest. A misfit pirate, ninja, zombie and robot aid the player engaging in the actual combat required to subdue the miscreants found along the path. There are two core gameplay mechanics, a navigation game based on moving through the real world, and a fighting minigame. The game is expected to be played by children; however, there is also a relatively simple map editor, which allows parents, educators and recreation specialists to create the maps for the children to follow. While the ability to share maps through the internet has been implemented, it was not enabled in our early pilot studies. 3.2 Game Play Module The play portion of the game is divided into two primary mechanics, following a treasure map-like representation by walking in the real world, and a puzzle-fighting minigame where players attempt to subdue the creatures they have found. Example screens from each play portion are shown in Figure 1. In the navigation portion of the game, the player is represented by a blue triangle and must move from waypoint to waypoint, represented by pirate-style X s. X s can indicate either waypoints, changes in the direction of the path, or encounters, where players must play a minigame. While the PiNiZoRo concept allows for many minigames, we have currently only implemented a simple fighting game. To enhance the ambiance, music plays as the player approaches the next encounter waypoint. The fighting minigame is triggered when the player reaches an encounter point. To subdue the infiltrators found on the map, the player must employ the services of four defectors, one from each of the factions: Nina the Ninja, Bob the Robot, Zoe the Zombie and Pete the Pirate. The fighting game is a timing and puzzle game. Each of the four allies has three possible actions they can perform, associated with a puzzle piece shape. Actions with compatible puzzle-pieces can stack together for combo bonuses. Both player and computer actions stack in the same queue. Unalike puzzle pieces cancel and like puzzle pieces stack together. The queue is flushed if either 5 stacked pieces are placed, or a special border piece is played. Every action is executed, but the player with the last action in the queue receives the combo bonuses. The fighting game ends when either the infiltrator or player runs out of health. 3.3 Map Editor Module The editor is designed to make it easy to build a quest regardless of expertise with mobile technologies. It is accessible for educators, parents and activity coordinators to design maps in their neighborhoods for children. In addition, children could design maps for their friends. Map creation is accomplished by actually walking the desired path. The main quest edit page and primary map editing view are shown in Figure 2. Walking the desired path has two benefits. First, it allows the user to observe the area from ground level, rather than from a potentially misleading or outdated satellite view. Second, the device has the opportunity to record not only the position of the user, but the local errors in GPS position estimates. Selecting the add encounter command will take the user to a set of cascading tables, typical of the Apple iPhone interface, which allows the user to place the enemy and edit its difficulty and statistics. 4. PILOT STUDY To test PiNiZoRo s potential we recruited four participants (parents of children 5-10, 3 male, 1 female), for a pilot focus group study. Prior to performing any experimental task, participants received verbal instructions about the game and the experimental tasks. Participants were then provided with an iPhone running PiNiZoRo. An experimenter remained with the participant throughout the tasks to ensure that tasks were completed consistently between users. Participants performed two tasks: play a pre-made PiNiZoRo beat-map on the university campus, and use the map editor to create a new custom map. After the tasks were complete participants participated in a short (15 minute) interview, designed to explore their experience with and opinion of PiNiZoRo, and the role of games and exercise in their daily lives. All participants felt that exercise is important for their children. Walking was listed as a common activity that participants do with their children, though often with a specific goal in mind, like walking to the store. As such all participants felt that a game incorporated walking as a mechanism of interaction could be successful. One participant suggested that other potential physical activities are too complex: Coordinating all 4 of us to do the same activity is hard, but walking or bike riding is certainly feasible. Participants also felt that the iPhone is a good platform for family games. The use of GPS as a game mechanic is also viewed as novel and fun one participant said: It makes the real world interactive as apposed to something that s just there. Two participants compared the use of GPS to geo-caching, citing it as an example of the success of GPS in games. Participants expressed the value of using a game as a motivational tool. Sometimes you do stuff like make a game along the way, they get tired along the way, of course, they get tired so it s better if they are distracted It gives purpose to walking, which might be good for kids: It makes it feel like an adventure in a sense. Participants felt that the activities offered by PiNiZoRo would function well as an exercise game for children and parents. The achievement of reaching a waypoint or winning a battle was considered to be the most satisfying part of the game. I kind of liked the anticipation of wondering what s going to happen at the next waypoint. However, participants agreed that additional minigames would be required to engage children in the long-term. Three participants felt that the minigames would not be required to engage younger children that the traveling from waypoint to waypoint would be sufficient. However, the same participants also felt that the traveling would be insufficient for older children, thus more minigames would be required. Compared to typical exercise games I like the idea that it s outside, and that you can go for a walk, and that it s in the real world, and that it s something that you can do as a family and that it s not so consuming like a normal video game would be where all your focus is paid to the video games itself, here you can [go] in and out of the video game as you need too, which is nice. One participant enjoyed how well the physical activity was integrated into the gameplay, saying: I think the exercise is really well hidden, and I can see kids just tearing around from location to location trying to get to the next minigame. All participants felt that the map editor was an important part of the game, although some participants wanted to build maps from home, rather than walk the map before playing the game. I liked kind of creating my own map, that was kind of neat to be creative and give them names, you know, and think how my own story would go. Overall, participants were enthusiastic about PiNiZoRo s potential. The differences the game offers over traditional exercise games, the activities, and that it is played outdoors made our game very appealing. 5. DISCUSSION AND FUTURE WORK PiNiZoRo is unique because of the balance of goals and objectives it represents. Exergames suffer a design challenge in that exercise is not always considered to be an inherently fun activity. Many sports have exercise as a byproduct of the activity rather than the goal; similarly, PiNiZoRo has walking as a byproduct of enjoyable gameplay. Walking is integral to the gameplay, but is made more fun through the scenario, the hunt for waypoints, and the triggered minigames. Many families already walk together, and parents often create adventures for their children on these walks using tools like identifying flora and fauna, or playing games like I spy with my little eye. Our game may appeal to these families, but we are targeting families who may need more motivation to go for a walk together. Some children may respond better to the motivation of the digital aspects of game play, and some parents may be pushed to go on these adventures by their children. We hope that a game such as PiNiZoRo could be a scaffold for families to learn to enjoy physical activity-based outings without the need for accompanying digital media. Parents in our pilot focus group appreciated our game for its use of digital technology to support purposeful walking. The design of our map editor constantly renews this purpose as new routes can be created users. In this way, PiNiZoRo supports leveling as more challenging routes can be created and played. To create a new quest, our implementation requires users to walk a route. Although we implemented a map editor that could be used from a stationary point (like a parent s home), we require users to walk their routes so that quests are reliable. There are two main advantages to walking the route: the GPS records not only the position, but the reliability of that position based on the surrounding environment; and it allows the creator to observe the area from ground level, rather than from a potentially outdated satellite view. Our current implementation appeals to children who like twitch­based games, because the only minigame we have implemented is a puzzle-fighter. To accommodate children with different play styles, we are currently implementing a clue-gathering minigame. We plan to create additional minigames to make the game more appealing for older children and for long-term play. In addition, we plan to conduct initial tests with children and large-scale tests with families and schools. 6. CONCLUSIONS Obesity rates are rising among children, due in part to their sedentary lifestyles. Time spent engaged in physical activity is decreasing, while time spent playing computer and video games is on the rise. We have created a GPS-based game, played on a mobile device that uses walking as a primary gameplay mechanic. Parents can support purposeful walking in their families by creating custom quests for their kids in their own neighbourhoods. In a pilot focus group, parents showed enthusiasm for the concept, implementation, and gameplay. 7. abstract.par: This paper studies narrative embedding in games, a phenomenon that has rarely been discussed in game studies. To understand the issues better, this work first seeks insights into embedding from narrative theory and sets up a descriptive framework that includes a categorization of horizontal, vertical and modal embedding, as well as their associated characteristics. The paper then applies the framework to game narratives and examines how narrative embedding is implemented in games, how it helps structure the narrative content, and how it influences the narrative experience. By relating theoretical discussions to game examples, the findings of this study can potentially help game narrative designers make more informed decisions when embedding narrative in games.

fulltext.ft_body: Embedded Narrative in Game Design Huaxin Wei Simon Fraser University 250 13450 102 Avenue Surrey, B.C., V3T 0A3, Canada huaxinw@sfu.ca ABSTRACT This paper studies narrative embedding in games, a phenomenon that has rarely been discussed in game studies. To understand the issues better, this work first seeks insights into embedding from narrative theory and sets up a descriptive framework that includes a categorization of horizontal, vertical and modal embedding, as well as their associated characteristics. The paper then applies the framework to game narratives and examines how narrative em­bedding is implemented in games, how it helps structure the nar­rative content, and how it influences the narrative experience. By relating theoretical discussions to game examples, the findings of this study can potentially help game narrative designers make more informed decisions when embedding narrative in games. Categories and Subject Descriptors K 8.0 [Personal Computing]: General Games. General Terms Design, Theory. Keywords Embedding, embedded narrative, narrative design, computer game, game narrative, narrative level. 1. INTRODUCTION Narrative embedding exists not only in almost all kinds of literary texts but also in such non-literary narrative media as films, hyper­texts and games. In narrative theory, embedding is a term usually used to describe the literary device of the story within a story , the structure by which a character in a narrative text becomes the narrator of a second narrative text framed by the first one [6]. For example, if character A tells a story about character B who tells a story about character C, we get two embedded stories at two different levels from the main story level, where character A resides. In the field of game design, embedded narrative is used to refer to those scripted narrative elements that are embedded throughout a game to form the background story; emergent nar­rative, as opposed to embedded narrative, is used to refer to non­scripted narratives generated via player actions [7, 13]. This view, however, is problematic; the way it cuts clearly between scripted and non-scripted narratives in games is too simple to describe narrative dynamics in games. In fact, a recent consensus about game narrative calls for an integrated view. As Doug Church Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, re­quires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 argues, a game story does not necessarily mean expository, pre­written text ; rather, it refers to any narrative thread that binds events together and drives the player forward toward completion of the game [4]. Under this contention, one needs to look at both pre-generated narrative content and player actions (i.e. both the designer s story and the player s story [11]) of the game. The aforementioned split-view approach is not very useful for a holis­tic study of game narrative. In fact, other than providing the distinction between embedded narrative and emergent narrative, existing works in game studies and game design offer almost no detailed discussion on how to embed narrative in games and how embedding can influence the narrative experience. In contrast, the topic of narrative embedding has been studied in some depth in narrative theory. Prominent in the literature, William Nelles monumental book Frameworks gives a comprehensive and provocative introduction to embedded narrative, the ways it exists in narrative texts, and the functions it performs to affect narrative interpretation [10]. Similarly, critical analyse of how narrative content is embedded in existing games can facilitate the understanding of narrative design and inspire new ways and approaches in future design. The past decade has seen increasing effort applied to creating meaningful and engaging stories in game development. In a recent article, Stephen Dinehart, the narrative designer of Companies of Heroes: Opposing Fronts, points out that a new niche is form­ing in game studios where the goal is to transplant the player into a believable drama where he is actor [5]. Dinehart suggests that interactive narrative design is at the heart of this new trend of dramatic play, which conjoins ludology, narratology, and game design methodologies. In line with this view and treating games as narrative texts, this paper adapts insights from narrative theory, especially those from Nelles work, and examines narrative em­bedding in games, both as a phenomenon and as a narrative de­vice. After a clarification of what is embedded narrative in the context of this work, the rest of the paper uncovers the ways nar­rative embedding exist in games and how it helps organize narra­tive content, provide narrative information, as well as shape narra­tive experience as a whole. The analysis is illustrated and sup­ported with relevant game examples. 2. (RE)DEFINE THE PROBLEMATIC EMBEDDED NARRATIVE To iterate the problem, a mere distinction between scripted and non-scripted narratives is not adequate to address such critical questions as how to embed narrative in games? and how can the way of embedding influence narrative experience? As the present work seeks insights from narrative theory to inform the study of narrative embedding in games, it is beneficial to go be­yond the narrow sentiment that only those pre-scripted, non­interactive narrative content is embedded narrative, and return to the narratological origin of the concept of embedded narrative. To define embedded narrative, one needs to be aware of narrative levels, a notion used by narrative theorists to identify and distin­guish multiple narrating acts (to generate one or more embedded narratives) found within a narrative text. Gérard Genette s model of narrative levels based on the distinction of diegetic levels seems to be widely followed [6].1 Marie-Laure Ryan expands the diegesis-based idea and considers that embedded narrative can also be differentiated by ontological boundaries that lead to a new system of reality without introducing a new speaker (or narrator) [12]. The somewhat vague notion of embedding has been finally examined and clarified by Nelles, who suggests that the shifts of narrator, narrative level (or diegetic level) and reality can all mark the border between the embedded narrative and the embedding narrative [10]. He then proposes two structurally dif­ferent types of embedding: horizontal embedding and vertical embedding. In horizontal embedding, texts are embedded at the same diegetic level, but narrated by different narrators, one after another. In vertical embedding, texts are embedded at different diegetic levels, either inserted within or stacked on top of one another [10]. Nelles also recognizes modal embedding as the third type to refer to those texts that are embedded in another spatial-temporal universe different from the main narrative, i.e., marked by a shift of reality. A narrative with a dream or fantasy could fall into this category. Nelles also adds that a modal em­bedding could be set up through vertical or horizontal shifts. Unlike written texts, games as visual narratives present the story not just through telling, but also through showing and inter­acting. As games use a set of storytelling devices different from that of traditional narratives, embedding keeps the general con­cept of story within a story, but does not have to be realized through a shift of narrator. An obvious example is the distinct game levels in games like Super Mario Bros., where each level has a unique thematic design as well as a unique set of objects and characters. There is certainly no shift of narrator, but each game level can also be considered a framed narrative a case of modal embedding. Nelles s clear yet broad classification system thus seems sufficient to describe computer games. Consequently this paper considers all narrative units that tell a mini story, which deviates from the main storyline through a shift of narrator, narra­tive level, or reality, as embedded narratives in games.2 The most common form of embedded narrative in games is what Ernest Adams calls narrative blocks that are non-interactive sequences including opening, ending and interlevel sequences, as well as cut-scenes [1]. There are other types of narrative units on a smaller scale that contain a distinct story. They can be dia­logues, text blocks (journals, letters, captions), and voice-over narration, as long as they contain a story. Under the broader no­tion of embedded narrative, one can occasionally see player inter­ 1 Diegesis and mimesis are Plato s distinction of two ways to present a story: the former is the telling of a story and the latter is the showing (or acting) of a story. In the example used in the Introduction, character A, B, and C reside on three different di­egetic levels as A and B are both narrators in the story. 2 As for other embedded content e.g. a quote, a comment, a picture that does not tell a story, Bal suggests they are better discussed under the realm of intertextuality [3]. actions within an embedded narrative. The following section will observe and describe different types of narrative embedding in games based on Nelles s typology. 3. EMBEDDED NARRATIVES IN GAMES The narrative of a game is constructed on the fly. One could see a game plot as a set of all possible narrative instances. Looking at the game retrospectively after one play, the player has gone through only one instantiation of the plot set, which is the main narrative from the beginning to the end of a game. It is the out­ermost frame of the game narrative, the containing narrative of all possible embedded ones, and the ground level in the game s nar­rative hierarchy. For most games, the narrator of the main narra­tive is a dual agent combining an external narrator (an agent who is outside the storyworld), presenting the pre-generated narrative, with the player, presenting (via playing) the emergent narrative. Horizontal and vertical embeddings can describe the relation ei­ther between any two embedded narratives or between the em­bedded narrative and the embedding narrative. To be consistent, the following discussion will be based on the relation between the embedded narrative and the main narrative. 3.1 Horizontal Embedding The defining characteristic of horizontal embedding is that it in­volves a shift in narrator but not narrative level. During a game play, the narration (i.e. the telling of the story) is sometimes handed over to an in-game character (i.e. an internal narrator) or the player character. When the narration is handed from one nar­rator to another, the embedding pattern is horizontal and as a re­sult we hear the main story and the embedded story side by side. At times objects tell stories, too; thus they are also considered embedded narratives. 3.1.1 Flashback Sequence In the narratological discussion, one criterion to categorize em­bedded narratives is based on their temporal relations to the main narrative because in most cases the time-shift is accompanied with a shift of narrator on the same narrative level [10]. These retrospective (flashback) or anticipative (flashforward) narratives are extensions to the main narrative. Although Juul claims that flashbacks are problematic for games [8], recent games with rela­tively complicated storytelling do have flashback sequences as a stylistic choice added to the narrative design. Max Payne and Metal Gear Solid are two game series famously using over-the­top flashback sequences at the beginning of the games. In flashbacks, players lose their co-narrating roles, partially (when the sequence is interactive) or fully (when it is not), to the player character (as internal narrator) or the external narrator. These sequences set the tone of the story and provide background in­formation for the player. For a sequel game, flashback sequences can also give a hint of what happened in previous games in the series a design welcomed by those new players. Flashforwad sequences are rarely seen in games but we might expect to see more in the future. 3.1.2 Narrative Object In games that employ environmental storytelling, not just charac­ters tell stories, but objects do, too. A common form that carries a literary tradition is objects with texts. Examples can be stone in­scriptions, or long captions that often appear at the beginning of a game section that tells a mini story, such as in Fable II. The nar­rator of these mini stories is often uncertain, though most likely is an omniscient external agent different from the one who tells the main story. In this case, these texts are considered as embedded narratives. 3.2 Vertical Embedding According to Nelles classification, other than the shift of narra­tor, vertical embedding also requires the shift of narrative level; namely, the new narrator takes the narration to a new level. Hence in a vertical embedding, there are at least two levels of narration. While horizontal embedding helps arrange the temporal sequence and organize narrative content, vertical embedding cre­ates depth in the storytelling, which caters to the diverse needs of various player types. 3.2.1 Dialogue In games we frequently see a character starting to tell a story. The narration is then passed on from the dual agent (the external nar­rator and the player) to the character and enters an embedded narrative. For example in The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hour­glass, several non-player characters tell the player character dif­ferent stories about the dangerous ghost ship. They help create a fearful mood and expectation of bad happenings. These mini sto­ries are one level up from the main narrative. Similar to what Bal observes in traditional narrative [3], these embedded mini stories in games usually serve the functions of explanation, by supplying information, or determination, by setting up causal relationships for future events. In addition, these dialogues can help in setting the mood and portraying the narrating character. 3.2.2 Narrative Objects As described above, a story-telling narrative object can be consid­ered as a horizontally embedded narrative when it is uncertain whom the narrator is. When it is certain, as often in the cases of letters and journals, the embedding is vertical as the narration clearly enters into a second level. One such example is the codex pages on the puzzle wall in Assassin s Creed II, which have jour­nals on the back written by Altair (the protagonist in the prequel game) documenting his explorations and experiences as well as some assassination-related articles. These journals create connec­tions between the storylines of the first and second game. 3.2.3 Non-flashback, Non-interactive Sequence Whenever the game enters a non-interactive narrative sequence, players lose their co-narrating roles. If it is not a flashback and there is a distinct narrator telling a deviating story, it qualifies as an embedded narrative. Opening, ending and interlevel sequences telling a separate story are all possible examples. 3.2.4 Voice-over Narration Sometimes voice-over narration as an audio sequence is played unobtrusively along with the gameplay. It is similar to a non­interactive sequence; namely, when it tells a distinct mini story, it qualifies as an embedded narrative. In most circumstances, we can tell who the narrator is. An interesting exception is Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time, where it only becomes clear who the narrator is at the end of the game and players realize that the en­tire game is a flashback. Within this large container flashback, all pre-generated sequences and player actions are embedded. Jordan Mechner, writer of this game, openly admits that using voice-over narration as a framing device and nesting stories within stories is a design choice with intent to combine game genres making a survival horror game ostensibly a swashbuckling acrobatic action-adventure [9]. 3.3 Modal Embedding The key factor that identifies modal embedding is the shift of the reality, or the storyworld. Nelles points out that examples of this kind are found in dreams, hallucinations, or science-fiction sto­ries of alternate dimensions [10], which appear in many literary and film works. In games, modal embedding is also widely ap­plied. In Assassin s Creed II, there is a hallucination sequence that happened to Desmond, the player character in modern times, during which he became Altair (the protagonist of the prequel game) and was chasing a target. After he reached the target on top of a tower, it turned out to be Maria, gesturing him to come closer. Altair kissed her and the two made love, after which he leaped off the tower. From there Desmond was no longer able to follow. This sequence implies Maria to be Desmond s distant grandmother and that he and Ezio (the protagonist in ancient times in the current game) both carry the lineage of Altair. It sim­ply serves the purpose of explanation of the larger story and has no contribution to the gameplay and strategic planning. However one interesting thing about this embedded narrative is that players have limited control in the early part of the sequence, where they actually need to use the controller to chase Maria in order to drive the story forward. Some recent entertainment works have been exploring the phi­losophical and ontological meanings of avatar . Examples range from the online virtual reality community Second Life, to the new game Assassin s Creed II, to the recently released film Avatar. Stories with an avatar theme have a double reality, with one or more characters having a double identity. To make audiences relate more to the story, the reality of the main narrative is usually chosen to be in a more contemporary setting, while the alternate reality (avatar reality) can be set in the future, in the past, or like in the film Avatar, on a different planet. This double setting some­times, oddly, can make the story appear more real. If we as play­ers were thrown into the role of Ezio hanging around in medieval Italian cities, we would face one of the two situations: the first being that we use modern languages both talking in the story and receiving game instructions, the second being that we use ancient languages (and manners) to do both. Neither of the two situations adds to the sense of realism. In fact, they both could remind us that the story we are playing is unreal. A double reality, therefore, is a resolution to this problem. We are Desmond, a contemporary character talking contemporary American English, who sets out to finish a series of commissions taking place in an alternate reality the ancient Italy as Ezio. Now things, though arguably, start to make sense and we are able to switch back and forth. Games also have another unique type of modal embedding. Early in the paper I have cited the example of Super Mario Bros. s level design. Game levels featuring different thematic designs can also be treated as modally embedded narratives. The rules or gameplay mechanics can be different from one game level to another. 3.4 Transgressing Boundaries In narratives of all sorts, narrators and characters do not just sit still in their supposed level within the boundaries. Occasionally we see them cross the boundary, from one embedded narrative to another, or from an embedded narrative to the embedding narra­tive. This phenomenon can be related to the narratological term metalepsis, often referring to the move made by a narrating char­acter from one narrative level to another. Metalepsis is a narrative device that can produce special effects. Nelles summarizes two effects observed by previous scholars: comedy and realism. In Prince of Persia: Sands of Time, when the player-controlled Prince falls to his death, the player will hear the Prince s voice saying: Wait, what did I just say? That didn t happen. Let me back up a bit. At this moment, the narrator, originally dwelling in the player character and thus an internal narrator, crosses the boundary and becomes an external narrator who is not affected by his own death. This humorous tone instantly enlightens the death outcome and encourages the player to try again to make it right. Another type of transgression that only exists in games is game modifications and customizations. These functions allow players to modify the game based on their own preferences. In Grand Auto Theft III, for example, players can copy their favorite songs into the game file folder so that in the game world, they can listen to their songs from the car audio player. Wm. Ruffin Bailey rec­ognizes this inviting subversion as a form of metalepsis [2]. It fuses the game world and real world and through doing so, makes the game feel more real. 4. EMBEDDING AS NARRATIVE DESIGN: A SUMMARY Embedding is an important narrative device that helps structure the narrative in different ways. The resultant structure as well as relations between the embedding and the embedded narratives leads to different narrative effects. In the previous sections, I have discussed various types of narrative embedding, the functions they performed and effects they produced, through interpretive analysis of examples found in games. To summarize, there are three categories of embedding existing in game narratives. In horizontal embedding, the embedded narrative has a different narrator from the main narrative but stays on the same narrative level. Common forms are flashback sequences and narrative ob­jects that tell a story by an obscure narrator. The main function of horizontal embedding is to help structure narrative content. In­stead of presenting a linear, single narrator story, designers can embed mini stories horizontally throughout the game and distrib­ute information (including instructions). In vertical embedding, the embedded narrative shifts not only in narrator but also in nar­rative level. By bringing layers to the storytelling, it helps in ex­plaining complicated events. Common forms are characters dia­logues, narrative objects with a distinct narrator, non-flashback sequences, and voice-over narrations. Vertical embedding also offers the option of nesting stories to those designers who want to play with genre and style in the game storytelling. Finally in mo­dal embedding, the embedded narrative shifts in reality and pro­vides an alternate storyworld to players. It is quite commonly used in games and plays a variety of roles, ranging from structur­ing the game (into game levels), to providing background stories, to helping players make sense of the story. As Nelles reminds us, a given author s manipulation of any structural component must be interpreted on a case-by-case basis [10]; it is thus impossible to develop an exhaustive list covering all the phenomena related to narrative embedding. Nevertheless, this paper has described the typical ways of narrative embedding in games and their associated narrative effects, which can serve as basic principles for narrative design. Built on the descriptive framework set up in the current paper, more work can be done in the future. This includes examining more games and extending the inventory of narrative embedding devices, from which a more refined set of embedding principles can be developed for game narrative design and more game narrative analyses on a larger scale can be carried out. 5. article_rec.title: Serious games for analog telecommunications education

abstract.par: Traditional teaching-and-learning environments often do not address the learning needs of today's "millennial" generation of students who prefer team-work, experiential activities, structure and the use of technology. Serious games leverage the power of computer games to captivate and engage players for a specific purpose such as to develop new knowledge or skills while providing a learner-centered approach to learning which have shown to be effective, particularly with today's generation of students. This paper describes an ongoing project that will see the development and evaluation serious game to facilitate learning of the concepts related to Amplitude Modulation (AM) for undergraduate Electronics Engineering curriculums allowing electronic engineering students to focus on and develop an understanding of the fundamental AM process.

fulltext.ft_body: Serious Games for Analog Telecommunications Education Alex Monclou1, Sayra Cristancho2, Bill Kapralos3, and Adam Dubrowski2,4 1Facultad de Ingenieria Electronica, Universidad Ponti.cia Bolivariana Seccional Bucaramanga. Bucaramanga, Colombia. 2SickKids Learning Institute, The Hospital for Sick Children. 555 University Ave., Toronto, Canada. 3 Faculty of Business and Information Technology, Health Education Technology Research Unit, University of Ontario Institute of Technology. 2000 Simcoe Street North, Oshawa, Canada. 4Department of Paediatrics and The Wilson Centre, Faculty of Medicine, University of Toronto. 200 Elizabeth Street, Toronto, Canada. alex.monclou@upbbga.edu.co sayra.cristancho@utoronto.ca bill.kapralos@uoit.ca adam.dubrowski@utoronto.ca ABSTRACT Traditional teaching-and-learning environments often do not address the learning needs of today s millennial generation of students who prefer team-work, experiential activities, structure and the use of technology. Serious games lever­age the power of computer games to captivate and engage players for a speci.c purpose such as to develop new knowl­edge or skills while providing a learner-centered approach to learning which have shown to be e.ective, particularly with today s generation of students. This paper describes an on­going project that will see the development and evaluation serious game to facilitate learning of the concepts related to Amplitude Modulation (AM) for undergraduate Electron­ics Engineering curriculums allowing electronic engineering students to focus on and develop an understanding of the fundamental AM process. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.3.7 [Computer Graphics]: Three-Dimensional Graphics and Realism Virtual reality. General Terms Human Factors, Performance. Keywords Electronics engineering, serious games, interactive learning environment, game-based learning, amplitude modulation. 1. INTRODUCTION At the Ponti.cia Bolivariana University in Bucaramanga, Colombia (UPB-Bucaramanga), Amplitude Modulation (a Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. ACM FuturePlay 2010 Vancouver, BC. Canada. May 6-7 2010. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 technique used in electronic communications whereby infor­mation is transmitted via a carrier wave) is taught during the fourth of the .ve year Electronics Engineering program, where lectures and laboratory are included as teaching re­sources. Amplitude Modulation is one of the backbone con­cepts for any electronics engineer, as it constitutes the base to understand the features and functionality of any telecom­munication system. Although the laboratory environment allows the students to test simple electronic circuit designs, the actual nuances, problem solving, and trouble shoot­ing that surrounds the implementation of AM Broadcasting Systems (Broadcasting stations and Single Side Bands sys­tems) is only acquired in a job-related environment where all commercial equipment are available. Such a traditional teaching methodology requires the students to master com­plex mathematical concepts (e.g., frequency mixing, Fourier Transform properties, etc.) that could be observed in the actual industrial setting by implementing electronic devices such as mixers, and multipliers for amplitude modulation. In the university context, particularly that of Colombia and UPB-Bucaramanga, during the lab sessions, students repli­cate the same processes by using hardware training boards; however, the high cost involved in purchasing these hard­ware resources makes it it very di.cult, if not impossible, to establish an adequate and constant update process of the technology. Traditional teaching-and-learning environments often do not address the learning needs of today s millennial gen­eration of students who prefer team-work, experiential ac­tivities, structure and the use of technology. In fact, mil­lennial students view technology as a necessity, both in life and in learning and highly regard doing rather than know­ing , making interactive, experiential learning, a necessity for their educational success [3]. In contrast to traditional approaches, serious games, or games that do not have en­tertainment, enjoyment, or fun as their primary purpose [4], leverage the power of computer games to captivate and en­gage players for a speci.c purpose such as to develop new knowledge or skills [1]. In addition to promoting learning via interaction, there are various other bene.ts to serious games. More speci.cally, they allow users to experience sit­uations that are di.cult (even impossible) to achieve in re­ality due to a number of factors including cost, time, and safety concerns [1, 6]. Serious games support the develop­ment of various skills including analytical and spatial, strate­gic, recollection, and psychomotor skills as well as visual selective attention and can foster improved self-monitoring, problem recognition/solving, and increased social skills [5]. In order to move this push into the Colombian university context and take advantage of the bene.ts serious games of­fer, we have recently begun development of a serious game to facilitate the learning of the concepts related to Amplitude Modulation (AM), both Broadcasting and Single Side Band, and to gauge whether learning in an online serious gaming environment will enhance engineering skill acquisition. Us­ing a virtual environment, where replication of any equip­ment/structure/tool is possible, the purpose of the present project is consequently to design, implement and validate a serious game to provide students with the opportunity of learning how to implement an AM General System in a similar fashion as in real life. The serious game will allow electronic engineering students to focus on, and develop an understanding of the process itself (i.e., the ordering of each of the steps in the transmission/reception system, and the various circuits used). By clearly understanding the steps of such a system and the underpinning decision making pro­cesses, when placed in a real job environment, trainees will be able to focus on the technical aspect of the process. The use of serious games in the Colombian education context has not been explored yet. Consequently, this proposal seeks to be one of the .rst studies of this kind in Colombia applied to the Electronics Engineering undergraduate education. The development of the game will follow the two key themes pro­posed by Kirriemuir and McFarlane [2]. More speci.cally, i) the desire to harness the motivational power of games in order to make learning fun , and ii) a belief that learning through doing in games such as simulations o.er a powerful learning tool. 2. OVERVIEW The AM-Station serious game is intended to serve as an innovative tool to help students learn analog telecommu­nication concepts, and to be used in conjunction to other traditional learning materials including books, lab sessions and videos. The goal is for the user/trainee to successfully complete the implementation of a AM Broadcasting Station and a AM-Single Side Band System focusing on the pro­cess itself (i.e., focusing on the ordering in which steps are performed and on the tools/equipment/circuits required to perform each) while minimizing the time to complete the process and maximizing the score (points are either added or taken away based on the trainee s actions). The game will include six levels with progressive di.culty as follows: i) simple Amplitude Modulation (AM) transmission, ii) super­heterodyne receiver, iii) phase-shift Single Side Band (SSB) generator, iv) Single Side Band (SSB) receiver, v) complete Amplitude Modulation system (i.e., join elements from lev­els i and ii), and vi) complete Single Side Band System (i.e., join elements from levels iii and iv). All levels will consist of i) selecting and putting together various conceptual blocks, and ii) selecting and assembling the actual electrical circuits for the block diagrams using symbolic and commercial electrical elements (e.g., resistors, capacitors, diodes). We will also incorporate games within the game whereby at various points in the game, the user is presented with a sub-game where they are required to perform a small task related to the step they are currently performing and allows users to accumulate further points. Fundamental to the game design is the breadboard, a construction base for electronic circuit prototyping com­monly used in electronics engineering curriculum. More speci.cally, the user/player is presented with a 3D bread­board in addition to a variety of 3D electronic components from their toolbox that they can choose on the breadboard. After completing the required circuit, the circuit is tested and if the circuit works, the player progresses to the next level. The faster the player connects the circuit, the more points they receive. At the end of the game, the player receives a grade based on the number of points they have accumulated. The goal is for the user/trainee to success­fully complete the implementation of a AM Broadcasting Station and a AM-Single Side Band System focusing on the process itself (i.e., focusing on the ordering in which steps are performed and on the tools/equipment/circuits required to perform each) while minimizing the time to complete the process and maximizing the score (points are either added or taken away based on the trainee s actions). 3. CONCLUSIONS This paper has described an ongoing project that seeks the development of a serious game to facilitate the learn­ing of the concepts related to Amplitude Modulation (AM) which are fundamental in any electronics engineering cur­riculum. To our knowledge, the application of serious games within the Colombian educational context has not yet been explored and therefore this work is the .rst of its kind in Colombia applied to the Electronics Engineering undergrad­uate education. Future work includes completion of the se­rious game followed by a Randomized-Controlled Trial that will be implemented in order to test the hypothesis that stu­dents will bene.t most by using the serious game approach than by being uniquely exposed to the traditional learning resources. A group of 40 Electronics Engineering students will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: i) serious game training, and ii) traditional training (i.e., lectures and laboratories). A retention test will be performed two weeks after the training sessions. 4. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS The .nancial support of the National Science and Engi­neering Research Council of Canada (NSERC), and 2010 General Research Department Funding from the Universi­dad Ponti.cia Bolivariana, Bucaramanga, Colombia is grate­fully acknowledged. 5.
