fulltext.ft_body: An Exploration of Distributed Mobile Audio and Games Karen Collins Canadian Centre of Arts and Bill Kapralos, Andrew Hogue Faculty of Business and IT Kamen Kanev Research Institute of Electronics Technology, University of Waterloo University of Ontario Institute of Shizuoka University Waterloo, Canada. Technology, Oshawa, Canada. Hamamatsu, Japan collinsk@uwaterloo.ca {bill.kapralos, andrew.hogue}@uoit.ca kanev@rie.shizuoka.ac.jp ABSTRACT In this paper, we present work in progress on distributed mobile audio games. We outline some of our areas of exploration along with how these types of games may be particularly useful in educational environments that require training in, for example, mixing, spatial sound and orchestration. Categories and Subject Descriptors K.8.0 [Computing Milieux]: Computing Milieux-Personal Computing-General-Games. Keywords Games, mobile, audio, distributed games, smart table. 1. INTRODUCTION Mobile devices are becoming an increasingly important part of the information technology ecosystem as the power of these devices increase and network bandwidth improves. The unique characteristics of these devices have a significant impact on the development of applications for them, and since these devices are relatively new, the design space is largely unexplored. The main properties of mobile devices that differentiate them from other computing devices are the fact that they are always on, carried on the individual most of the time, and they have the ability to be connected to some type of network. This allows for connectivity between various devices using WiFi (when available) or Bluetooth. Furthermore, various devices including the Apple iPhone, employ assisted GPS technologies providing the ability to localize the device physically within a 10-20m accuracy, opening up a huge possibility for interesting applications. An underexplored area of gaming is the idea of networking mobile devices (particularly smart phones) together for distributed gaming applications. Here we present the possibility of combining mobile devices together, and with collaborative displays in audio­based games. We suggest that in addition to being fun, audio­based games may be useful in training students of sound and music in particular aspects of their craft and that smart phones lend themselves well to distributed gaming applications. Traditionally, audio games include audio-only computer games (that is, where there are no visuals) and audio-based games (where visuals are included but not the focus). The idea of audio-based games dates back to at least Real Sound Kazeno Regret, a commercial audio adventure game designed specifically for visually impaired children and released for the Sega Dreamcast and Saturn by Sega in 1999. Essentially, Real Sound- Kaze no Regret was an interactive radio drama, similar to a choose-your- Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. ACM FuturePlay 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 own-adventure style audio-book. Several audio-based or audio­only games have now been adapted from popular existing games. For a more complete survey, see [4]. Augmented mobile audio-based games represent a new technological trend that enriches the real acoustic environment with synthesized sound produced by virtual sound objects [8]. These games have primarily tapped into ideas of utilizing spatialized sound on mobile devices, rather than using the potential for networking these devices together in a larger pervasive gaming space, limiting their potential use and application. There are several reasons for this, most notably due to the some current issues or problems with networking mobile devices and with their audio capabilities. 2. ISSUES WITH MOBILE DEVICES Despite the opportunities presented by mobile devices, there are still many issues that must be addressed for these types of games to become more popular, particularly when with respect to sound generation and sound output for gaming applications. Gaming sound requirements are computationally demanding, thus difficult to sustain in terms of the limited speed and memory bandwidth inherent in mobile devices [1]. This is further complicated when spatial sound is required. In this case, the amount of information that needs to be computed and transferred is difficult to manage on the limited storage and computing ability of a small hand-held device. Battery life is another significant issue, as audio is used in combination with demanding high-band width processing (3D graphics, video); keeping a high-priority for audio is mandatory to avoid dropouts [1]. Furthermore, mobile devices typically employ just one loudspeaker (which is of poor quality), preventing the effective output of spatial sound unless headphones are employed. Headphones themselves have their share of problems, including the fact that they may not always be practical to wear and they commonly have to be tethered to the device itself (wireless, Bluetooth-based headphones are available but these have issues of their own including limited battery life). 3. EXAMPLE GAMING APPLICATIONS There are many areas of mobile audio networked games that we wish to explore. Here we present two novel games that we are currently developing. 3.1 Mobile Audio Positioning Game with Marker-Based Interactions In this game, players are assigned a particular sound to their mobile device and given a corresponding positional marker to wear on a hat on their head. In a room configured with cameras, the position of the players is tracked using the ARToolKit, a computer vision-based augmented reality library that can be used to recognize specific real-world objects [3]. A large screen on one wall presents the results of the positioning in a 3D representation. Players must then create a soundscape to match the landscape by positioning themselves in the room according to a series of directions. Players may be required to continuously move about the room to match the positioning of a moving item in the landscape (e.g., a train or loud animal). Players score points for quickly finding the correct position of their sound-making object in the landscape. This game can be played with visuals on or off, and so can be used as an audio-only game in which players must first listen to the spatialized soundscape played back over surround speakers, and then try to recreate that soundscape in the physical space by correctly positioning their sounds in the mix . The game can be used to teach students about soundscapes and auditory effects as well as spatial audio positioning, Doppler effects, and so on. A similar game can also be designed to teach students about the virtual sound box in music, a concept that acknowledges the way sound sources are perceived to exist in four dimensions: laterality, register, prominence, and temporal continuity [7]. Each student for instance could be assigned an instrument and must then re-create the song in real three-dimensional space according to their perceptions of the instrumentation spatialization. 3.2 Mobile/Augmented Table Music Game A second series of games address the idea of connecting mobile phones to augmented-reality smart table games. This concept of using small, private individualized devices with larger, collective screens has become a recent area of interest in pervasive gaming [2,9], and using mobile devices in particular is becoming an important area of inquiry [2]. Sahami et al. [9], have recently designed games that explore using mobile phones through a combination of smart table and gestural mobile interaction (tilting, throwing, and shaking the phone). One can easily imagine this gestural interaction incorporated into a musical jam session in which one person controls a kind of sequencer at the tabletop and sends sounds or sequences out to individuals who then play those sounds/instruments. Turning this into a game may involve, for instance, a Rock Band style musical game in which the timing of the individual performance is tied to a larger group performance. Again, this type of game may be particularly useful for educational purposes, in teaching orchestration, musical composition, and other music-based topics. 4. CONCLUDING REMARKS Our games are in conceptual stage at the moment. In the next few months we will be building early prototypes. There are several noted problems with the technology at the moment, but it is our hope that raising interest in these possible uses of mobile devices may encourage mobile developers to incorporate better networking capabilities between phones, as well as high fidelity and louder speakers in phones. We welcome all suggestions at this stage. Solving problems of networking audio on mobile phones can provide some interesting applications in non-gaming scenarios. We present below two scenarios that we envisage could be useful applications: Imagine walking into a business meeting with your new video projector-phone, ready to excite customers with a powerful movie presentation, complete with surround sound. However, you arrive to find that there are no loudspeakers available and your laptop loud speakers are of very poor quality (typical in most laptops currently available), and even in their loudest setting, cannot be heard by those in the audience sitting in the back of the room. Now imagine could the ability to network your presentation to everyone in the room with a phone, projecting your audio to their phones, so that everyone s phone becomes a speaker: Instant surround sound.1 While it may not be configured as well as a fixed surround application, the general effect will be good enough for the purpose at hand. Taking that same idea, imagine being in a concert venue where the band projects its music to everyone in the venue, or selects sections and projects certain instruments to segments of a larger venue, perhaps changing the configuration of projected audio during a performance. The audience could even become an interactive part of the experience, by actively selecting which instrument they wish to have projected from their phone. 4. fulltext.ft_body: GameSoup: A Two-stage Game Development Environment [Extended Abstract] Kevin Tonon Tech. for Aging Gracefully lab (TAGlab) University of Toronto 40 St. George Street Toronto, Ontario, Canada ktonon@cs.toronto.edu ABSTRACT Designing an end-user development environment seems to require making a trade-o. between ease of use and expres­siveness. GameSoup is an online game development plat­form that attempts to satisfy these two design requirements by splitting development into two distinct stages. One stage requires programming experience and is highly expressive; the other stage is very easy to use. Keywords End-user development 1. INTRODUCTION End-user programming environments for making games are abundant, however most of these are meant for use in education and sacri.ce expressiveness for ease of use. Game-Soup is an online game development platform that attempts to provide both expressiveness and ease of use. Game devel­opment is split into two distinct stages. In the .rst stage, called library building, programmers de.ne interfaces and types using a conventional programming language. Game-Soup interfaces and types are similar to Java interfaces and classes. In the second stage, called game assembly, game de­signers instantiate objects from types and make connections between them. The game assembly tool is easy to use and allows non-programmers to create new games from existing ones. The expressiveness of the assembly tool depends on the richness of the library. 2. RELATED WORK There are many frameworks for end-user development which can be used to make games [2, 3, 5, 7]. Many of these frame­works are meant for use in education [2, 3, 7]. By contrast, GameSoup is a tool meant to aid researchers interested in gaming. For example, Velian Pandeliev is creating a web­site for enabling online studies involving participants play- Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay 2010, May 6-7 2010 Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 Ronald Baecker Tech. for Aging Gracefully lab (TAGlab) University of Toronto 40 St. George Street Toronto, Ontario, Canada rmb@kmdi.toronto.edu ing games [6]. The games for this site will be supplied by GameSoup. In some end-user development frameworks, low-level logic is speci.ed using visual techniques such as graphical rewrite rules and programming by demonstration [3, 7]. In Game-Soup all low-level behaviour is encapsulated as types and is speci.ed using a traditional programming language. During game assembly connections between objects are shown as a .ow chart, from which the high-level logic of the game can be understood. 3. CREATING AND MODIFYING GAMES GameSoup games are made in two stages: library build­ing and game assembly. These stages are carried out by programmers and designers, respectively. The following sec­tions describe each stage in more detail. 3.1 Library Building The GameSoup library is a collection of interfaces and types. GameSoup interfaces and types are similar to Java interfaces and classes respectively. Both interfaces and types may have template parameters, which makes them similar to Java Generics or C++ Class Templates [1]. A big di.erence between Java interfaces and classes and GameSoup inter­faces and types is that GameSoup types do not implement interfaces directly. Instead, types implement interface ex­pressions which are expressions involving interface names, interface template parameters bindings, and type template parameters. Interface expressions are recursive in the sense that interface template parameters are bound to nested in­terface expressions. Figure 1 shows the parse tree of an example interface expression. Suppose interface B de.nes a method read() :y (meaning y is the interface of the object returned by this method call) and interface E de.nes another method speak(). Now suppose that Figure 1 represents the inter­face implemented by type Q. Then a client of an object q which instantiates type Q can make the following method calls q.read().speak(). A type can also declare instance parameters, which will be bound by objects which instantiate the type. Instance pa­rameters must also be speci.ed using interface expressions. Suppose we have a type R which declares an instance pa­rameter u with the interface requirement [A<x=[E]>].Now suppose that r is an instance of R and that we want to bind q to the instance parameter r.u. This can be done by bind­ing the type template parameter Q.x to [E], because then Figure 1: Parse tree for the interface expression [A<x=[@Q.x]> +B<x=[], y=[E + F]>]. A,B,E, and F are interfaces while Q.x is a type template pa­rameter. Interface template parameters are bound to sub-expressions between angled brackets. For ex­ample, B.y binds to [E + F]. Interface addition (+) means that both interfaces are supported. the type of q would be [A<x=[E]> + ...]. Thiskindofdy­namic typing of objects based on the connections they make with other objects is automated by GameSoup during game assembly. 3.2 Assembling Games The GameSoup game assembler is a tool that aids non­programmers in instantiating objects from types and com­posing objects into functioning games. Objects are either visible or invisible. Visible objects rep­resent the interface of the game. Invisible objects can be anything, but typically represent algorithms or data struc­tures. Figure 2 shows the game Boggle [4] being assembled on GameSoup. Objects are instantiated in a number of ways. The sim­plest way is browsing through the library of types. When an object is instantiated it acquires a default interface ex­pression from its type. As connections are made between objects their interfaces are re.ned as needed by binding type template parameters. The interfaces of objects and object parameters are used by the game assembler to: decide which bindings are legal .lter for candidate objects and types when binding object parameters suggest objects and types which can make use of ob­jects already in the game Consider Figure 2. Suppose the game designer began by adding the visual elements of the game .rst: for the letters use a SquareGrid for entering words use a TextInput Figure 2: The GameSoup game assembler. Full ob­ject list (left) and canvas with visible objects (right). for storing entered words use a List Next the user wants some way of checking that a word is on the board. The best way to .nd an algorithm that does this is to search for it using the objects which will be used by the algorithm. SquareGrid and TextInput become the query and the search yields all objects that can bind both of these objects to object parameters. In this case, among the types returned is WordOnBoardPath, an algorithm that has two parameters, board and word, which require interfaces supported by SquareGrid and TextInput, respectively. 4. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS The expressiveness of the game assembly tool increases with the size and variability of the library. Ease of use will also decrease with a larger library since game designers will have to search through a larger set of types to .nd the one that .ts into their game. The ability to use objects as queries for other compatible objects helps counter this e.ect. GameSoup is under development. Boggle has been imple­mented. Future work will focus on expanding the GameSoup library, studying the usability of the game assembly tool, and ways to visually represent the interfaces of objects. 5. REFERENCES [1] O. Agesen, S. article_rec.title: An emotion aware agent platform for interactive storytelling and gaming

abstract.par: As an emerging medium and industry, computer games received a lot of attention from scholars across a variety of disciplines. The realistic 3D graphics, intelligent non-player characters (NPC) and fascinating game play have made a great impact on user experience in the entertainment domain, e-Learning and other gaming related applications. In this paper, we investigate the game from another perspective - how the game can be affected by the player's real-time experience, such as emotion and gesture. A generic goal oriented software agent platform is proposed to automatically refine the animation, the NPC's personality and emotions, and the game story by learning from the player's realtime feedback from the emotion analyzing and gesture tracking modules. Fuzzy cognitive maps (FCMs) and data mining techniques are used to infer the mutual influences between the player's real world experience and the contents of the game. The adaptation of game to the player's real-time reactions will bring dynamism into the player's game experience. The proposed agent platform has been integrated with several commercial game engines including Unreal Engine 3, and Torque, etc.

fulltext.ft_body: An emotion aware agent platform for interactive storytelling and gaming Zhiqi Shen Chunyan Miao, Liang Zhang, Mark J. Chavez Nanyang Technological University Han Yu Nanyang Technological University School of Electrical and Electronic Nanyang Technological University School of Art, Design and Media Engineering School of Computing Engineering 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore + 65 6316 8827 + 65 6790 4386 + 65 6790 6197 mchavez@ntu.edu.sg zqshen@ntu.edu.sg {ascymiao, zhangliang, yuha0008}@ntu.edu.sg ABSTRACT As an emerging medium and industry, computer games received a lot of attention from scholars across a variety of disciplines. The realistic 3D graphics, intelligent non-player characters (NPC) and fascinating game play have made a great impact on user experience in the entertainment domain, e-Learning and other gaming related applications. In this paper, we investigate the game from another perspective - how the game can be affected by the player s real-time experience, such as emotion and gesture. A generic goal oriented software agent platform is proposed to automatically refine the animation, the NPC s personality and emotions, and the game story by learning from the player s real­time feedback from the emotion analyzing and gesture tracking modules. Fuzzy cognitive maps (FCMs) and data mining techniques are used to infer the mutual influences between the player s real world experience and the contents of the game. The adaptation of game to the player s real-time reactions will bring dynamism into the player's game experience. The proposed agent platform has been integrated with several commercial game engines including Unreal Engine 3, and Torque, etc. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.2.1 [Artificial Intelligence]: Applications and Expert Systems - Game General Terms Algorithms, Performance, Design, Human Factors Keywords Intelligent Agent, Real-time emotion analysis, FCM, Data mining 1. INTRODUCTION Of late, the development of computer games have received a tremendous boost from a series of new technologies that enabled realistic 3D graphics rendering, intelligent non-player characters (NPCs) and non-linear interactive story plots etc. This resulted in the computer games gaining more attention from scholars in various fields (e.g. entertainment, e-learning, etc.). As the boundary between the virtual world and the physical world is blurred by the development of virtual/augmented reality, we are motivated to investigate the game from a new perspective which is concerned with how player s real-time experience (e.g. Permission to make digital or hard copies of part or all of this work or personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers, or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. ACM FuturePlay 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, BC. Canada Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7 ...$10.00 emotion, gesture, etc.) affect the game. Traditional game inputs are usually from standard hardware such as joysticks or keyboards/mice, which is currently starting to be gradually replaced by more intuitive technologies such as real-time gesture/emotion analysis from the cameras, action tracking by handheld sensors and speech recognition technologies. Thus, enabling the game to learn from the player s experience becomes a challenge that requires multidisciplinary research efforts, ranging from psychology, artificial intelligence to human­computer interaction to be adequately addressed. In this paper, we propose a goal oriented software agent platform to automatically refine the virtual contents and game experience by learning the player s real-time feedback from the emotion analyzing and gesture tracking modules. Augmented by software agents, the NPCs or interactive virtual objects will possess rich personality and emotional states that are flexible enough to respond to player s interactions with the illusion of intelligence and affective awareness. In addition, the systems will automatically refine the game story by exploring the dynamics of a player s experiences. Fuzzy cognitive maps (FCMs) [1], data mining and the OCC emotion model [2] are used to infer the mutual influences between the player s experience and the contents of the game. The proposed agent platform has been integrated with several existing commercial game engines including Unreal Engine 3, and Torque, etc. 2. THE AGENT PLATFORM The goal oriented software agent platform includes an agent model, Goal Net, and an agent development framework, the Multi-Agent Development Environment (MADE) [3] [4]. Goal Net is a comprehensive agent modeling methodology for agent design, which models the mental state of an agent. Based on the Goal Net methodology, the MADE has been developed to facilitate the design and implementation of agent systems. It bridges the gap between agent technology and agent system design and implementation. Figure 1 shows a simple goal net. A goal is a desired state that an agent intends to reach. A goal net is a composite goal hierarchy which is composed of goals and transitions. The goals, represented by circles, are used to represent the states that an agent needs to go through in order to achieve its final goal. The transitions, represented by arcs and vertical bars, connect one goal to anther specifying the relationships between goals. Each transition must have at least one input goal and one output goal. Each transition is associated with a task list which defines the possible tasks that the agent needs to perform in order to transit from the input goal to the output goal. By using the Goal Net methodology, sophisticated storylines and NPCs of a game can be modeled. The game execution is augmented with an agent or a Figure 1 A simple Goal Net 3. THE PROPOSED PLATFORM To enable a game to learn from the player s experience and allow the system to automatically adapt accordingly, we propose an emotion aware agent platform by using interactive media and cognitive intelligence techniques whereby the contents of a game can be adjusted based on a player s emotional and gestural status to offer a personalized gaming experience. The proposed platform is shown in Figure 2. Goal nets and FCMs are used as the planning model/tool for the game manager. The game created using this unique approach is a user emotion-aware system, in which game characters become fully automated, emotional, intelligent agents embodied by visually appealing avatars; and are able to adapt both its visual and behavioral characteristics based Figure 2 System Platform As shown in Figure 2, the proposed platform includes three parts: the Goal Net Designer is for game story plot/agent designers to design game storylines and game characters; the Agent Engine is the core of the agent augmented system which includes game player s emotion analysis module, gesture detection module, data mining module for analyzing a player s past interactions (this information is useful to intelligent virtual agents such as emotion agents, user avatars, and the game manager); the Human Computer Interaction (HCI) is the interface between the agent platform and the environment which integrate the agent platform with game engines and sensing devices, such as cameras, microphones. The emotion/gesture analyzing module aims to use the player s real-time images from the cameras to analyze his/her reactions to the game. The derived emotional state and gesture will be used by the virtual agents and game manager agent to adjust the game contents and game experience. The knowledge mining module is responsible for discovering useful patterns from the player s historical interaction data to infer the preference of the player. The results will be used for decision making by the virtual agents and game manager agent. The Goal Net methodology is used to model the mental state of a NPC or a group of characters, ranging from single responsive animations to dynamic plot development. Virtual game characters are able to demonstrate their emotional and physical states by choosing appropriate actions. To simulate the dynamic behaviors of the background entities, such as a flock of animals, a crowd of people, formation behavior controls are embedded into the system to allow a group of entities to behave in a coordinated fashion [5]. Agent cloning is used to model the formation behavior control to increase flexibility, which enables the dynamic changes of character behaviors on the fly. The game manager is a high level agent to oversee and coordinate all the virtual characters in the game. 4. CONCLUSION In this paper, we proposed a generic emotion-aware agent platform to automatically adapt the game contents and game experience by learning the player s real-time feedback from the emotion analysis and gesture tracking. The adaptation of the virtual world in the game to the player s real-time reactions will offer a high level of interactivity to the players. Currently, the proposed agent platform has been integrated with several existing commercial game engines including Unreal Engine 3 and Torque, etc. Several simple games have bee created using the current platform and the results are very encouraging. In our future work, we will create an interactive film using our user emotion-aware agent platform. 5. REFERENCES [1] Miao, Y., Liu, Z. Q., and Miao, C. Y., Dynamical Cognitive Network, an Extension of Fuzzy Cognitive Maps, IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems (IEEE TFS), vol.9, no.5, pp. 760-770, 2001. [2] Ortony, A., Clore, G., & Collins, A. (1988). H., "Goal Oriented Modeling for Intelligent Software Agents", Proc of the 2004 IEEE/WIC/ACM International Conference on Intelligent Agent Technology (IAT'04), Beijing, China, September, 20-24, 2004. article_rec.title: The virtual Jet Ski
article_rec.subtitle: a visual-physical motion simulation

abstract.par: Generating effective immersive environments involves providing the synchronized and timely presentation of a range of different perceptual cues. This paper describes the development of a virtual reality system that uses both visual and physical motion cues to simulate a Jet Ski. The paper provides details on the generation of physical and visual motion cues using a stereo HMD and a physical motion platform.

ref.ref_text: Robinson, M., Laurence, J., Zacher, J., Hogue, A., Allison, R., Harris, L. R., Jenkin, M. and Stuerzlinger, W., IVY: The Immersive Visual environment at York. IPT Symposium (held in conjunction with VR2002). 2002.

fulltext.ft_body: The Virtual Jet Ski: a visual-physical motion simulation Andrew Speers, Lowell Crotin, Douglas Stamp, Timothy Crawford, Tushar Goel York University 4700 Keele St., Toronto, ON M3J 1P3 CANADA speers@cse.yorku.ca ABSTRACT Generating effective immersive environments involves providing the synchronized and timely presentation of a range of different perceptual cues. This paper describes the development of a virtual reality system that uses both visual and physical motion cues to simulate a Jet Ski. The paper provides details on the generation of physical and visual motion cues using a stereo HMD and a physical motion platform. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.3.7 [Three-Dimensional Graphics and Realism]: Virtual reality General Terms Performance, System Design and Integration, Experimentation, Human Factors Keywords Integrated visual-physical motion environment simulation 1. INTRODUCTION In designing and implementing VR systems the immersion of the user within the environment is perhaps the most difficult feature to achieve, and yet informally it is often the measure of success for such a system. We investigated the ability of multi-modal sensory cues to increase the immersion of the user. The resulting virtual reality system consists of a race car chair mounted to a Stewart Platform; which provides motion cues for the user, coupled with a tracked head mounted display (HMD), which provides visual stereo cues to the user. Tracking of the motion of the platform and the user s head is used to provide a realistic user­driven rendering of the environment. A custom virtual visual and physical environment was created for the user to navigate through. 2. VISUAL ENVIRONMENT The virtual environment simulated a Jet Ski environment including both water and land features. A figure eight course of buoys and a start gate helped to guide the user s motion (see Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. FuturePlay @ Vancouver Digital Week 2010, May 6-7, 2010, Vancouver, Canada. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 (a) User (b) Visual display Figure 1. System and Virtual Environment Figure 1). Ramps located within the environment are available for the user to interact with. All of these elements interact with the platform in various ways and are discussed in the Stewart Platform section of the paper below. The visual scene is rendered using OpenGL on parallel machines synchronized using a custom software package known as VE [1]. Stereo image streams are presented to the user via a HMD. A simple physics engine based on ODE provides collision and physics to the simulation. A multitude of objects are constantly in motion in the rendered environment. These objects help distract the user from focusing too much on any specific sensory input placed on the user, and thus increase the effectiveness of the rest of the system as a whole in immersing the user. Examples include a boat that constantly travels about the perimeter of the course, birds that periodically fly overhead and the motion of the sky and water. The water is designed as two height maps modeled from photos of standing waves in water. These maps are set in sinusoidal motion (both set out of phase with each other). This provides a highly complicated, intersecting, fluid-like surface underneath the user. The motion of the buoys is tied to the motion of the water and thus maintains the illusion of the rendered water. The motion of the water height also provides a basic background motion to drive the motion base. 3. PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT Physical motion cues are provided via a Stewart Platform. The Stewart Platform adds a sensory input to the system which is used in order to immerse the user within the virtual environment. The net motion of the platform is generated by layering several motion components together. Five main classes of motion are simulated on the platform: turning, acceleration, jumping, collisions and wave noise. Individual motions can be tuned, enabled and disabled independently. This feature aided development and accommodates user preferences, as well as providing a framework for testing and evaluating the effectiveness of each of the motions individually. 259 A useful concept used in amusement park motion rides is that of washout. A design limitation of the Stewart Platform is that the greatest range of mobility is available when the device is in its home position. When the platform is moved away from this position, motion in various directions can be greatly diminished. For this reason it is desirable to constantly attempt to bring the user back to the home position of the device without the user sensing this motion. This is accomplished in two ways. First, the transition itself is made as smooth as possible. Second, the transition is made while wave motions are simulated on the platform. This additional motion noise allows this transition to take place with minimal impact on the user s experience. 3.1 Control Systems Introducing physical motion to the user involves changing the orientation or position of the user. Two types of motion control systems were used to provide an accurate portrayal of the physical motion of the Jet Ski. In order to provide smooth motion transitions an S-Curve (hyperbolic tangent curve) motion controller was used to introduce motion changes to the platform in a smooth manner (Figure 2). Figure 2. S-Curve Controller Example This controller provides smooth motion transitions though it introduces latency/responsiveness issues which can act as a distraction and decrease the immersion of the user in the environment. In order to address responsiveness issues an exponential controller was added into the control scheme for the system. This controller is then tuned so that more emphasis is placed on recent inputs, making the system more responsive as a result. The S-Curve controller is used for washing-out motions and the exponential controller is used for everything else, making the platforms motion much more in-sync with the user s inputs and keeping the sudden and jerky motions of the platform to a minimum. This combination results in a compelling portrayal of the motion of a Jet Ski, while finding a balance with the other sensory inputs provided by the system. 3.2 Platform Environment Synchronization There can be a noticeable delay between events occurring in the virtual environment and the corresponding motion of the physical platform. For example, in the case of collisions, without synchronization there will be a noticeable delay between the visual motion stopping in the virtual environment and the corresponding collision motion on the platform. This inconsistency breaks the immersive experience for the user. In order to remedy this situation two collision regions were created around each object in the environment; one tightly wrapped to the object, which is used to stop the motion for a visual collision cue, and one that is slightly larger, to cue the motion of the platform. This brings the two cues back into sync, thus diminishing the effect of the synchronization error. While inconsistencies like this may seem minor, when present, they can be very distracting to the user. 4. TRACKING When viewing a large environment, it is natural for a person to move their head to reposition their eyes. This allows the person to view more of the area. A common constraint in typical virtual world applications (i.e. video games) is that the camera view into the world is bound to the virtual body. This looks and feels incorrect as the viewport into the virtual world is not rendered based on the head position of the user. A ground-based head tracker is introduced into the system in order to decouple the virtual body from the virtual view into the world. This coupling between the users head position and the rendering of the viewport into the virtual world provides the necessary state information to update the visual display with head motion. A ground-based platform tracker was added to the system which permits the rendering of the virtual environment to be dependent on both the user s head position as well as the position of the platform. This provides a method of decoupling visual and physical motion cues. In the case of simulating acceleration, for example, the pitch of the platform is not presented in the visual display to the user. This causes the pitch acceleration generated by the platform to be more readily perceived as acceleration through the water. For turning, the visual roll of the platform is amplified in the visual output relative to the physical roll. This causes the perceived roll experienced by the user to be magnified when compared to the motion of the platform alone. When done to an unrealistic extreme while maintaining the same roll motion of the platform, the exaggerated visual roll can make the user feel like they are going to fall off of the machine. This trick allows for the magnitude of the platform roll motion to be reduced while maintaining the same experience for the user. 5. SUMMARY This paper describes a virtual Jet Ski virtual reality simulation that integrates both visual and physical motion cues and some of the tricks used to increase the user s immersion within the virtual environment. The use of several different sensory inputs provides a method for distracting the user from any inconsistencies in any given medium, either visual or physical, by blending all the sensory inputs together and making the individual sensory inputs as consistent as possible. By providing multi-modal inputs to the user it is possible for a small deficiency of any one input to be compensated through the use of another input. When the inputs are balanced and blended correctly the immersion caused by the system as a whole is greater than the contributions of the individual inputs alone. 6. REFERENCES [1] Robinson, M., Laurence, J., Zacher, J., Hogue, A., Allison, R., Harris, L. R., Jenkin, M. and Stuerzlinger, W., IVY: The Immersive Visual environment at York. IPT Symposium (held in conjunction with VR2002). 2002. 7. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS We would like to thank Michael Jenkin and James Zacher for their guidance during the course of our development.

fulltext.ft_body: Wiimote-Controlled Stereoscopic MRI Visualization With Sonic Augmentation Jonathan Lam1, Christopher Collins2, Bill Kapralos1,3, Andrew Hogue1,3 and Miguel A. Garcia-Ruiz4 1Faculty of Business and Information Technology, 2Faculty of Science, 3Health Education Technology Research Unit. University of Ontario Institute of Technology. 2000 Simcoe Street North, Oshawa, Canada. L1H 7K4. 4College of Telematics University of Colima Ave. Universidad 333, Colima, 28040, Mexico {jonathan.lam, christopher.collins, bill.kapralos, andrew.hogue}@uoit.ca mgarcia@ucol.mx ABSTRACT Medical imaging techniques such as Computed Tomography (CT) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) that produce three-dimensional views of the body have become common­place. In this paper we provide a preliminary overview of an MRI stereoscopic visualization system that we have recently begun developing. Stereoscopic visualization aug­mented with auditory cues (soni.cation) and a Nintendo Wii remote controller ( Wiimote ) allows the user to easily manipulate the visualization. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.4.10 [Image Processing and Computer Vision]: Im­age Representation Volumetric. Keywords Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), visualization, soni.ca­tion, Wiimote 1. INTRODUCTION Medical imaging, or the use of imaging-based techniques to generate and process images of the human body (or parts of the human body) is an integral component in clinical de­cision making. Recently, techniques such as Computed To­mography (CT) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) which produce three-dimensional views of the human body (or parts of the body) have become commonplace, aiding in the diagnoses of a number of diseases and in surgical plan­ning as they provides surgeons and medical experts with internal views of the patient s body prior to the surgery. This reduces the likelihood of damaging organs and other parts of the body. Such techniques reconstruct a three­dimensional view ( volume ) using a series of slicing images Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for pro.t or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the .rst page. To copy otherwise, to republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior speci.c permission and/or a fee. ACM FuturePlay 2010 Vancouver, BC. Canada. May 6-7 2010. Copyright 2010 ACM 978-1-4503-0235-7/10/05 $10.00 and ultimately require visualization and analysis of three­dimensional (3D) objects in order to transform, and view data as images in order to allow an understanding and in­sight into the generated data (i.e., to make sense of the large data the techniques generate) [2]. Visualization technology makes it possible to provide a multimedia tool for medical instruction, diagnosis, and research, whereby the structure and function of human organs are explored interactively [2]. Recently we have begun development of a dynamic MRI stereoscopic visualization system whereby the presented vi­suals are augmented with auditory cues (soni.cation) and a Nintendo Wii remote ( Wiimote ) controller, allows the user to easily manipulate the visualization. In this paper we describe our work in progress and present a preliminary overview of the system. 2. OVERVIEW The system itself is comprised of three components: i) stereoscopic visualization, ii) soni.cation, and iii) interac­tion (input/output). The details of each component are provided below. 2.1 Stereoscopic Visualization Currently, visualization consists of rendering the three­dimensional MRI data of either single or multiple two­dimensional slices of data 3D (e.g., voxels ); the data can be viewed as individual slices on any of the three planes (sagittal, coronal, and transverse). Figure 1 provides a sam­ple rendering across each of the three planes. The data to construct the renderings illustrated in Figure 1 was obtained from the 2010 IEEE Visualization Contest and consists of two data sets: i) an MRI brain scan of a patient with an inter-cerebral metathesis, and ii) an MRI and CT brain scan of another patient with a glioma [6] (in this work, only the MRI dataset is being used). To ensure real-time render­ing rates, the system dynamically adjusts the level of detail based on the zoom level. Stereoscopic rendering is accom­plished using the OpenGL graphics API and displayed using a passive stereo dual projector system. 2.2 Soni.cation Auditory display is the use of non-speech sound to present information, and soni.cation is a speci.c type of auditory display that refers to the mapping of data onto parameters of non-verbal sound, such as pitch, volume, timbre, dura­ Figure 1: Varying viewing modes. Clockwise from top­left: .ltered views of the brain, and tumour, and sagittal slicing view with no .lter. tion, frequency, amplitude, and rhythm in a computer inter­face [4]. We are currently examining a number of mappings between MRI data and auditory parameters to determine whether the presence of soni.cation augments visualization in a meaningful manner. The goal is to provide auditory feedback regarding occluded voxel data that is not visible to the user. Although soni.cation has been successfully applied for analyzing biomedical data (e.g., soni.cation of electroen­cephalogram data [3]), research on soni.cation of multivari­ate image analysis (including MRI data) has only recently begun [5]. Wake.eld et al. [1] are developing and testing a three-dimensional virtual environment that provides multi­modal interaction using biofeedback data and claim that this environment allows real-time soni.cation and visualization of the user s brain activity using biosignal sensors, includ­ing user interaction with static audio-visual functional MRI data. Soni.cation enables us to provide multi-modal feedback so the user can focus on visualizing muscle-tissue/bone while planning the surgery and still be able to have knowledge of the location/presence of tumor cells. For example, voxels corresponding to a region of interest, such as a brain tumor, may be obscured by the voxels corresponding to the brain and skull. However, by mapping the regions representing the tumor map to a particular pure tone whose frequency and/or intensity varies relative to the position of the on screen cur­sor (whose position can be calculated using ray-casting), the user can be alerted to the presence of a tumor even when it is obscured. This technique may be applied to multiple regions of interest, each emitting a unique sound allowing each region of interest to be clearly distinguished. Soni.­cation can reduce the frequent need of switching between rendering modes to analyze multiple data sets. In addition, it may be a useful tool in neurosurgical planning as it can be used for surgical planning. 2.3 Interaction Interaction is accomplished using Nintendo s Wii remote­controller ( Wiimote ) whereby a user is able to interact with and manipulate objects in the virtual 3D world using gesture recognition and pointing. For example, the user can orient the rendered MRI data in order to view it from di.erent angles. The Wiimote face buttons allow the user to toggle between di.erent rendering modes (e.g., rendering the entire data set, a single slice of data on one of the three planes, or a region of interest such as a tumor). Using the Wiimote s infrared pointing capabilities, the user is able to control a cursor which, as previously described, is used in conjunction with the soni.cation system. This gives the user full control over the orientation of the MRI data and can enable a simple point-to-zoom gesture that is both intuitive and usable in this context. Figure 2: Using the Wiimote to orient MRI voxel data. 3. CONCLUSIONS This paper has described preliminary details regarding an ongoing project that seeks the development of a system for MRI visualization that is augmented with auditory informa­tion in order to provide a quick overview of occluded infor­mation not visible to the user. We are planning to add haptic feedback to the system to enable the user to be presented with three display modalities and study the interaction be­tween soni.cation, visualization, and haptic feedback along with their e.ectiveness to isolate and analyze interesting re­gions in the MRI data. In addition to viewing MRI data, we are con.dent the multi-modal interaction techniques de­veloped here will be transferable to other domains including virtual reality and gaming. 4.
